COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  L.D. 390  1

REPORT B  3 
APPROPRIATIONS AND FINANCIAL AFFAIRS  4 
Reproduced and distributed under the direction of the Clerk of the House.  5 
STATE OF MAINE  6 
HOUSE OF REPRESENTAT IVES  7 
128TH LEGISLATURE  8 
FIRST REGULAR SESSIO N 9 
COMMITTEE AM ENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390, Bill, “An Act Making 10 
Unified Appropriations and Allocations for the Expenditures of State Government, 11 
General Fund and Other Funds and Changing Certain Provisions of the Law Necessary to 12 
the Proper Operations of State Gov ernment for the Fiscal Years Ending June 30, 2018 13 
and June 30, 2019”  14 
Amend the bill by striking out everything after the title and inserting the following:  15 
'Emergency preamble. Whereas, acts and resolves of the Legislature do not 16 
become effective until 90 days after adjournment unless enacted as emergencies; and  17 
Whereas, the 90 -day period may not terminate until after the beginning of the next 18 
fiscal year; and  19 
Whereas, certain obligations and expenses incident to the operation of state 20 
departments and insti tutions will become due and payable immediately; and  21 
Whereas, in the judgment of the Legislature, these facts create an emergency within 22 
the meaning of the Constitution of Maine and require the following legislation as 23 
immediately necessary for the preserv ation of the public peace, health and safety; now, 24 
therefore,  25 
Be it enacted by the People of the State of Maine as follows:  26 
PART A  27 
Sec. A -1.  Appropriations and allocations.  The following appropriations and 28 
allocations are made.  29 
ADMINISTRATIVE AND FINANCI AL SERVICES, DEPARTMENT OF  30

Administration - Human Resources 0038  19 
Initiative: Eliminates one vacant Plumber II position and one vacant Boiler Engineer 20 
position from the Building and Grounds Operations program, General Fund. This 21 
initiative also transfe rs one vacant Space Management Specialist position and one vacant 22 
High Voltage Electrician position from the Buildings and Grounds Operations program to 23 
the Administration - Human Resources program within the same fund and reorganizes the 24 
High Voltage Elec trician position to a Public Service Manager II position and the Space 25 
Management Specialist position to a Public Service Manager III position.  26

Improvements - Planning/Construction - Administration program to the Administration - 34 
Hum an Resources program within the same fund to realign department resources to areas 35 
of greatest need. The employee retains all rights as a classified employee, as well as all 36 GENERAL FUND  2017 -18 2018 -19

Special Services Team Z080  6

Systems Team program within the General Fun d for All Other costs related to 2 8 
Education Specialist III positions transferred in Public Law 2015, chapter 267.  9

Special Services Team Z080  15 
Initiative: Transfers, reallocates and reorganizes various positions and adjusts between 16 
All Other and Personal Services within the Department of Education as a result of an 17 
internal review and reorganization of department structure. Establishes one Managem ent 18 
Analyst I position and one Public Service Coordinator I position and eliminates one 19 
vacant Regional Education Representative position and one vacant Office Associate II 20 
position as part of the reorganization of department structure. Position details ar e on file 21 
in the Bureau of the Budget.  22 
 23 
 24 
 25 
 26 
 27 
 
Special Services Team Z080  28 
Initiative: Continues one Public Service Ma nager II position previously established by 29 
Financial Order 004200 F7.  Transfers and reallocates the position from 100% General 30 
Fund in the Special Services Team program to 70% General Fund and 30% Federal 31 
Expenditures Fund within the same program. Reduce s funding for All Other in the Child 32 
Development Services program, General Fund in order to offset the increase in Personal 33 
Services costs in the Special Services Team program, General Fund.  34

within the same program and adjusts All Other related to STA -CAP charges.  Also 23

Expenditures Fund within the same program and adjusts All Other related to STA -CAP 26 
charges to be in line  with federal match requirements. Position detail is on file in the 27 
Bureau of the Budget.  28

position was originally established as a limited -period position by Financial Order 4 
000674 F2 and continued by Public Law 2013, chapter 368 and by Public Law 2015, 5 
chapter 267.  6

General Assistance - Reimbursement to Cities  and Towns 0130  14 
Initiative: Reduces funding in the general assistance program for a person who has 15 
exhausted the 60 -month lifetime limit on Temporary Assistance for Needy Families 16 
program benefits and who is therefore ineligible to receive municipal genera l assistance 17 
program benefits and for an applicant for general assistance who voluntarily abandons or 18 
refuses to use an available resource without just cause and is therefore ineligible to 19 
receive general assistance to replace the abandoned resource for a period of 120 days.  20

 Page 452 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  Initiative: Reorganizes 2 Public Service Manager II positions from range 30  to range 32, 1 
one Biologist I position to a Biologist II position, one Office Specialist I Manager 2 
Supervisor position to a Planning and Research Associate II position, one Programmer 3 
Analyst position to a Business Systems Administrator position and one Of fice Associate I 4 
position to an Office Associate II position, all allocated between the General Fund and 5 
Federal Expenditures Fund in the Fisheries and Hatcheries Operations program, the 6 
General Fund and Federal Expenditures Fund in the Resource Management  Services - 7 
Inland Fisheries and Wildlife program and the Other  Special Revenue Funds in the 8 
Endangered Nongame Operations program.  Eliminates one Management Analyst II 9 
position funded in the General Fund and Federal Expenditures Fund of the Resource 10 
Management Services - Inland Fisheries and Wildlife program.  Also adjusts All Other 11 
funding for the reorganization and contractual work.  12

Technology Servic es Z242  6 
Initiative: Transfers and reallocates the cost of one Public Service Manager II position, 7 
one GIS Coordinator position and 2 Senior Programmer Analyst positions and associated 8 
All Other costs from 100% Office of Information Services Fund to 100% Ge neral Fund 9 
and reallocates the cost of one Public Service Manager II position from 100% Office of 10 
Information Services Fund to 85% Other Special Revenue Funds and 15% General Fund 11 
within the same program to provide funding for Maine's Geographic Informatio n Services 12 
and GeoLibrary.  13

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  D.  A group of school administrative units that has an interlocal agreement pursuant 1 
to Title 30 -A, chapter 115 to establish a regional education service agenc y to jointly 2 
purchase the services of a superintendent may elect the superintendent in the manner 3

Sec. C -4.  20-A MRSA §1485, sub -§1-A is enacted to read:  5 
1-A.  Instructional expenditures transition; annual targets.  A regional school unit 6 
shall meet the annual targets for the direct instruction percentage share of total General 7 
Fund expenditures as follows:  8 
A.  For fiscal year 2018 -19, the target is 61%;  9 
B.  For fiscal year 2019 -20, the target is 63%;  10 
C.  For fiscal year 2020 -21, the target is 65%;  11 
D.  For fiscal year 2021 -22, the target is 67%; and  12 
E.  For fiscal year 2022 -23 and succeeding years, the target is 70%.  13 
For the purposes of this subsection, "direct instruction" means those expenditures in 14 
subsection 1, pa ragraph A for regular instruction, special education instruction, career and 15 
technical education instruction and other instruction including summer school instruction 16 
and extracurricular instruction as defined in the State's accounting handbook for local 17 
school systems.  18 
Sec. C -5.  20-A MRSA §2405, sub -§9, as amended by PL 2011, c. 570, §8, is 19 
further amended to read:  20 
9.  Transition period.  The public charter school program set out in this chapter must 21 
begin with a 10 -year transition period, beginning on th e effective date of this chapter.  22 
During the transition period, the commissioner shall register the charters approved by all 23 
authorizers in chronological order by date of approval under this chapter.  During the 24 
transition period, only 10 public charter s chools may be approved by the commission ; the 25 
Maine School for Marine Science, Technology, Transportation and Engineering, 26 
established in chapter 312 -A, is not considered a public charter school for the purposes of 27 
this cap .  Once the cap is reached, the c ommissioner may not accept further registrations 28 
from the commission and only local school boards and collaboratives of local school 29 
boards may approve charters until the end of the transition period.  30 
This subsection is repealed July 1, 2022.  31

amended to read:  4 
3.  Grant funds.  Beginning wit h the 2015 -2016 school year and for each subsequent 5 
school year, the commissioner may provide start -up funding to qualified school 6 
administrative units to operate public preschool programs for children 4 years of age. 7 
Grants provided for allowable costs fo r approved public preschool programs must be 8 
provided from state, federal or private funds appropriated, allocated or authorized by the 9 
Legislature for that purpose and must include $4,000,000 annually in revenues distributed 10 
from general purpose aid for l ocal schools that the department receives from casino slot 11 
machines or casino table games pursuant to section 15671, subsection 5 -A.  Any balance 12 
of funds appropriated, allocated or authorized by the Legislature remaining at the end of a 13 
fiscal year do not  lapse and are carried forward to the next fiscal year to carry out the 14 
purposes of this subchapter . 15

Sec. C -10.  20-A MRSA §4775, as amended by PL 2013, c. 368, Pt. C, §2 , is 18 
further amended to read:  19 
§4775.  Payment; appropriations  20 
The Until the 2018 -2019 school year, the  department shall pay 50% of the in -state 21 
tuition for the first 6 credit hours taken each semester by a student at an eligible 22 
institution and up to 12 cr edit hours per academic year.  The eligible institution may not 23 
make any additional tuition charges for the course but may impose fees and charges, 24 
other than tuition, that are ordinarily imposed on students not covered by this chapter.  25 
Funds appropriated  to the department to carry out the purposes of this chapter must be in 26 
addition to the customary and ongoing amounts appropriated for general purpose aid for 27 
local schools.  28 
Beginning with the 2018 -2019 school year, the department shall reimburse each 29 
eligible institution the cost of in -state tuition up to the maximum rate, calculated as 30 
follows: 50% of the average in -state tuition rate for the highest and lowest in -state tuition 31 
rates established by the University of Maine System for eligible institutions within the 32 
system for the first 6 credit hours taken each semester by a student at an eligible 33 
institution and up to 12 credit hours per academic year. The eligible institution may not 34 
make any additional tuition charges for the course but may impose fees and charges, 35 
other than tuition, that are ordinarily imposed on students not covered by this chapter. 36 
Funds appropriated to the department to carry out the purposes of this chapter must be in 37 
addition to the customary and ongoing amounts appropriated for g eneral purpose aid for 38 
local schools.  39 
Sec. C -11.  20-A MRSA §5806, sub -§2, as repealed and replaced by PL 2013, c. 40 
497, §1, is amended to read:  41 
2.  Maximum allowable tuition.   The maximum allowable tuition charged to a 42 
school administrative unit by a priva te school is the rate established under subsection 1 or 43 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 629 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  the state average per public secondary student cost as adjusted, whichever is lower, plus 1 
an insured value factor.  The insured value factor is computed by dividing 5% of the 2 
insured value of school b uildings and equipment by the average number of pupils 3 
enrolled in the school on October 1st and April 1st of the year immediately before the 4 
school year for which the tuition charge is computed.  From school year 2009 -2010 to 5 
school year 2013 -2014, a scho ol administrative unit is not required to pay an insured 6 
value factor greater than 5% of the school's tuition rate or $500 per student, whichever is 7 
less, unless the legislative body of the school administrative unit votes to authorize its 8 
school board to pay a higher insured value factor that is no greater than 10% of the 9 
school’s tuition rate per student.  For the 2014 -2015 school year, a school administrative 10 
unit is not required to pay an insured value factor greater than 6% of the school's tuition 11 
rate per student, unless the legislative body of the school administrative unit votes to 12 
authorize its school board to pay a higher insured value factor that is no greater than 10% 13 
of the school's tuition rate per student.  Beginning in the 2015 -2016 school ye ar, a school 14 
administrative unit is not required to pay an insured value factor greater than the amount 15 
of the prior school year's insured value factor adjusted by a percentage equal to the 16 
percentage change in the state share percentage of the total cost of funding public 17 
education in the prior school year as determined by section 15671, subsection 7, 18 
paragraph C D as compared to the applicable percentage for the current school year.  In 19 
no case may the insured value factor be less than 6% or greater than 10% of the school's 20 
tuition rate per student, unless the legislative body of the school administrative unit votes 21 
to authorize its school board to pay an insured value factor that exceeds the amount 22 
otherwise permitted by this subsection by no more than 5%  of the school's tuition rate per 23 
student.  For the 2013 -2014 school year only, the maximum allowable tuition charged to 24 
a school administrative unit by a private school that participates in the Maine Public 25 
Employees Retirement System must be increased ab ove the amount otherwise permitted 26 
under this section by an amount equal to the calculated normal cost of teacher retirement 27 
for that school divided by the number of enrolled students as of October 1, 2012.  28

Sec. C -17.  20-A MRSA §8232, sub -§2, as enacted by PL 2015, c. 363, §4, is 7 
amended to read:  8 
2.  Tuition; room and board; funding.   Students from this State may attend the 9 
school free of tuition charges.  Additional funding for students from thi s State may be 10 
provided within amounts appropriated for that purpose as follows.  11 
A.  The amount must be paid in 4 equal quarterly payments during the year of 12 
attendance.  The first payment must be made by July 31st.  The amount of tuition and 13 
other costs p aid for all students is limited to the amount appropriated for this purpose.  14 
State funding for the school must be provided using the method established for public 15 
charter schools that are authorized by the commission in accordance with the funding 16 
provisio ns established in section 2413 -A and section 15683 -B.  To be eligible for 17 
state funding under this paragraph, a student must have resided in Maine with a 18 
parent, other relative or guardian for at least 6 months immediately preceding 19 
application to the scho ol. 20 
B.  Except as otherwise provided in this paragraph, effective July 1, 2018, the student 21 
or the student's parent or guardian shall pay to the school the cost of room and board 22 
for the school year.  In the case of financial need, the State shall pay to t he school the 23 
difference between the cost of room and board and the student's or the student's 24 
family's ability to pay that cost.  The board of trustees shall establish rules governing 25 
the determination of financial need and the cost and schedule of paymen t of room and 26 
board under this paragraph.  The determination of financial need must be based on a 27 
nationally recognized public or private school financial needs assessment system.  A 28 
student may use scholarship funds in place of payment for all or part of the cost of 29 
room and board and any other fees or expenses incurred as a result of that student's 30 
enrollment at the school.  31 
Sec. C -18.  20-A MRSA §8235 -A is enacted to read:  32 
§8235 -A.  Oversight by the commission  33 
The Maine Charter School Commission, as set o ut in section 2405, subsection 8, shall 34 
provide oversight of the school in accordance with the following.  35 
1.  Data collection; monitoring.  The commission shall collect, analyze and report 36 
all data from state assessments in accordance with the performance framework developed 37 
under section 2409, subsection 1.  The commission shall monitor the performance and 38 
legal compliance of the school, including collecting and analyzing all data to support 39 
ongoing evaluation of the school.  In order to carry out the purp oses of this subsection, 40 
the school shall provide to the commission information that the commission requests in 41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 631 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  the format, with the content and within the time schedules, established by the 1 
commission.  2 
2.  Notification of unsatisfactory performance or com pliance.  If the school's 3 
performance or legal compliance appears unsatisfactory, the commission shall promptly 4 
provide written notice to the school of identified problems and provide reasonable 5 
opportunity for the school to remedy those problems.  The com mission shall provide the 6 
commissioner with a copy of the written notice and a report of the plan developed by the 7 
school to remedy the identified problems.  8 
Sec. C -19.  20-A MRSA §13007, sub -§2, ¶D, as amended by PL 2015, c. 389, 9 
Pt. C, §1 and c. 395, §5, is repealed.  10 
Sec. C -20.  20-A MRSA §13013 -A, as amended by PL 2011, c. 702, §2, is further 11 
amended to read:  12 
§13013 -A.  Scholarship fund for national board -certified teachers  13 
1.  Department of Education salary supplement.   Notwithstanding any other 14 
provisio n of law, the Department of Education shall provide a public school teacher or a 15 
teacher in a publicly supported secondary school who has attained certification from the 16 
National Board for Professional Teaching Standards, or its successor organization, wit h 17 
an annual national board certification salary supplement for the life of the certificate.  The 18 
salary supplement must be added to the teacher's base salary and must be considered in 19 
the calculation for contributions to the Maine Public Employees Retireme nt System.  If a 20 
nationally certified teacher is no longer employed as a teacher, the supplement ceases.  21 
The amount of the salary supplement is:  22 
A.  For fiscal year 2012 -13, $2,500;  23 
B.  For fiscal year 2013 -14, $2,750; and  24 
C.  For fiscal year 2014 -15 and succeeding years, $3,000.  25 
1-A.  Funding revenue.   The National Board Certification Salary Supplement Fund 26 
is established as a nonlapsing dedicated fund within the Department of Education 27 
beginning in fiscal year 2012 -13. The salary supplement under subsect ion 1 must be 28 
funded from fees collected by the department pursuant to section 13007, subsection 1.  29 
2.  Local filing; certification.   On or before October 15th annually, the 30 
superintendent of schools of a school administrative unit or the chief administrat ive 31 
officer of a publicly supported secondary school or a career and technical education 32 
region shall file with the commissioner a certified list of national board -certified teachers 33 
eligible to receive the salary supplement pursuant to subsection 1.  34 
3.  P ayment.   The department shall provide the salary supplement to school 35 
administrative units and publicly supported secondary schools for eligible teachers no 36 
later than February 15th of each year.  37 
4.  Expend funds.   A school administrative unit or a publicl y supported secondary 38 
school may expend funds received through the salary supplement under subsection 1 39 
without calling for a special meeting of the local legislative body.  40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 632 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  5.  Scholarship fund.   The National Board Certification Scholarship Fund is 1 
establi shed as a nonlapsing dedicated fund, referred to in this subsection as "the 2 
scholarship fund," within the Department of Education to encourage teachers to apply to 3 
and enroll in the certification program offered by the National Board for Professional 4 
Teach ing Standards or its successor organization, referred to in this subsection and 5 
subsection 6 as "the certification program."  A school administrative unit or a publicly 6 
supported secondary school may request scholarship funds on behalf of its teachers who 7 
meet the requirements set forth in subsection 6.  The department shall award funds 8 
according to this subsection.  9 
A.  In fiscal year 2012 -13, the department shall allocate $50,000 from fees collected 10 
by the department pursuant to section 13007, subsection 1  to the scholarship fund.  11 
The department shall award an amount equal to the cost of the certification program 12 
less any other funds received by the applicant on a first -come first -served basis for 13 
the first 20 teachers accepted into the certification progr am annually.  14 
B.  Beginning in fiscal year 2013 -14, the department shall allocate $75,000 from fees 15 
collected by the department pursuant to section 13007, subsection 1 each fiscal year 16 
to the scholarship fund.  The department shall award an amount equal to the cost of 17 
enrollment in the certification program less any other funds received by the applicant 18 
to not more than 30 teachers accepted into the program annually . 19 
6.  Eligibility requirements.  In order to receive scholarship funds according to 20 
subsection  5 on behalf of a teacher, the school administrative unit or a publicly supported 21 
secondary school must certify to the department that the teacher:  22 
A.  Is currently employed by a school administrative unit or a publicly supported 23 
secondary school;  24 
B.  Has completed at least 3 years of teaching in the State;  25 
C.  Has agreed to mentor at least one other teacher employed in the State through the 26 
national board certification process to apply to and enroll in the certification program;  27 
D.  Has provided documentat ion of acceptance into the certification program; and  28 
E.  Has disclosed any other funds received to cover the cost of the certification 29 
program.  30 
7.  Nonlapsing funds.   Any unencumbered balance of the National Board 31 
Certification Scholarship Fund under subs ection 5 remaining at the end of a fiscal year 32 
may not lapse but must be carried forward to be used for the same purpose.  33

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  15.  Special education budgetary hardship adjustment.  Beginning in fiscal year 1 
2018 -19, the following provisions apply to adjustments for special education budgetary 2 
hardships.  3 
A.  If a school administrative unit determined eligible pursuant to paragraph B 4 
petitions the commissioner and demonstrates that the unexpected education costs of 5 
placement of a student in a special education program will cause a budgetary 6 
hardship, the com missioner may provide to the unit an amount not to exceed the 7 
allowable costs of the placement less 3 times the statewide special education EPS 8 
per-pupil rate for in -district placements or less 4 times the statewide special education 9 
EPS per -pupil rate for  out-of-district placements. The allowable costs are those 10 
special education costs described in section 15672, subsection 30 -A, paragraphs A 11 
and B.  12 
B.  The commissioner shall determine that a school administrative unit is eligible for 13 
an adjustment under p aragraph A if:  14 
(1)  The student's placement is a result of an appeal approved by the 15 
commissioner pursuant to section 5205, subsection 6 or the student became the 16 
fiscal responsibility of the school administrative unit after the passage of that 17 
unit's budg et for the current fiscal year; and  18 
(2)  The school administrative unit's unexpected allowable costs result in a 5% or 19 
more increase in the percentage of the unit's special education budget category to 20 
the unit's total budget excluding the debt service bud get category.  21 
C.  The funds for adjustments under paragraph A are limited to the amount 22 
appropriated by the Legislature for that purpose, and any unexpended balance from 23 
another program's appropriated amounts under this chapter may be applied by the 24 
commis sioner toward the adjustments.  25 
D.  A school administrative unit may expend the funds from the adjustment under 26 
paragraph A without seeking approval by the unit's legislative body.  27

Sec. C -53.  Authorization of payments.  If the State's continued obligation for 27 
any individual component contained in those sections of this Part that set the total cost of 28 
funding public e ducation from kindergarten to grade 12 and the local and state 29 
contributions for that purpose exceeds the level of funding provided for that component, 30 
any unexpended balances occurring in other programs may be applied to avoid proration 31 
of payments for an y individual component. Any unexpended balances from this Part may 32 
not lapse but must be carried forward for the same purpose.  33 
Sec. C -54.  Limit of State's obligation.  Those sections of this Part that set the 34 
total cost of funding public education from ki ndergarten to grade 12 and the local and 35 
state contributions for that purpose may not be construed to require the State to provide 36 
payments that exceed the appropriation of funds for general purpose aid for local schools 37 
for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2017 and ending June 30, 2018.  38

plan for the funding of public education from kindergarten to grade 12 by using the local 40 
and state contributions. The plan for a new school fundin g formula must be based on 41 
providing direct instruction and support for student learning and include a statewide 42 
teacher contract and the implementation of a system to measure and ensure that school 43 
administrative units are held accountable for the intende d use of the state funds. The new 44  State contribution to the total cost of

Sec. D -1.  5 MRSA §1518 -A, sub -§1-A, ¶A, as amended by PL 2015, c. 390, §1, 17 
is further amended to read:  18 
A.  By November 1st annually, the State Tax Assessor shall calculate the amount by 19 
which the income tax rates under T itle 36, section 5111, subsections 1-F, 2-F and 3 -F 20 
1-G, 2-G and 3 -G may be reduced during the subsequent tax year using the amount 21 
available from the fund. Bracket rate reductions must be a minimum of 0.2 22 
percentage points in the first year in which reduc tions are made and a minimum of 23 
0.1 percentage points in subsequent years. If sufficient funds are not available to pay 24 
for the minimum reduction, a rate reduction may not be made until the amount in the 25 
fund is sufficient to pay for the reduction. When th e amount is sufficient to pay for 26 
the reduction, the reduction must first be applied equally to each bracket under Title 27 
36, section 5111, subsections 1-F, 2-F and 3 -F 1-G, 2 -G and 3 -G until the lower 28 
bracket reaches 4%. Funds available from the fund in su bsequent years must be 29 
applied to reduce the higher bracket rates until there is a single bracket with a rate of 30 
4%, after which future tax relief may be identified.  31

 35 If Maine taxable income is:  The tax is:  
Less than $21,050  5.8% of the Maine taxable income  
At least $21,050 but less than $50,000  $1,221 plus 6.75% of the excess over 
$21,050  
$50,000 or more  $3,175 plus 7.15% of the  excess over 
$50,000  
If Maine taxable income is:  The tax is:  
Less than $42,000  5.8% of the Maine taxable income  
At least $42,000 but less than $100,000  $2,436 plus 6.5% of the excess over 
$42,000  
$100,000 or more  $6,206 plus 6 .99% of the excess over 
$100,000  
If Maine taxable income is:  The tax is:

purposes and individual retirement account benefits reported as individual 39 
retirement account distributions for federal income tax purposes.  40

Sec. D -14.  36 MRSA §5218, as amended by PL 2015, c. 267, Pt. DD, §24 and 18 
affected by §34, is further amended to read:  19 
§5218.  Income tax credit for child care exp enses  20 
1.  Resident taxpayer.  A For tax years beginning before January 1, 2018, a  resident 21 
individual is allowed a credit against the tax otherwise due under this Part in the amount 22 
of 25% of the federal tax credit allowable for child and dependent care ex penses in the 23 
same tax year , except that for tax years beginning in 2003, 2004 and 2005, the applicable 24 
percentage is 21.5% instead of 25% . 25 
For tax years beginning on or after January 1, 2018, a resident individual is allowed a 26 
credit against the tax other wise due under this Part in the amount of 50% of the federal 27 
tax credit allowable for child and dependent care expenses in the same tax year.  28 
2.  Nonresident taxpayer.  A For tax years beginning before January 1, 2018, a  29 
nonresident individual is allowed a  credit against the tax otherwise due under this Part in 30 
the amount of 25% of the federal tax credit allowable for child and dependent care 31 
expenses multiplied by the ratio of the individual's Maine adjusted gross income, as 32 
defined in section 5102, subsec tion 1 -C, paragraph B, to the individual's entire federal 33 
adjusted gross income, as modified by section 5122 , except that for tax years beginning in 34 
2003, 2004 and 2005, the applicable percentage is 21.5% instead of 25% . 35 
For tax years beginning on or after  January 1, 2018, a nonresident individual is allowed a 36 
credit against the tax otherwise due under this Part in the amount of 50% of the federal 37 
tax credit allowable for child and dependent care expenses multiplied by the ratio of the 38 
individual's Maine ad justed gross income, as defined in section 5102, subsection 1 -C, 39 
paragraph B, to the individual's entire federal adjusted gross income, as modified by 40 
section 5122.  41

Fifty percent  of the just v alue of all the homestead exemptions under this subchapter must 4 
be included in the total municipal valuation used to determine the municipal tax rate.  For 5 
property tax years beginning on or after April 1, 2017, 62.5% of the just value of all the 6 
homestead  exemptions under this subchapter must be included in the total municipal 7 
valuation used to determine the municipal tax rate.   The municipal tax rate as finally 8 
determined may be applied to only the taxable portion of each homestead qualified for 9 
that tax year.  10 
Sec. G -3.  36 MRSA §685, sub -§2, as amended by PL 2015, c. 390, §§3 and 4, is 11 
further amended to read:  12 
2.  Entitlement to reimbursement by the State; calculation.   A municipality that 13 
has approved homestead exemptions under this subchapter may recove r from the State : 14 
50% of the taxes lost by reason of the exemptions under section 683, subsections 1 and 15 
1-B. 16 
A.  For property tax years beginning before April 1, 2017, 50% of the taxes lost by 17 
reason of the exemptions under section 683, subsections 1 and 1-B; and  18 
B.  For property tax years beginning on or after April 1, 2017, 62.5% of the taxes lost 19 
by reason of the exemptions under section 683, subsections 1 and 1 -B. 20 
The municipality must provide proof in a form satisfactory to the bureau.  The bureau 21 
shall reimburse the Unorganized Territory Education and Services Fund in the same 22 
manner for taxes lost by reason of the exemptions.  23 
Sec. G -4.  Retroactive application.  This Part applies retroactively to property 24 
tax valuations determined on or after April 1 , 2017.  25

subsection 4;  19

derive less than 30% of their total annual revenue on a calendar year basis from 26

purchase of goods or services or the rental of tangible personal property.  31 
"Retail sales activity" does not include production as defined in section 1752, 32 
subsection 9 -B; and  33

goods or services at retail or for renting tangible personal property.  "Retail 36 
sales facility" does not include a separate structure that is used as a 37

Sec. O -1.  5 MRSA §1725 -A, as amended by PL 1991, c. 780, Pt. Y, §51, is 2 
further amended to re ad: 3 
§1725 -A.  Risk management  4 
1.  Creation and authority.   The Department of Administrative and Financial 5 
Services is designated as the agency through which this chapter is administered.  The 6 
Director of the Bureau of General Services, in this chapter call ed the "director,"  State 7 
Controller  is empowered with such authority as necessary to carry out the purposes of this 8 
chapter.  9 
Risk management responsibilities are under the supervision and administrative control of 10 
the Director of the Bureau of General Serv ices State Controller . 11 
2.  State Controller.   The commissioner shall appoint  direct  the Director of the 12 
Bureau of General Services, in this chapter called the "director,"  State Controller  to 13 
administer the State's policy on insurance management, as develop ed through the 14 
authority of this chapter.  The director  State Controller  or the director's  State Controller's  15 
designee must be knowledgeable of insurance practices and principles and must be 16 
qualified by actual experience in the field of risk management to  carry out the purposes of 17 
this chapter.  18 
3.  Personnel.   The director  State Controller  may employ such assistants and 19 
employees as are necessary, and distribute the risk management duties among such 20 
persons as the director  State Controller  considers necess ary for economy and efficiency 21 
of administration. Employees are subject to the Civil Service Law.  22

read:  24 
§1727 -A.  Conflict of interest prohibited  25

financially interested, directly or indirectly, in any insurer, agency or insurance 27 
transaction, except as a policyholder or claimant under a policy, nor shall  may the 28 
director  State Controller  or any other employee be licensed under Title 24 -A, as an agent, 29 
broker, consultant or adjuster.  30

property and activities and other persons pursuant to this section, and to provide to 8 
the Commissioner of Administrative and Financial Services a statement of its 9 
activities during the year ending the preceding June 30th. This report must include:  10 
(1)  An evaluation of the state insurance program;  11 
(2)  A complete statement of all types and costs of insurance in effect;  12 
(3)  Names of agents and companies of record; a nd  13 
(4)  Such other matters as the director  State Controller  determines appropriate 14 
and necessary or as the commissioner may request;  15 
B.  To recommend to the Commissioner of Administrative and Financial Services 16 
such insurance protection as the director  State Controller  considers necessary or 17 
desirable for the protection of all state property or activities or other insureds under 18 
this section;  19 
C.  Pursuant to programs approved by the Commissioner of Administrative and 20 
Financial Services, to provide insuranc e protection for property and liability in 21 
accordance with the Maine Tort Claims Act, Title 14, section 8116, and premises 22 
liability, when required by a state lease or private property approved by the Attorney 23 
General, by self -insured retention or purchase  of insurance from companies or agents 24 
licensed to do business in this State, or by both, to effect the best possible contracts as 25 
to services, coverages and costs. The purchase of insurance under this section 26 
normally must be made upon competitive bidding , except that the director  State 27 
Controller  may, in appropriate circumstances, purchase insurance by negotiation;  28 
D.  To determine and review the values of property in which the State has an 29 
insurable or legal interest and recommend limits and types of ins urance protection for 30 
that property;  31 
E.  To establish and promote safety and other loss prevention programs;  32 
F.  To receive and, with the assistance of the Attorney General, administer all claims 33 
for personal injury and property damage against the State;  34 
G.  With the assistance of the Attorney General, to pursue all claims against 3rd 35 
parties in all cases in which the State may be subrogated to the rights of injured 36 
employees or where damage to state property may have resulted from the negligence 37 
of a 3rd p arty; 38 
H.  To administer the funds established by sections 1731 and 1737.  In performing the 39 
functions authorized by this chapter, the funds, the Commissioner of Administrative 40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 673 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  and Financial Services and the director  State Controller  are not subject to the 1 
provisions of Title 24 -A; and  2 
I.  On or before December 31, 1996 and every 3 years thereafter, to submit to the 3 
Commissioner of Administrative and Financial Services a report on the availability 4 
and affordability of insurance advice and services to those e ntities participating in the 5 
state-administered fund pursuant to section 1737 and to make specific 6 
recommendations for the removal from the state -administered fund of those entities 7 
that do not qualify.  8 
2.  Appraisal.   In case an agreement as to the amount  of loss sustained to any 9 
building or property insured under this chapter can not be arrived at between the insured 10 
entity and the director  State Controller , the loss must be referred to appraisal as provided 11 
by Title 24 -A, section 3002.  12 
3.  Rejection of risk.   In the event that the director  State Controller  determines that a 13 
risk may be prejudicial to the State's insurance program or to the state -administered fund 14 
established by section 1737 because of an actual or expected adverse loss ratio, the 15 
directo r State Controller  may refuse to include that risk in the program until the time that 16 
the hazards of the risk have been removed or ameliorated to a satisfactory degree.  17 
When coverage is declined by the director  State Controller , the department, agency or 18 
entity in charge of the risk may request that the director  State Controller  procure separate 19 
insurance from any authorized insurance company, and the premium for that separate 20 
insurance is a proper charge against the department, agency or entity responsible  for the 21 
property.  22 
4.  Forms and rules.   The director  State Controller  may prescribe forms of policies, 23 
proofs of loss and other forms and may adopt rules as are necessary or expedient for the 24 
proper administration of this chapter.  25 
5.  Actuarial review.   Once every 3 years, and more frequently if determined prudent 26 
by the Commissioner of Administrative and Financial Services, the director  State 27 
Controller  shall arrange for a review of the reserves of the state -administered fund by a 28 
qualified actuary who is  a member in good standing of the Casualty Actuarial Society.  29 
The actuary shall issue an opinion on the adequacy of reserves of the state -administered 30 
fund to cover the estimated ultimate liability of the state -administered fund.  Costs for 31 
this service m ust be paid from the Risk Management Fund.  32
