CHAPTER 21  29 
DEPARTMENT OF TECHNO LOGY SERVICES  30 
SUBCHAPTER 1  31 
GENERAL PROVISIONS  32 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 679 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §481.  Department established  1 
The Department of Technology Services is established as the primary department of 2 
State Government responsible for information technology.  The department is responsible 3 
for oversight and coordination of information technology policy, planning and service 4 
delivery and shall ensure consistency in programming services, stability in data 5 
processing functions and operational reliability of systems, while maintaining 6 
responsiveness and flexibility to react to changing situations and needs.  7 
The department is under the supervision and control of the commissioner, who is 8 
appointed by the Governo r and serves at the pleasure of the Governor.  The commissioner 9 
must have educational qualifications and professional experience directly related to the 10 
functions of and services provided by the department.  11 
§482.  Definitions  12 
As used in this chapter, unles s the context otherwise indicates, the following terms 13 
have the following meanings.  14 
1.  Commissioner.  "Commissioner" means the Commissioner of Technology 15 
Services, who shall serve as the State's Chief Information Officer.  16 
2.  Computer system.  "Computer s ystem" has the same meaning as in Title 17 -A, 17 
section 431.  18 
3.  Data processing.  "Data processing" means the process that encompasses all 19 
computerized and auxiliary automated information handling, including systems analysis 20 
and design, conversion of data, computer programming, information storage and retrieval, 21 
data and facsimile transmission, requisite system controls, simulation and all related 22 
interactions between people and machines.  "Data processing" also includes all word or 23 
text manipulation process ing. 24 
4.  Department.  "Department" means the Department of Technology Services.  25 
5.  Enterprise.  "Enterprise" means collectively all departments and agencies of the 26 
executive branch.  27 
6.  Telecommunications.  "Telecommunications" means, but is not limited t o, the 28 
process of transmitting and receiving any information, including voice, data and video, by 29 
any medium, including wire, microwave, fiberoptics, radio, laser and satellite.  30 
§483.  Powers and duties of the commissioner  31 
The commissioner serves as the pr incipal technology advisor to the Governor and is 32 
responsible for information technology leadership, planning and performance 33 
management.  The commissioner provides central leadership and vision in the use of 34 
technology across State Government.  35 
1.  Appoint  a deputy commissioner.  The commissioner may appoint and set the 36 
salary for a deputy commissioner to assist in carrying out the responsibilities of the 37 
department.  The deputy commissioner serves at the pleasure of the commissioner.  38 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 680 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  2.  Adopt rules.  The commissioner may adopt rules for carrying out the purposes of 1 
this chapter.  Rules adopted pursuant to this subsection are routine technical rules 2 
pursuant to chapter 375, subchapter 2 -A. 3 
3.  Information technology leadership.  The commissioner shall:  4 
A.  Set policies and standards for the implementation and use of information and 5 
telecommunications technologies, including privacy and security standards and 6 
standards of the federal Americans with Disabilities Act, for information technology;  7 
B.  Assist the Governor's Office with development and support of information 8 
technology -related legislation;  9 
C.  Identify and implement information technology best business practices;  10 
D.  Facilitate research and development activities to identify and establish effective 11 
information technology service delivery in State Government; and  12 
E.  Facilitate interjurisdictional collaboration, services, sharing and initiatives among 13 
departments, agencies, instrumentalities and political subdivisions of State 14 
Government and with othe r states and the Federal Government.  15 
4.  Information technology planning.  The commissioner shall:  16 
A.  Establish and manage a process for strategic information technology planning;  17 
B.  Ensure integration between the enterprise strategic plan and informatio n 18 
technology plans specific to the state departments;  19 
C.  Approve all state departments' information technology plans; and  20 
D.  Develop, implement and monitor compliance with statewide standards and 21 
information technology architecture.  22 
5.  Information techn ology financial management.  The commissioner shall 23 
develop an information technology financial management process to:  24 
A.  Protect current and future investments in information and telecommunications 25 
technologies in State Government;  26 
B.  Identify ways to u se information and telecommunications technologies to reduce 27 
cost of government and improve service to customers;  28 
C.  Analyze business process improvement options that will yield benefits to the 29 
State;  30 
D.  Establish performance and other outcomes measures and cost -benefit analyses for 31 
information technology;  32 
E.  Develop and administer a statewide information technology financial management 33 
and budget planning process;  34 
F.  Establish internal service funds accounts.  These accounts include, but are not 35 
limite d to, appropriations made to the accounts, funds transferred to the department 36 
and funds received for data processing and telecommunications planning services 37 
rendered to state departments and agencies;  38 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 681 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  G.  Levy appropriate charges against all state depart ments and agencies using 1 
services provided by the department and for the operations of the department.  The 2 
charges must be fixed in a schedule or schedules prepared and revised as necessary 3 
by the commissioner.  The schedule of charges must be supported a nd explained by 4 
accompanying information; and  5 
H.  Submit a budget of estimated revenues and costs to be incurred by the department 6 
as part of the unified current services budget legislation in accordance with sections 7 
1663 to 1666.  Notwithstanding section  1583, allocations may be increased or 8 
adjusted by the State Budget Officer, with approval of the Governor, to specifically 9 
cover those adjustments determined to be necessary by the commissioner.  A request 10 
for adjustment to the allocation is subject to re view by the joint standing committee 11 
of the Legislature having jurisdiction over appropriations and financial affairs.  12 
6.  Information technology procurement and contract management.  The 13 
following provisions govern information technology procurement and c ontract 14 
management.  15 
A.  The commissioner, or the commissioner's designee, shall work with the 16 
Department of Administrative and Financial Services to:  17 
(1)  Approve all major or nonstandard information and telecommunications 18 
technology initiatives, contracts  and acquisitions, including enterprise initiatives;  19 
(2)  Develop written standards for and approve the acquisition and use of all data 20 
processing and telecommunications services, equipment, software and systems by 21 
state departments and agencies;  22 
(3)  Appr ove the Department of Administrative and Financial Services, Division 23 
of Purchases' standards and evaluation procedures for standard information and 24 
telecommunications technology acquisitions and contracts; and  25 
(4)  Comply with all other state procurement policies.  26 
B.  The purchase of technology equipment, software or services may not be made 27 
except in accordance with this chapter.  A state department or agency may not 28 
purchase technology equipment, software or services without documented approval 29 
of the co mmissioner.  The Department of Administrative and Financial Services may 30 
not award contracts nor authorize payments for technology equipment, software or 31 
services without evidence of this prior approval.  32 
(1)  A state department or agency is in noncomplianc e with this chapter if the 33 
department or agency enters into agreements for technology equipment, software, 34 
or services without documented approval by the commissioner or fails to adhere 35 
to the standards and policies established in accordance with this chap ter. 36 
(2)  A state department or agency found to be in noncompliance as described in 37 
this paragraph is prohibited from further action related to acquiring or purchasing 38 
technology equipment, software or services until the commissioner determines 39 
that the de partment or agency is in compliance with this chapter.  40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 682 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  C.  Notwithstanding the provisions of this subsection, the commissioner may act to 1 
acquire or purchase technology equipment, software or services to maintain or meet 2 
the emergency needs of a state depa rtment or agency.  3 
D.  The commissioner shall provide information technology communications by 4 
serving as the lead advocate for information technology directions, policies, standards 5 
and plans for the executive branch and independent units of State Governme nt, 6 
constitutional offices, the media and the general public.  7 
7.  Maintain central telecommunications services.  The commissioner shall 8 
maintain and operate central telecommunications services and may:  9 
A.  Employ or engage outside technical and professiona l services that may be 10 
necessary for telecommunications purposes;  11 
B.  Levy charges, according to a rate schedule based on uniform billing procedures 12 
against all units utilizing telecommunications services; and  13 
C.  Require state departments and agencies to be a part of the central 14 
telecommunications service network.  Capital items purchased through the 15 
department may not be given, transferred, sold or otherwise conveyed to any other 16 
department, agency or account without authorization through the normal budge tary 17 
process.  Except as authorized by the commissioner, telecommunications services, 18 
equipment and systems are the responsibility and property of the department.  19 
8.  Provide services.  The department shall direct, coordinate and oversee the 20 
provision of i nformation technology services throughout State Government.  21 
9.  Maintain central data processing services.  The commissioner shall maintain 22 
and operate central data processing and geographic information systems pursuant to 23 
subchapter 2.  24 
10.  InforME respon sibilities.  The commissioner shall serve as the contracting 25 
authority under Title 1, chapter 14 and shall provide staff to the InforME Board 26 
established in Title 1, chapter 14.  27 
11.  Intergovernmental cooperation and assistance.  The commissioner may enter  28 
into agreements with the Federal Government, the University of Maine System, the 29 
Maine Community College System and other agencies and organizations that will 30 
promote the objectives of this chapter.  31 
§484.  Information security and technology risk manageme nt 32 
1.  Protection of information files.  The commissioner shall coordinate and oversee 33 
the storage, accessibility and recovery of information files.  The contents of all data files 34 
are the property of the state department or agency responsible for their co llection and use.  35 
2.  Confidentiality.  Computer programs, technical data, logic diagrams and source 36 
code related to data processing or telecommunications are confidential and are not public 37 
records, as defined in Title 1, section 402, subsection 3, to the  extent of the identified 38 
trade secrets.  To qualify for confidentiality under this subsection, computer programs, 39 
technical data, logic diagrams and source code must:  40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 683 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  A.  Contain trade secrets, as defined in Title 10, section 1542, subsection 4, held in 1 
private ownership; and  2 
B.  Have been provided to a state department or agency by an authorized independent 3 
vendor or contractor under an agreement by which:  4 
(1)  All trade secrets that can be protected are identified without disclosing the 5 
trade secret;  6 
(2)  The vendor or contractor retains all intellectual property rights in those trade 7 
secrets; and  8 
(3)  The state department or agency agrees to hold and use the programs, data, 9 
diagrams or source code without disclosing any identified trade secrets.  10 
3.  Publ ic records.  Except as provided in subsection 2, any document created or 11 
stored on a State Government computer must be made available in accordance with Title 12 
1, chapter 13.  13 
4.  Response to requests for public records.  Each state department or agency that  14 
collects and uses data or information is responsible for responding to requests for public 15 
data or information hosted on state -owned computer devices and equipment.  The 16 
department shall assist the state department or agency in searching for and identifyi ng all 17 
stored data and information and in compiling the data and information.  18 
SUBCHAPTER 2  19 
GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATI ON SYSTEMS  20 
§491.  Office of Geographic Information Systems established  21 
1.  Office established.  The Office of Geographic Information Systems is e stablished 22 
within the Department of Technology Services.  23 
2.  Powers and duties.  The Office of Geographic Information Systems shall:  24 
A.  Establish, maintain and operate a geographic database information center, 25 
develop and administer standards, subject to the approval of the commissioner, and 26 
provide geographic information system services to the public.  A request to provide 27 
the Legislature or an office of the Legislature with existing information for the 28 
purposes of making policy decisions must be consider ed high priority;  29 
B.  Create a GIS data repository for the proper management of GIS data and ensure 30 
the GIS data are documented, including ownership.  Data must be stored and 31 
managed in a manner that facilitates the evolution of a distributed agency GIS 32 
network;  33 
C.  Maintain GIS base map data and other multipurpose data not specific to any state 34 
department or agency.  All other GIS data are owned by the department or agency 35 
originally compiling the mapped data that were digitized for the GIS.  Data owners 36 
are responsible for updating their GIS data and certifying its accuracy;  37 
D.  Ensure that GIS data added on the GIS data repository are developed and 38 
maintained at an accuracy level and in a format that meets the GIS data standards, 39 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 684 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  kept in a format that is compatible with the GIS and, upon request of a potential user, 1 
made available to the user;  2 
E.  Levy appropriate charges on those using the services provided by the Office of 3 
Geographic Information Systems, except that charges may not be levied on the 4 
Legis lature for existing information.  The charges must be fixed in a schedule or 5 
schedules.  The schedule of charges must be supported and explained by 6 
accompanying information and approved by the commissioner; and  7 
F.  Consult with the commissioner on all majo r policy issues, including fee schedules, 8 
related to the management of GIS data and development of GIS data standards.  9 
3.  Cooperation and assistance.  The administrator may enter into such agreements 10 
with other agencies and organizations as will promote t he objectives of this subchapter 11 
and accept funds from public and private organizations to be expended for purposes 12 
consistent with this subchapter.  13 
4.  Licensing agreements.  GIS data are subject to licensing agreements and may be 14 
made available only in a ccordance with this subchapter and upon payment of fees 15 
established under this subchapter.  A licensing agreement must protect the security and 16 
integrity of the GIS data, limit the liability of the data owners and the Office of 17 
Geographic Information Syste ms in providing the services and products and identify the 18 
source of the GIS data.  19 
§492.  Definitions  20 
As used in this subchapter, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following 21 
terms have the following meanings.  22 
1.  Administrator.  "Administrator" m eans the Administrator of the Office of 23 
Geographic Information Systems.  24 
2.  Geographic information system or GIS.  "Geographic information system" or 25 
"GIS" means an entire formula, pattern, compilation, program, device, method, technique, 26 
process, digital database or system that electronically records, stores, reproduces and 27 
manipulates by computer geographic information system data.  28 
3.  Geographic information system data or GIS data.  "Geographic information 29 
system data" or "GIS data" means geographic info rmation that has been compiled and 30 
digitized for use in geographic information systems by a state department or agency, 31 
either alone or in cooperation with other departments and agencies.  32 
4.  Geographic information system services or GIS services.  "Geogra phic 33 
information system services" or "GIS services" means the process of gathering, storing, 34 
maintaining and providing geographic information system data for geographic 35 
information systems.  "Geographic information system services" or "GIS services" does 36 
not include general purpose data processing services.  37 
§493.  Priority of responsibilities  38 
The activities authorized under this subchapter do not take priority over the primary 39 
responsibilities of the Department of Technology Services.  If there are not suff icient 40 
financial or personnel resources for the Office of Geographic Information Systems to 41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 685 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  perform certain GIS services and deliver GIS data and products as provided in this 1 
subchapter, the administrative management functions related to the Office of Geog raphic 2 
Information Systems, technical support for other state department or agency GIS users, 3 
office equipment maintenance and GIS database management must take precedence.  4 
SUBCHAPTER 3  5 
MAINE LIBRARY OF GEO GRAPHIC INFORMATION ACT  6 
§501.  Short title  7 
This su bchapter may be known and cited as "the Maine Library of Geographic 8 
Information Act."  9 
§502.  Definitions  10 
As used in this subchapter, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following 11 
terms have the following meanings.  12 
1.  Association.  "Association" me ans an organization:  13 
A.  Whose membership is identifiable by regular payment of organizational dues and 14 
regularly maintained membership lists;  15 
B.  That is registered with the State or is a corporation in the State; and  16 
C.  That exists for the purpose of ad vancing the common occupation or profession of 17 
its membership.  18 
2.  Data custodian.  "Data custodian" means a federal data custodian, state data 19 
custodian or nonstate data custodian.  20 
3.  Federal data custodian.  "Federal data custodian" means any branch, ag ency or 21 
instrumentality of the Federal Government.  22 
4.  Geographic information board.  "Geographic information board" means the 23 
Maine Library of Geographic Information Board established in section 503.  24 
5.  Geographic information system.  "Geographic informa tion system" or "GIS" 25 
means a computer system capable of assembling, storing, manipulating, analyzing and 26 
displaying information identified according to locations.  A GIS includes operating 27 
personnel, hardware, software and the data that go into the system . 28 
6.  Maine Library of Geographic Information.  "Maine Library of Geographic 29 
Information" or "library" means the statewide network created pursuant to this subchapter 30 
by which data custodians, or their designees, organize and catalog public geographic 31 
information and provide access to that information to all levels of government and to the 32 
public.  33 
7.  Nonstate data custodian.  "Nonstate data custodian" means any agency or 34 
instrumentality of a political subdivision of the State.  35 
8.  Public geographic informa tion.  "Public geographic information" means public 36 
information that is referenced to a physical location.  Public geographic information 37 
includes, but is not limited to, physical, legal, economic or environmental information or 38 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 686 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  characteristics concerning land, water, groundwater, subsurface resources or air in this 1 
State relating to:  2 
A.  Topography, soil, soil erosion, geology, minerals, vegetation, land cover, wildlife 3 
and associated natural resources;  4 
B.  Land ownership, land use, land use controls and r estrictions, jurisdictional 5 
boundaries, tax assessments, land value and land survey records and references; and  6 
C.  Geodetic control networks, aerial photographs, maps, planimetric data, remote 7 
sensing data, historic and prehistoric sites and economic proj ections.  8 
9.  Public information.  "Public information" means information that is stored, 9 
gathered, generated, maintained or financed by a data custodian.  Information of state and 10 
nonstate data custodians is public information only if it is either:  11 
A.  A public record under Title 1, section 402, subsection 3; or  12 
B.  Otherwise expressly authorized by law to be released.  The presence of data in the 13 
library does not, by itself, make that information a public record.  14 
10.  State data custodian.  "State data cu stodian" means any branch, agency or 15 
instrumentality of State Government.  16 
11.  State funds.  "State funds" means bond revenues and General Fund money 17 
appropriated by the Legislature for the purposes of this subchapter.  18 
§503.  Maine Library of Geographic In formation Board  19 
1.  Purposes and duties.   The Maine Library of Geographic Information Board, as 20 
established by section 12004 -G, subsection 30 -B, has the following purposes and duties:  21 
A.  To oversee the Maine Library of Geographic Information to ensure tha t it 22 
operates as a coordinated, cost -effective electronic gateway providing public access 23 
to data custodians' public geographic information.  Nothing in this paragraph may be 24 
construed to affect the rights of persons to inspect or copy public records under  Title 25 
1, chapter 13, subchapter 1 or the duty of data custodians to provide for public 26 
inspection and copying of those records;  27 
B.  To establish and maintain standards, rules and policies for nonstate data 28 
custodians' geographic information that is incorp orated into the Maine Library of 29 
Geographic Information.  These standards, rules and policies must be consistent with 30 
the standards, rules and policies set by the commissioner that govern state data 31 
custodians' information technology.  The geographic infor mation board shall adopt 32 
rules to carry out this subchapter.  Rules adopted pursuant to this paragraph are 33 
routine technical rules as defined in chapter 375, subchapter 2 -A.  Standards and 34 
policies may concern, without limitation:  35 
(1)  Methods of access an d delivery of information held by the library;  36 
(2)  Geographic information system technical specifications;  37 
(3)  Data content, metadata and security, including guideline criteria for 38 
accepting 3rd -party data from data custodians or data volunteered by the private 39 
sector;  40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 687 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  (4)  Privacy and privacy protection;  1 
(5)  Mechanisms to correct inaccuracies; and  2 
(6)  Data validation tools and processes;  3 
C.  To reduce redundancies in the creation, verification and maintenance of public 4 
geographic information and to enh ance its utility for complex analyses;  5 
(1)  Each state data custodian, or its designee, that acquires, purchases, verifies, 6 
maintains or produces geographic information with state funds or grants shall:  7 
(a)  Inform the geographic information board and the Office of Geographic 8 
Information Systems as established in subchapter 2 of the existence of this 9 
information and its geographic extent; and  10 
(b)  Upon request, provide to the library and office an electronic copy of all 11 
information classified as public, in a form compatible with standards set by 12 
the commissioner.  13 
(2)  Each nonstate data custodian, or its designee, that acquires, purchases, 14 
verifies, maintains or produces geographic information with state funds 15 
specifically provided for that purpose shall:  16 
(a)  Inform the geographic information board and the Office of Geographic 17 
Information Systems of the existence of this information and its geographic 18 
extent; and  19 
(b)  Upon request, provide to the library and the Office of Geographic 20 
Information Systems an el ectronic copy of all information classified as 21 
public, in a form compatible with standards set by the commissioner;  22 
D.  To set priorities and authorize the expenditure of state funds, including awarding 23 
of grants or subgrants to data custodians when availa ble.  The geographic information 24 
board may seek federal and other funding partners, accept gifts and grants and 25 
expend the funds acquired for purposes consistent with this subchapter;  26 
E.  To promote innovative uses of geographic information through the pro vision of 27 
verified, coordinated, intergovernmental information via the Maine Library of 28 
Geographic Information. The geographic information board shall seek advice from 29 
the general public, professional associations, academic groups and institutions and 30 
individuals with knowledge of and interest in geographic information regarding 31 
needed information and potential innovative uses of geographic information;  32 
F.  To enter into partnerships to promote the purposes of this subchapter;  33 
G.  To hear and resolve disput es that may arise between data custodians or with 34 
respect to information to be placed in the Maine Library of Geographic Information, 35 
enforcement of geographic information board standards, rules or policies or other 36 
related matters, all in accordance with the Maine Administrative Procedure Act.  37 
Complainants may directly present their case to the geographic information board, 38 
which has the power to hold investigations, inquiries and hearings concerning matters 39 
brought to its attention and to make decisions with respect to the case.  All interested 40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 688 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  parties must be given reasonable notice of the hearing and an opportunity to be heard.  1 
Hearings must be open to the public;  2 
H.  To conduct studies relating to the coordination, development and use of statewide 3 
geographic information;  4 
I.  To report annually by January 1st to the joint standing committees of the 5 
Legislature having jurisdiction over natural resources matters and state and local 6 
government matters.  The report must provide a review of the past year's a ctivities, 7 
including, but not limited to, a description of standards adopted, data added to the 8 
library, partnerships established, disputes addressed, studies conducted and financial 9 
activity.  The library shall also make this report available to the publi c.  This report 10 
may also include suggested legislative language intended to address geographic 11 
information issues needing legislative action; and  12 
J.  To develop appropriate internal services to facilitate generalized access for and use 13 
of data by governmen tal agencies and the public.  The library may not compete 14 
directly with private enterprise.  The library shall work in partnership with nonstate 15 
data custodians to promote the purposes of this subchapter.  16 
2.  Membership.  The geographic information board c onsists of 14 voting members 17 
as follows:  18 
A.  The commissioner, or the commissioner's designee;  19 
B.  Two members who are responsible for overseeing GIS functions of a state 20 
department that is a data custodian of geographic information, appointed by the 21 
Gover nor; 22 
C.  Eight representatives as follows:  23 
(1)  A representative of the University of Maine System, appointed by the 24 
Chancellor of the University of Maine System;  25 
(2)  Two representatives of a statewide association of municipalities, one 26 
representative app ointed by the President of the Senate from nominations made 27 
by the association's governing body and one representative appointed by the 28 
Speaker of the House from nominations made by the association's governing 29 
body;  30 
(3)  One representative of a statewide a ssociation of regional councils, appointed 31 
by the Speaker of the House from nominations made by the Department of 32 
Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry;  33 
(4)  One representative of a statewide association of counties, appointed by the 34 
Governor from nominat ions made by the association's governing body;  35 
(5)  One representative of a statewide association representing real estate and 36 
development interests, appointed by the President of the Senate;  37 
(6)  One representative of a statewide association representing environmental 38 
interests, appointed by the Speaker of the House; and  39 
(7)  One member representing public utilities, appointed by the Governor;  40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 689 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  D.  Two members of the private sector representing geographic information vendors, 1 
one member appointed by the Pre sident of the Senate and one member appointed by 2 
the Speaker of the House; and  3 
E.  One public member, appointed by the President of the Senate.  4 
The terms for the members appointed pursuant to paragraphs B, C, D and E are 3 years.  5 
A member who designates a nother person to serve on the geographic information board 6 
as that member's designee shall provide written notice to the geographic information 7 
board's staff of the name and title of the designee.  8 
3.  Board chair.  The geographic information board shall an nually elect a chair from 9 
its membership at the first meeting in each year.  10 
4.  Staff.  Staff support to the geographic information board is provided by the 11 
department.  12 
5.  Quorum; action.  Eight members of the geographic information board constitute 13 
a quo rum.  The affirmative vote of 7 members is necessary for any action taken by the 14 
geographic information board.  A vacancy in the membership of the geographic 15 
information board does not impair the right of a quorum to exercise all the powers and 16 
perform the  duties of the geographic information board.  The geographic information 17 
board may use video conferencing and other technologies to conduct its business but is 18 
not exempt from Title 1, chapter 13, subchapter 1.  19 
6.  Meetings.  The geographic information boa rd shall meet at the call of the chair 20 
but not less than quarterly.  Notice must be provided no less than 5 working days prior to 21 
the meeting.  Notice may be in writing by facsimile or electronic transmission.  22 
7.  Memorandum of understanding.  Information to be provided by a nonstate data 23 
custodian, or its designee, to the Maine Library of Geographic Information is governed 24 
by a memorandum of understanding between the geographic information board, or its 25 
designee, and the nonstate data custodian, or its des ignee.  26 
8.  Data custodian responsibilities.  Federal and nonstate data custodians may 27 
voluntarily contribute data to the Maine Library of Geographic Information, except that 28 
data developed with state funds must be submitted to the library.  Data custodians , or 29 
their designees, are responsible for:  30 
A.  Ensuring that the public information is accurate, complete and current through the 31 
creation of adequate procedures;  32 
B.  Updating source databases following verification of suggested corrections that 33 
users subm it in accordance with geographic information board standards;  34 
C.  Complying with standards adopted by the geographic information board; and  35 
D.  Providing reasonable safeguards to protect confidentiality.  36 
§504.  Liability  37 
The geographic information board an d any of the parties submitting data to the Maine 38 
Library of Geographic Information for public use may not be held liable for any use of 39 
those data.  40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 690 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §505.  Copyrights and fees  1 
Copyright or licensing restrictions may not be fixed by the geographic informati on 2 
board or data custodians to the information made available through the Maine Library of 3 
Geographic Information.  The geographic information board may set fees for electronic 4 
copies of library data that are no more than 3 times the actual cost of reprodu ction.  Fee 5 
schedules must be set annually and made readily available to requestors.  6 
§506.  Geospatial data accounts  7 
1.  Accounts established.  There are established within the department separate 8 
accounts, referred to in this section as "the accounts," to  be administered by the 9 
geographic information board.  10 
2.  Sources of funding.  The following must be paid into the accounts:  11 
A.  All money appropriated for inclusion in the accounts;  12 
B.  All interest earned from investments of the accounts;  13 
C.  Any money a llocated from Other Special Revenue Funds accounts for the purpose 14 
of the accounts;  15 
D.  Proceeds from any bonds issued for the purpose of the accounts; and  16 
E.  Matching funds received from the Federal Government or other legal entity for 17 
geospatial data ac quisition expenditures made from the accounts pursuant to 18 
subsection 4.  19 
3.  Use of accounts.  The purpose of the accounts is to continue projects developed 20 
by the geographic information board.  The accounts must be used to provide and maintain 21 
to the exten t practicable statewide GIS data sets necessary for the efficient delivery of 22 
state services and to conserve state expenditures through partnerships with other GIS 23 
stakeholders interested in acquiring the same data sets.  The accounts may be used at the 24 
discretion of the geographic information board for acquiring geospatial data primarily 25 
including but not limited to the following data sets:  26 
A.  An orthoimagery program.  Imagery collected through this program must be from 27 
all areas of the State and be 4 -band images that include the red, green, blue and near - 28 
infrared bands; and  29 
B.  An elevation data set.  A consistent statewide elevation data set must be collected 30 
using light detection and ranging technology or an equivalent method.  31 
4.  Matching funds.  State  funds used to purchase geospatial data must be matched 32 
by funding from other sources at at least a one -to-one ratio.  33 
5.  Annual report.  The commissioner shall submit a written report to the Governor 34 
and the Legislature on the accounts' balance and expend itures by January 15th of each 35 
year.  36 
SUBCHAPTER 4  37 
STATEWIDE RADIO AND NETWORK SYSTEM  38 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 691 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §511.  Statewide Radio and Network System Reserve Fund  1 
1.  Fund established.  The Statewide Radio and Network System Reserve Fund, 2 
referred to in this section as "the fund ," is established as an internal service fund in the 3 
department for the purposes of managing the fund and acquiring, expanding, upgrading 4 
and replacing a statewide radio and network system for use by state departments and 5 
agencies.  The department may char ge a fee to state departments and agencies using the 6 
statewide radio and network system in accordance with an established rate structure.  7 
Revenues derived from operations must be used to pay the costs of the lease -purchase to 8 
acquire a system and to expan d, upgrade and replace the system and to manage the fund.  9 
A.  The department shall work closely with all state departments and agencies to 10 
identify radio and network requirements for the statewide system to ensure that state 11 
department and agency program r equirements are met to the maximum extent 12 
possible. The department shall:  13 
(1)  Ensure that the annual costs of the lease or lease -purchase are paid in a 14 
timely manner and that the financial affairs of the fund are properly managed;  15 
(2)  Maintain records of  radio and network system requirements for all state 16 
departments and agencies using the system and make this information available 17 
to state departments and agencies;  18 
(3)  Require state departments and agencies to become part of the statewide radio 19 
and netw ork system when replacing their current systems or purchasing new 20 
systems;  21 
(4)  Acquire, expand, upgrade or replace the statewide radio and network system 22 
in accordance with an established replacement plan; and  23 
(5)  Transfer radio equipment and network inf rastructure into the fund from state 24 
departments and agencies using the system, purchase, lease, lease -purchase or 25 
enter into other financing agreements, in accordance with section 1587, for the 26 
acquisition, expansion, upgrade or replacement of the system or any of its 27 
components in accordance with paragraph B when it can be demonstrated that 28 
any such action or agreement provides a clear cost or program advantage to the 29 
State.  30 
B.  The commissioner, in conjunction with the state departments and agencies usin g 31 
the statewide radio and network system, operating as a board that may be referred to 32 
as "the Statewide Radio Network Board," shall establish the following:  33 
(1)  Standards for statewide radio and network system operations;  34 
(2)  Specifications for systems and components to be acquired by the State; and  35 
(3) Standards for the exemption or waiver of state departments and agencies from 36 
the requirements of this section.  37 
C.  The department shall establish, through the Department of Administrative and 38 
Financial Se rvices, Office of the State Controller, the Statewide Radio and Network 39 
System Reserve Fund account.  The funds deposited in the account may include, but 40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 692 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  are not limited to, appropriations made to the account, funds received from state 1 
departments and agen cies using the services provided by the department, earnings by 2 
the fund from the Treasurer of State's pool and proceeds from the sale of system 3 
assets under the administrative control of the fund by the state surplus property 4 
program in the Department of Administrative and Financial Services in accordance 5 
with paragraph B and other provisions of law.  6 
D.  The fund may levy charges according to a rate schedule recommended by the 7 
commissioner against all state departments and agencies using the services of th e 8 
statewide radio and network system.  9 
E.  Service charges for the statewide radio and network system must be calculated to 10 
provide for system acquisition costs, expansion costs, upgrade costs, necessary 11 
capital investment and fund management costs, replace ment costs and sufficient 12 
working capital for the fund.  13 
F.  Each state department or agency using the services of the statewide radio and 14 
network system must budget adequate funds to pay for costs described in paragraph 15

Sec. R -15.  T ransition provisions.  The following provisions govern the 15 
transition of the Department of Administrative and Financial Services, Office of 16 
Information Technology, referred to in this section as "the office," to the Department of 17 
Technology Services, refer red to in this section as "the department."  18 
1.  The department is the successor in every way to the powers, duties and functions 19 
of the office.  20 
2.  All existing rules, regulations, policies and procedures in effect, in operation or 21 
adopted in or by the off ice or any of its administrative units or officers are hereby 22 
declared in effect and continue in effect until rescinded, revised or amended by the 23 
department.  24 
3.  All existing contracts, agreements and compacts currently in effect in the office 25 
continue in  effect.  26 
4.  Any positions authorized and allocated subject to the personnel laws to the office 27 
are transferred to the department and may continue to be authorized.  28 
5.  All records, property and equipment previously belonging to or allocated for the 29 
use of  the office become, on the effective date of this Act, part of the property of the 30 
department.  31 
6.  All existing forms, licenses, letterheads and similar items bearing the name of or 32 
referring to the office may be used by the department until existing suppl ies of those 33 
items are exhausted.  34

Beginning July 1, 2015, the counties shall annually collect no less than $62,172,371 from 16 
municipalities for the provision of correctional services in accordance with this 17 
subsection.  The counties may collect an amount that is more than the base assessment 18

exceed the base assessment limit as adjusted by the growth limitation factor established in 20 
section 706 -A, subsection 3 or 3%, whichever is less. For the purposes of this subsection, 21 
"correctional services" includes management services, personal services, contractual 22 
services, commodity purchases, capital expenditures and all other costs, or portions 23 
thereof, necessary to maintain and operate correctional services. "Correctional services" 24 
does not include county jail debt unless there is a surplus in the account that pays for 25 
correctional services at the end of the state fiscal year.  26 
The assessment to municipalities within each county may not be greater or less than the 27 
base assessment limit, which is:  28 
A.  A sum of $4,287,340 in Androscoggin County;  29 
B.  A sum of $2,316,666 in Aroostook County;  30

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 697 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §9203.  Broadband Development Authority  1 
1.  Establishment; membership.   The ConnectME  Broadband Develo pment  2 
Authority is established to further the goals and policies in section 9202 -A.  The authority 3 
is created as a body corporate and politic and a public instrumentality of the State.  The 4 
exercise by the authority of powers conferred by this chapter is c onsidered to be the 5 
performance of essential governmental functions. The authority consists of the following 6 
7 voting members:  7 
A.  The chair of the Public Utilities Commission or the chair's designee;  8 
B.  The Chief Information Officer of the State or the o fficer's designee;  9 
C.  One representative of consumers, appointed by the Governor;  10 
D.  Two members with significant knowledge of communications technology, 11 
appointed by the Governor;  12 
E.  The Commissioner of Economic and Community Development or the 13 
commis sioner's designee; and  14 
F.  One member with significant knowledge of telemedicine as defined in Title 24 -A, 15 
section 4316, subsection 1, appointed by the Governor.  16 
Compensation of members is as provided in Title 5, section 12004 -G, subsection 33 -F. 17 
2.  Terms ; chair; vacancies.   All members are appointed for 3 -year terms.  The 18 
Governor shall appoint a chair from among the 4 members appointed by the Governor. In 19 
the event of a vacancy in the membership, the Governor shall appoint a replacement 20 
member for the re mainder of that vacated term. Each member of the authority serves until 21 
that member's successor is appointed and qualified. Any member of the authority is 22 
eligible for reappointment.  23 
3.  Officers; quorum.   The authority may elect a secretary and a treasure r, who may, 24 
but need not, be members of the authority. Four members of the authority constitute a 25 
quorum, and the affirmative vote of 4 members is necessary for any action taken by the 26 
authority.  27 
4.  Participation by members.   A member may participate in a  meeting of the 28 
authority and place a vote electronically or telephonically as long as members of the 29 
public have an opportunity to listen to the deliberations of the authority and otherwise 30 
participate in or observe the proceedings of the authority consis tent with Title 1, section 31 
405. 32 
5.  Indemnification.   Each member of the authority must be indemnified by the 33 
authority against expenses actually and necessarily incurred by the member in connection 34 
with the defense of any action or proceeding in which the  member is made a party by 35 
reason of being or having been a member of the authority and against any final judgment 36 
rendered against the member in that action or proceeding.  37 
Sec. W -7.  35-A MRSA §9203 -A is enacted to read:  38 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 698 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §9203 -A.  Office established  1 
1.  Office of Broadband Development.   The Office of Broadband Development is 2 
established within the Department of Economic and Community Development.  The 3 
Director of the Office of Broadband Development shall administer the office in 4 
accordance with the policie s of the Commissioner of Economic and Community 5 
Development and the provisions of this chapter, emphasizing a program that seeks to 6 
encourage, foster, develop and improve broadband within the State in order to:  7 
A.  Expand and improve information and broadb and service that leads to job creation, 8 
an innovative economy and increased market opportunities for businesses in the 9 
State;  10 
B.  Serve the ongoing and growing needs of the State's education systems, health care 11 
system, public safety system, industries and  businesses, governmental operations and 12 
citizens; and  13 
C.  Improve accessibility for unserved and underserved communities and populations.  14 
2.  Organization.   The office consists of the Director of the Office of Broadband 15 
Development, as well as any staff n ecessary to carry out the office's duties under 16 
subsection 3. The director shall report to the Commissioner of Economic and Community 17 
Development in the execution of the director's responsibilities and to the authority in the 18 
execution of the State's broad band policy established in section 9202 -A. 19 
3.  Duties.   The office shall serve as the central broadband planning body for the 20 
State and shall support the authority in its duties under section 9204 -A. 21 
4.  Administer funds.   The office shall administer the B roadband Development Fund 22 
as established pursuant to section 9211, the Municipal Gigabit Broadband Network 23 
Access Fund as established pursuant to section 9211 -A and any state or federal funding to 24 
support the programs of the office.  25 
Sec. W -8.  35-A MRSA §9 204-A, sub -§§3, 5 and 7, as enacted by PL 2015, c. 26 
284, §7, are amended to read:  27 
3.  Support local and regional broadband planning.   The authority shall provide 28 
technical and  approve  financial assistance from the Broadband Development Fund as 29 
established p ursuant to section 9211  to communities in the State that include unserved 30 
and underserved areas to  identify the need for broadband infrastructure and services and 31 
develop and implement plans to meet those needs.  32 
5.  Facilitate state support of deployment o f broadband infrastructure.  The 33 
authority shall review, recommend and facilitate changes in laws, rules, programs and 34 
policies of the State and its agencies to further deployment of broadband infrastructure to 35 
all unserved and underserved areas of the Sta te.  The authority shall assist in identifying 36 
opportunities to use broadband infrastructure to achieve the state policies and goals as set 37 
out in section 9202 -A and support coordination between communications providers and, 38 
state departments  and local gov ernmental entities , including coordination with the 39 
statewide emergency radio network  on broadband infrastructure initiatives . 40 
7.  Administer funds.  The authority shall administer  approve expenditures in  the 41 
ConnectME  Broadband Development  Fund as establi shed pursuant to section 9211.  42

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  Sec. W -9.  35-A MRSA §9205, sub -§19, as enacted by PL 2005, c. 665, §3, is 1 
repealed.  2 
Sec. W -10.  35-A MRSA §9207, as enacted by PL 2005, c. 665, §3, is amended to 3 
read:  4 
§9207.  Collection of data  5 
Subject to the provisions in  this section, the office and the  authority may collect data 6 
from communications service providers and any wireless provider that own or operate 7 
advanced communications technology infrastructure in the State concerning infrastructure 8 
deployment and costs, revenues and subscribership.  9 
1.  Confidential information.   If the office and the  authority, on its their own or 10 
upon request of any person or entity, determines  determine  that public access to specific 11 
information about communications service providers in  the State could compromise the 12 
security of public utility systems to the detriment of the public interest or that specific 13 
information is of a competitive or proprietary nature, the authority shall issue an order 14 
designating that information as confidenti al. Information that may be designated as 15 
confidential pursuant to this subsection includes, but is not limited to, network diagrams.  16 
The authority may designate information as confidential under this subsection only to the 17 
minimum extent necessary to pro tect the public interest or the legitimate competitive or 18 
proprietary interests of a communications service provider.  The authority shall adopt 19 
rules pursuant to section 9205, subsection 3 defining the criteria it will use to satisfy the 20 
requirements of t his paragraph and the types of information that would satisfy the criteria.  21 
The authority may not designate any information as confidential under this subsection 22 
until those rules are finally adopted.  23 
Information designated as confidential under this subs ection is not a public record under 24 
Title 1, section 402, subsection 3.  25 
2.  Protection of information.   A communications service provider may request that 26 
confidential or proprietary information provided to the office and the  authority under 27 
subsection 1 n ot be viewed by those members of the office or the  authority who could 28 
gain a competitive advantage from viewing the information.  Upon such a request, the 29 
authority shall ensure that the information provided is viewed only by those members of 30 
the authorit y and staff who do not stand to gain a competitive advantage and that there are 31 
adequate safeguards to protect that information from members of the authority who could 32 
gain a competitive advantage from viewing the information.  33 
Sec. W -11.  35-A MRSA §9208, as amended by PL 2015, c. 284, §9, is further 34 
amended to read:  35

shall provide a report to the Governor and the  joint s tanding committee of the Legislature 38 
having jurisdiction over utilities matters that:  39 
1.  Budget.   Includes a report on the budget of the authority  office ; 40

 Page 700 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  2.  Activities.   Documents the activities of the office and the  authority, including a 1 
detailed desc ription of the progress toward the goals and objectives established in the 2 
triennial strategic plan under section 9218;  3 
3.  Investments.   Contains a listing of any investments of money in the ConnectME  4 
Broadband Development  Fund, as established pursuant to  section 9211, and a tracking of 5

of the competitive market in the State for communications services and advanced 9 
communications technology infrastructure and whether the communications services 10 
provided in the State are reasonably comparable to services provided regionally a nd 11 
nationwide.  12

the office and the  authority.  15 
Sec. W -12.  35-A MRSA §9211, as enac ted by PL 2005, c. 665, §3, is amended to 16 
read:  17 
§9211.  Broadband Development Fund  18 
1.  Broadband Development Fund established.   The ConnectME  Broadband 19 
Development  Fund, referred to in this section as "the fund," is established as a nonlapsing 20 
fund in the  Department of Economic and Community Development  administered by the 21 
office in consultation with  the authority for the purposes of supporting the activities and 22 
projects of the authority under this chapter.  23 
2.  Assessment.   After receiving authorization p ursuant to Title 5, section 8072 to 24 
finally adopt major substantive rules under section 9205, subsection 3 or after January 15, 25 
2007, whichever is later, the office and the  authority may require every communications 26 
service provider to contribute on a comp etitively neutral basis to the fund.  The 27 
assessment may not exceed 0.25% of the revenue received or collected for all 28 
communications services provided in this State by the communications service provider.  29 
A facilities -based provider of wireless voice or data retail service may voluntarily agree 30 
to be assessed by the authority as a communications service provider under this 31 
subsection.  32 
3.  Explicit identification on customer bills.   A communications service provider 33 
assessed pursuant to subsection 2 may re cover the amount of the assessment from the 34 
provider's customers.  If a provider recovers the amount from its customers, it must 35 
explicitly identify the amount owed by a customer on the customer's bill and indicate that 36 
the funds are collected for use in t he ConnectME  Broadband Development  Fund.  37 
Sec. W -13.  35-A MRSA §9211 -A, as enacted by PL 2015, c. 323, §1, is 38 
amended to read:  39 
§9211 -A.  Municipal Gigabit Broadband Network Access Fund  40 
1.  Definitions.   As used in this section, unless the context otherwise  indicates, the 41 
following terms have the following meanings.  42 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 701 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  A.  "Applicant" means a community, regional partnership or municipality that applies 1 
for a grant under this section.  2 
B.  "Community" means a municipality with a population of at least 1,200 peopl e, as 3 
determined by the office and the  authority in accordance with the United States 4 
Census data, or a municipality that has received a waiver from this population 5 
requirement from the office and the  authority upon a determination that the 6 
municipality is  in an unserved or underserved area.  7 
C.  "Fund" means the Municipal Gigabit Broadband Network Access Fund 8 
established in this section.  9 
D.  "Regional partnership" means 2 or more municipalities that do not, on their own, 10 
meet the requirements of paragraph B  and have joined together with one or more 11 
contiguous municipalities in the region to achieve the population requirements of 12 
paragraph B.  13 
2.  Fund established.   The Municipal Gigabit Broadband Network Access Fund is 14 
established as a nonlapsing, revolving f und administered by the office in consultation 15 
with the  authority for the purposes of supporting the activities and projects of the 16 
authority under this section.  All money in the fund must be continuously applied by the 17 
authority to carry out this section .  The authority may receive and deposit in the fund 18 
funds from the following sources:  19 
A.  Federal funds and awards that may be used for the purposes of this section;  20 
B.  The proceeds of bonds issued for the purposes of this section; and  21 
C.  Any other fund s from public or private sources received in support of the 22 
purposes for which the fund is established.  23 
3.  Purpose of the fund.   The fund is established to address the need in the State for 24 
access to ultra high -speed broadband infrastructure that will enh ance the State's 25 
competitiveness in national and international economies.  To the extent funds are 26 
available, the fund must be used to provide grants to communities, regional partnerships 27 
and municipalities to support public -private partnerships to support  a municipal gigabit 28 
fiber -optic broadband network in their regions with the following goals:  29 
A.  Provide high -speed broadband access to attract, create and grow the State's 30 
economy and market the products and services of businesses in the State in nationa l 31 
and international markets with ultra high -speed symmetric connectivity and address 32 
challenges in geography;  33 
B.  Provide expanded health care services by facilitating access to telemedicine, as 34 
defined in Title 24 -A, section 4316, subsection 1, and state and local services for 35 
senior citizens and persons with disabilities;  36 
C.  Expand educational opportunities for students across the State through virtual and 37 
distance learning;  38 
D.  Facilitate broader access for the public to services provided by municipal a nd 39 
county governments, including, but not limited to, law enforcement entities, the 40 
judicial system and child, youth and family social services; and  41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 702 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  E.  Provide expanded residential services to support employment opportunities.  1 
In order to facilitate the a chievement of the goals and policies of this section, the 2 
authority shall establish and regularly update, after opportunity for public comment and 3 
taking into consideration relevant federal policies, definitions of "gigabit fiber -optic 4 
broadband network" a nd "ultra high -speed broadband infrastructure."  5 
4.  Implementation grants; maximum awards.   To the extent funds are available, 6 
the office in consultation with the  authority shall award implementation grants to achieve 7 
the purpose of the fund as described i n subsection 3 as follows.  8 
A.  An implementation grant to an applicant may not exceed $200,000 for each 9 
eligible project selected for funding.  10 
B.  An implementation grant may be awarded only to an applicant that has 11 
demonstrated to the satisfaction of the office and the  authority that it has participated 12 
in a planning grant process as described in subsections 5, 6 and 7.  13 
C.  Municipalities selected for funding must be required to provide a 25% cash 14 
match.  15 
5.  Planning grants; requirements for applicants.   In order to assist applicants with 16 
completion of the planning process necessary to achieve the goals of this section, to the 17 
extent funds are available, the authority shall award planning grants of up to $20,000 for 18 
community applicants and up to $25,000 fo r regional partnerships and municipalities, 19 
which require a cash match.  The office in consultation with the  authority shall establish 20 
application requirements for planning grants for community and regional applicants that 21 
require an applicant to demonstra te to the satisfaction of the authority participation with 22 
public and private institutions and local businesses in the development of the grant 23 
process.  Municipal applicants must provide the authority  office  with the following 24 
information:  25 
A.  A plan that  identifies how the municipality will use ultra high -speed broadband 26 
access to fulfill the economic goals of the municipality;  27 
B.  A written commitment to nondiscriminatory open access to the broadband 28 
infrastructure by all parties involved in the grant;  29 
C.  A written summary of public forums used to gather information from the public in 30 
establishing the goals for the grant that serve the goals of this section;  31 
D.  Information gathered from local public and private institutions that identifies how 32 
the broad band services will expand access to state and local services identified under 33 
subsection 3; and  34 
E.  A summary of input received from the business community to identify the 35 
services that will be used in planning the implementation grant application.  36 
6.  Planning grant requirements.   An applicant awarded a planning grant under 37 
subsection 5 must provide to the authority  office : 38 
A.  Identification of the local broadband needs and goals;  39 
B.  An inventory of existing broadband infrastructure assets within the mun icipality, 40 
municipalities or region;  41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 703 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  C.  The results of a gap analysis that defines the additional broadband infrastructure 1 
necessary to meet identified needs and goals;  2 
D.  One or more potential network designs, cost estimates, operating models and 3 
potent ial business models, based on input from broadband providers operating within 4 
the municipality, municipalities or region and any other parties that submit a network 5 
design solution, to address any broadband gaps identified in the analysis described in 6 
paragraph C; and  7 
E.  An assessment of all existing municipal procedures, policies, rules and ordinances 8 
that may have the effect of delaying or increasing the cost of broadband infrastructure 9 
deployment.  10 
7.  Cash match for planning grants; restrictions.   The c ash match required from 11 
the applicant for a planning grant under subsection 5 may consist of municipal 12 
appropriations, private funds, funding from economic development entities and funding 13 
from nonprofit entities.  The cash match for planning grants may no t consist of funds 14 
provided by a vendor or private business that proposes to build, operate or provide retail 15 
services using the gigabit fiber -optic broadband network.  16 
8.  Technical assistance; contract for services.   The authority  office  may provide 17 
techn ical assistance to applicants that request assistance with the grant application 18 
process.  The authority  office  may contract for services to assist in the administration, 19 
management and evaluation of the fund.  20 
9.  Rules; application procedure.   The authori ty shall adopt rules to implement this 21 
section, including rules governing the application process for the fund.  Rules adopted 22 
under this subsection are routine technical rules pursuant to Title 5, chapter 375, 23 
subchapter 2 -A. 24 
10.  Report.   Beginning Decem ber 15, 2016, the office in consultation with the  25 
authority shall provide an annual report to the joint standing committee of the Legislature 26 
having jurisdiction over energy and utility matters on the grants distributed from the fund 27 
and an analysis of the  fund's activities that have addressed the need for expansion of ultra 28 
high-speed broadband access in the State.  29

PART X  16 
Sec. X -1.  Attrition savings.  Notwithstanding any provision of law to the 17 
contrary, the attrition rate for the 2018 -2019 biennium is increased from 1.6% to 5% for 18 
judicial branch and executive branch departments and agencies only, with the exception 19 
of the District Attorneys Salaries program within the Department of the Attorney 20 
General. The attrition rate for subsequent biennia is 1.6% with the exception of the 21 
District Attorneys Salaries program within the Department of the Attorney General. The 22 
attrition rate for the District Attorneys Salaries program is 0% for the 2018 -2019 23 
biennium.  24 
Sec. X -2.  Calculation and transfer; attrition savings.  The State Budget 25 
Officer shall calculate the amount of the savings in section 3 of this Part that applies 26 
against each General Fund account for all executive branch departments and agencies 27 
statewide, with the exception of the District Attorneys Salaries program, and shall 28 
transfer the amounts by financial order upon the approval of the Governor. These 29 
transfers are considered adjustments to appropriations in fiscal years 2017 -18 and 2018 - 30 
19. The State Budget Officer shall submit to the Joint Standing Committee on 31 
Appropriations and Financial Affairs a report of the transferred amounts no later than 32 
September 1, 2018.  33 
Sec. X -3.  Appropriations and allocations.  The following appropriations and  34 
allocations are made.  35 
ADMINISTRATIVE AND FINANCIAL SERVICES, DEPARTMENT OF  36 
Executive Branch Departments and Independent Agencies - Statewide 0017  37 
Initiative:  Reduces funding to reflect projected savings from an increase in the attrition 38 
rate from 1.6% to  5% for fiscal years 2017 -18 and 2018 -19. 39

PART Y  5 
Sec. Y -1.  Department of Administrative and Financial Services; lease - 6 
purchase authorization.  Pursuant to the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 5, section 7 
1587, the Department of Administrative and Financial Services, in cooperation with the 8 
Treasurer of State, may enter into financing agreements in fiscal years 2017 -18 and 201 8- 9 
19 for the acquisition of motor vehicles for the Central Fleet Management Division. The 10 
financing agreements entered into in each fiscal year may not exceed $5,500,000 in 11 
principal costs, and a financing agreement may not exceed 4 years in duration. The 12 
interest rate may not exceed 5%. The annual principal and interest costs must be paid 13 
from the appropriate line category allocations in the Central Fleet Management Division 14 
account.  15

purchase authorization.  Pursuant to the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 5, section 18

in duration.  The interest rate may not exceed 5%.  The annual principal and interest costs 24

State Police accounts.  26

PART CC  3 
Sec. CC -1.  Voluntary employee incentive programs.  Notwithstanding the 4 
Maine Revised Statutes, Title 5, section 903, subsections 1 and 2, the Commissioner of 5 
Administrative and Financial Services shall offer for use prior to July 1, 2019 special 6 
voluntary employee incentive programs for state employees, in cluding a 50% workweek, 7 
flexible position staffing and time off without pay. Employee participation in a voluntary 8 
employee incentive program is subject to the approval of the employee's appointing 9 
authority.  10 
Sec. CC -2.  Continuation of group health insura nce.  Notwithstanding the 11 
Maine Revised Statutes, Title 5, section 285, subsection 7 and Title 5, section 903, the 12 
State shall continue to pay health and dental insurance benefits for a state employee who 13 
applies prior to July 1, 2019 and is approved to pa rticipate in a voluntary employee 14 
incentive program under section 1 of this Part based upon the scheduled workweek in 15 
effect prior to the employee's participation in the voluntary employee incentive program.  16 
Sec. CC -3.  Continuation of group life insurance .  Notwithstanding the Maine 17 
Revised Statutes, Title 5, sections 903 and 18056 and the rules of the Maine Public 18 
Employees Retirement System, the life, accidental death and dismemberment, 19 
supplemental and dependent insurance amounts for a state employee wh o applies prior to 20 
July 1, 2019 and is approved to participate in a voluntary employee incentive program 21 
under section 1 of this Part are based upon the scheduled hours of the employee prior to 22 
the employee's participation in the voluntary employee incenti ve program.  23 
Sec. CC -4.  General Fund savings.  Notwithstanding the Maine Revised 24 
Statutes, Title 5, section 1585, the State Budget Officer shall transfer the General Fund 25 
savings resulting from the voluntary employee incentive programs under section 1 of t his 26 
Part to the General Fund Compensation and Benefit Plan account in the Department of 27 
Administrative and Financial Services. The State Budget Officer shall submit to the joint 28 
standing committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction over appropriations and 29 
financial affairs a report of the transferred amounts no later than January 15, 2019 for 30 
fiscal year 2017 -18 and no later than January 15, 2020 for fiscal year 2018 -19. 31 
Sec. CC -5.  Lapsed balances.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law, 32 
$350,000 in fiscal year 2017 -18 and $350,000 in fiscal year 2018 -19 of savings identified 33 
from the voluntary employee incentive programs in this Part lapse to the General Fund.  34

PART RR  8 
Sec. RR -1.  10 MRSA c. 501, sub -c. 4-A is enacted to read:  9 
SUBCHAPTER 4 -A 10 
LOCAL SEALERS  11 
§2461.  Election by municipal officers  12 
The municipal officers of a municipality may elect or appoint a sealer of weights and 13 
measures, and a deputy sealer if necessary, not necessarily a resident of that municipality, 14 
and the sealer and deputy sealer hold office during their efficiency and the faithful 15 
performance of their duties.  On complaint being made to the municipal officers of the 16 
inefficiency or neglect of duty of a sealer or deputy sealer, the municipal officers shall set 17 
a date for and give notice of a hearing to the complainant, the relevant sealer and the state 18 
sealer. If evidence satisfies the municipal officers that the sealer or deputy sealer has been 19 
inefficient or has neglected the sealer's or deputy sealer's du ty, they may remove the 20 
sealer or deputy sealer from office and elect or appoint another in the sealer's or deputy 21 
sealer's stead. The state sealer has jurisdiction over a sealer or deputy sealer elected or 22 
appointed pursuant to this section, and any vacan cy caused by death or resignation must 23 
be filled by election or appointment by the municipal officers within 30 days. For each 24 
month that the municipal officers neglect their duty, they severally are subject to a fine of 25 
$10. Within 10 days after each such  election or appointment, the clerk of each 26 
municipality shall communicate the name of the person so elected or appointed to the 27 
state sealer and for neglect of this duty is subject to a fine of $10. A sealer of weights and 28 
measures in any municipality may  be sealer for several municipalities, if such is the 29 
pleasure of the municipal officers of those municipalities, as long as this action receives 30 
the approval of the state sealer.  31 
§2462.  Appointment by state sealer  32 
The municipal officers of a municipality  may request the state sealer to appoint a 33 
qualified person to serve as sealer of weights and measures in lieu of local appointment or 34 
election as provided for in section 2461. If the municipal officers fail to elect or appoint a 35 
sealer and make a return t o the state sealer of the election or appointment within 30 days 36 
after the election or appointment, the state sealer may appoint a qualified person to act as 37 
sealer of weights and measures. Any person appointed under this section may serve in 38 
that capacity  for more than one municipality.  39 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 715 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §2463.  Powers and duties  1 
A weights and measures official elected or appointed for a municipality has the duties 2 
enumerated in section 2402, subsections 2 to 9 and the powers enumerated in section 3 
2403. These powers and dut ies extend to the official's jurisdiction.  4 
§2464.  Records of weights and measures sealed; annual report  5 
A sealer shall keep records of all weights and measures, balances and measuring 6 
devices inspected, sealed or condemned by that sealer, giving the name of the owner or 7 
agent, the place of business, the date of inspection and kind of apparatus inspected, sealed 8 
or condemned. The sealer shall make an annual report on July 1st for the 12 preceding 9 
months on forms prescribed by the state sealer and shall furn ish such information as the 10 
state sealer may require.  11

Sec. SS -1.  12 MRSA §8901, sub -§1, ¶A, as enacted by PL 2015, c. 267, Pt. Z, 13 
§1, is amended to read:  14 
A.  The forest protection unit of the Bureau of Forestry shall employ no fewer than 45 15 
and no  more than 50 forest rangers classified as Forest Ranger II to serve as wildfire 16 
control specialists and forestry law enforcement officers, and no fewer than 17 16 17 
forest rangers classified as follows: 3 Regional Rangers, 8 District Rangers, one 18 
Forest Fir e Prevention Specialist, one Ranger Pilot Supervisor and  4  3 Ranger 19 
Pilots.  Each forest ranger must, at a minimum, be a graduate of the Maine Criminal 20 
Justice Academy's law enforcement preservice program or equivalent.  21 
PART TT  22 
Sec. TT -1.  33 MRSA §479 -C, as amended by PL 2011, c. 655, Pt. II, §7 and 23 
affected by §11 and amended by c. 657, Pt. W, §5, is further amended to read:  24 
§479 -C.  Conservation easement registry  25 
A holder of a conservation easement that is organized or doing business in the State 26 
shall  annually report to the Department of Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry the 27 
book and page number at the registry of deeds for each conservation easement that it 28 
holds, the municipality and approximate number of acres protected under each easement 29 
and such other information as the Department of Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry 30 
determines necessary to fulfill the purposes of this subchapter. The filing must be made 31 
by a date and on forms established by the Department of Agriculture, Conservation an d 32 
Forestry to avoid duplicative filings when possible and otherwise reduce administrative 33 
burdens.  The annual filing must be accompanied by a $30 fee of $80 .  The Department 34 
of Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry shall maintain a permanent record of th e 35 
registration and report to the Attorney General any failure of a holder disclosed by the 36 
filing or otherwise known to the Department of Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry. 37

Controller shall transfer $5,000,000 from the General Fund unappropriated surplus to the 5

account within the Department of Education no later than June 30, 2018.  7

for Efficient Delivery of E ducational Services, Other Special Revenue Funds 9

PART VVV  14 
Sec. VVV -1.  Lease -purchase authorization; Department of Education's 15 
learning through technology program.  Pursuant to the Main e Revised Statutes, 16 
Title 5, section 1587, the Department of Education may enter into financing agreements 17 
in fiscal years 2017 -18 and 2018 -19 for the acquisition of portable learning devices and 18 
support systems for students and educators to support the op erations of the Department of 19 
Education's learning through technology program. The financing agreements may not 20 
exceed 4 years in duration and $50,000,000 in principal costs for the Department of 21 
Education's learning through technology program. The interes t rate may not exceed 8%, 22 
and the total interest costs may not exceed $4,000,000. The annual principal and interest 23 
costs must be paid from the appropriate line category allocations in the Department of 24 
Education. The State is authorized to extend the prov isions of the lease -purchase 25 
agreement on behalf of school administrative units as long as all costs of the extension 26 
are borne by the school administrative units.  27

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  Sec. EEEE -2.  22 MRSA §3104, sub -§15 is enacted to read:  1 
15.  Denial of assistance based on felony drug offense.  An applicant for benefits 2 
under the food supplement program who has been convicted of a felony drug offense 3 
within the 5 years prior to applying to the program is ineligible for benefits under the 4 
food supplement program.  A recipient of benefits under the food supplement program 5 
who is convicted of a felony drug o ffense while receiving benefits is ineligible to receive 6 
benefits for 5 years following the date of the felony drug offense conviction.  As used in 7 
this subsection, "felony drug offense" means an offense that, at the time of conviction, is 8 
punishable by im prisonment for one year or more under any law of the United States or 9 
of any state and that has as an element the possession, use or distribution of a controlled 10 
substance as defined in Section 102(6) of the federal Controlled Substances Act, 21 11 
United Sta tes Code, Section 802(6) or a scheduled drug as defined in Title 17 -A, section 12 
1101, subsection 11. "Felony drug offense" does not include conviction of a crime under 13 
the laws of another state that is classified by laws of that state as a misdemeanor and i s 14 
punishable by a term of imprisonment of 2 years or less. This subsection applies to 15 
recipients of and applicants for food assistance.  16

repealed.  18 
Sec. EEEE -4.  22 MRSA §3762, sub -§17-A is enacted to read:  19 
17-A.  Denial of assistance based on felony drug offense.  An applicant for TANF 20 
benefits who has been convicted of a felony drug offense within the 5 years prior to 21 
applying for TANF benefits is ineligible for TANF benefits.  A re cipient of TANF 22 
benefits who is convicted of a felony drug offense while receiving TANF benefits is 23 
ineligible to receive TANF benefits for 5 years following the date of the felony drug 24 
offense conviction.  As used in this subsection, "felony drug offense"  means an offense 25 
that, at the time of conviction, is punishable by imprisonment for one year or more under 26 
any law of the United States or of any state and that has as an element the possession, use 27 
or distribution of a controlled substance as defined in Section 102(6) of the federal 28 
Controlled Substances Act, 21 United States Code, Section 802(6) or a scheduled drug as 29 
defined in Title 17 -A, section 1101, subsection 11. "Felony drug offense" does not 30 
include conviction of a crime under the laws of another  state that is classified by laws of 31 
that state as a misdemeanor and is punishable by a term of imprisonment of 2 years or 32 
less. This subsection applies to recipients of and applicants for TANF assistance.  33
