Sec. FFFF -5.  22 MRSA §3762, sub -§§21 and 22 are enacted to read:  15 
21.  Job readiness requirement.  Before TANF assistance may b e granted to an 16 
applicant by the department, the applicant must attend a job readiness and vocational 17 
evaluation and training program administered by the department or its designee.  18 
22.  Denial of assistance based on quitting or losing a job without good c ause.  19 
An applicant or recipient of TANF assistance must be denied TANF assistance as 20 
described in this subsection.  21 
A.  If an applicant or recipient of TANF has quit or has lost a job without good cause 22 
in the 30 days prior to application, during the appli cation -processing period or after 23 
application approval, the family will be ineligible for TANF for a period of 3 months. 24 
The ineligibility period includes the month employment ended and the next 2 months.  25 
B.  A penalty for quitting a job or losing a job is  applied when an individual:  26 
(1)  Voluntarily quits a job without good cause as defined by rule of the 27 
department;  28 
(2)  Leaves a job unannounced or does not return to work without good cause as 29 
defined by rule of the department; or  30 
(3)  Has been warned abo ut performance or behavior by the employer, continues 31 
the objectionable conduct after the warning and is subsequently terminated.  32 
C.  The penalty under paragraph A is not applied when:  33 
(1)  An individual has terminated a self -employment enterprise; or  34 
(2)  There is good cause as defined by rule of the department.  35 
D.  There is no cure for the penalty for quitting or losing a job.  Once the penalty 36 
period begins, it continues for the full 3 months, even if the individual obtains 37 
employment.  38

Sec. FFFF -12.  22 MRSA §3785 -B is enacted to read:  18 
§3785 -B.  Domestic violence exception from sanctions for failure to participate  19 
An individual may not be sanctioned under ASPIRE -TANF or Temporary Assistance 20 
for Needy Families for failur e to participate in the ASPIRE -TANF program if that 21 
individual is unable to participate because of physical injuries or the psychological effects 22 
of abuse; because of legal proceedings, counseling or other activities related to abuse; 23 
because the abuser ac tively interferes with the individual's participation; because the 24 
location puts the individual at risk; or for other good cause related to domestic violence.  25 
Good cause for failure to participate in ASPIRE -TANF must be found when there is 26 
reasonable and verifiable evidence of domestic violence.  For the purposes of this section, 27 
reasonable and verifiable evidence may include but is not limited to the following:  28 
1.  Records.  Court, medical, law enforcement, child protective, social services, 29 
psychological  or other records that establish that the individual has been a victim of 30 
domestic violence; or  31 
2.  Sworn statements.  Sworn statements from persons other than the individual with 32 
knowledge of the circumstances affecting the individual.  33 
Each individual par ticipating in an ASPIRE -TANF orientation must receive written 34 
and oral notice of what constitutes good cause for nonparticipation in ASPIRE -TANF.  35

 Page 735 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §3787 -A.  Fund for the Payment of Federal Fines Imposed for  Noncompliance with 1 
Federal Work Participation Requirements  2 
1.  Fund established.  The Fund for the Payment of Federal Fines Imposed for 3 
Noncompliance with Federal Work Participation Requirements, referred to in this section 4 
as "the fund," is established w ithin the department for the purpose of paying fines 5 
imposed on the State by the Federal Government due to the State's failure to comply with 6 
federal requirements related to the ASPIRE -TANF program.  7 
2.  Fund maintenance.  By January 31st annually, the comm issioner shall report to 8 
the joint standing committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction over health and human 9 
services matters any fines owed by the State to the Federal Government as a result of 10 
noncompliance with federal work participation requireme nts under the ASPIRE -TANF 11 
program. The committee, within 30 days of the commissioner's report, shall report out a 12 
bill that appropriates to the fund the amount necessary to pay any federal fines owed and 13 
may report out legislation related to the commission er's report.  14

3-A.  Comprehensive screening and assessmen t.  If upon an initial screening or at a 28 
later date it is determined that a participant has physical or mental health impairments, 29

c. 407, §1, is am ended to read:  7 
3.  Program requirements.   An enrollee must participate in a combination of 8 
education, training, study or work -site experience for an average of 20 hours per week  in 9 
a manner that meets federal work participation requirements  in the first 24 12 months of 10 
the program.  Aid under this chapter may continue beyond 24 12 months if the enrollee 11 
remains in an educational program and agrees to participate in either of the following 12 
options:  meets federal work participation requirements.  13 
A.  Fifteen h ours per week of work -site experience in addition to other education, 14 
training or study; or  15 
B.  A total of 40 hours of education, training, study or work -site experience.  16 
The department shall present both options to enrollees and permit them to choose eith er 17 
option.   For the purpose of this subsection, work -site experience includes, but is not 18 
limited to, paid employment, work study, practicums, internships, clinical placements, 19 
laboratory or field work directly related to the enrollee's employment goal or any other 20 
work activities that, as determined by the department, will enhance the enrollee's 21 
employability in the enrollee's field.  In the last semester of the enrollee's educational 22 
program, work -site experience may also include resume preparation, emplo yment 23 
research, interviews and other activities related to job placement.  24 
The department shall make reasonable adjustments in the participation requirements in 25 
this subsection for good cause.  For the purpose of this subsection, "good cause" means 26 
circumst ances in which the required participation would cause the enrollee to seriously 27 
compromise academic performance.  "Good cause" includes, but is not limited to, a 28 
verifiable need to take care of a family member with special needs, a physical or mental 29 
healt h problem, illness, accident, death or a serious personal or family problem that 30 
necessitates reduced participation or time off from education, training or work.  An 31 
enrollee receiving aid under this chapter must make satisfactory progress in the enrollee' s 32 
educational program.  The department shall adopt rules defining satisfactory academic 33 
progress.  The department may not disapprove an educational plan based solely on the 34 
length of the educational program.  35

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  10-A.  Reimbursement of expenses.  Administer and improve reimbursement of 1

Sec. UUUU -14.  4 MRSA §1805 -A is enacted to read:  4 
§1805 -A.  Indigency determinations; redeterminations; verifications; collections  5 
1.  Duties.  The executive director shall administer and improve reimbursement of 6 
expenses incurred by assigned counsel and contract counsel by:  7 
A.  Estab lishing procedures to ensure that the eligibility of defendants and civil 8 
parties is verified and reviewed randomly and when circumstances have changed, 9 
information has changed, additional information is provided or as otherwise needed;  10 
B.  Petitioning the  court to reassess the indigency of a defendant or civil party if the 11 
executive director determines that indigency should be reassessed;  12 
C.  Providing to the commission recommendations to improve reimbursement of 13 
expenses;  14 
D.  Requiring that the amount of time spent on each case by assigned counsel or 15 
contract counsel is recorded separately for each case; and  16 
E.  Receiving from the courts collections for the costs of representation from 17 
defendants or civil parties who are found to be partially indigent or w ho have 18 
otherwise been determined to be able to reimburse the commission for expenses 19 
incurred by assigned counsel or contract counsel.  20 
2.  Determination of defendant’s or civil party’s eligibility.  The executive director 21 
shall provide the court having ju risdiction over a proceeding information used to 22 
determine indigency for guidance to the court in determining a defendant’s or civil 23 
party’s financial ability to obtain private counsel.  24 
3.  Partial indigency and reimbursement.  This subsection applies to p artial 25 
indigency and reimbursement of expenses incurred by assigned counsel or contract 26 
counsel.  27 
A.  If the court determines that a defendant or civil party is unable to pay to obtain 28 
private counsel but is able to contribute to payment of assigned counsel  or contract 29 
counsel, the court shall order the defendant or civil party to make installment 30 
payments up to the full cost of representation or to pay a fixed contribution.  The 31 
court shall remit payments received to the commission.  32 
B.  A defendant or civil  party may not be required to pay for legal services in an 33 
amount greater than the expenses actually incurred.  34 
C.  Upon petition of a defendant or civil party who is incarcerated, the court may 35 
suspend an order for reimbursement issued pursuant to this sub section until the time 36 
of the defendant’s or civil party’s release.  37 
D.  The executive director may enter into contracts to secure the reimbursement of 38 
fees and expenses paid by the commission as provided for in this section.  39

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  Sec. UUUU -15.  15 MRSA §1074, s ub-§3, as amended by PL 2003, c. 87, §1, is 1

3.  Setoff of defendant's property.   When a defendant has deposited cash or other 3 
property owned by the defendant as bail or has offered real estate owned by the defendant 4 
and subject to a bail lien as bail and the cash, other property or real estate has not been 5 
forfeited, the court, before ordering the cash or other property returned to the defendant or 6 
discharging the real estate bail lien, shall determine whether the cash, other proper ty or 7 
real estate or any portion of the cash, other property or real estate is subject to setoff as 8 
authorized by this section.  The court may order all or a portion of the bail owned by a 9 
defendant that has not been forfeited to be first paid and applied to one or more of the 10 
following:  11 
A.  Any fine, forfeiture, penalty or fee imposed upon a defendant as part of the 12 
sentence for conviction of any offense arising out of the criminal proceeding for 13 
which the bail has been posted and the sentence for convicti on of any offense in an 14 
unrelated civil or criminal proceeding;  15

unrelated proceeding;  18

request of the defendant or attorney and actually paid by the State on behalf of the 20 
defendant on the ground that the defendant has been found to be indigent in the 21 
proceeding for whic h bail has been posted and in any unrelated proceeding; and  22 
D.  Any surcharge imposed by Title 4, section 1057.  23 
The court shall apply any bail collected pursuant to this subsection first to restitution then 24 
to attorney's fees and then to fines and surcharg es. 25 
Sec. UUUU -16.  36 MRSA §191, sub -§2, ¶CCC is enacted to read:  26 
CCC.  The disclosure by employees of the bureau to an authorized representative of 27 
the Maine Commission on Indigent Legal Services for determining the eligibility for 28 
indigent legal services  and the ability to reimburse expenses incurred for assigned 29 
counsel and contract counsel under Title 4, chapter 37.  30 
Sec. UUUU -17.  Working group established.  Notwithstanding Joint Rule 353, 31 
the Working Group to Improve the Provision of Indigent Legal Serv ices, referred to in 32 
this section as "the working group," is established.  33 
1.  Membership.   The working group consists of 11 members appointed as follows:  34 
A.  Two members of the Senate appointed by the President of the Senate, including 35 
members from each of  the 2 parties holding the largest number of seats in the 36 
Legislature;  37 
B.  Two members of the House of Representatives appointed by the Speaker of the 38 
House, including members from each of the 2 parties holding the largest number of 39 
seats in the Legislatur e;  40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 748 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  C.  Two members appointed by Chief Justice of the Supreme Judicial Court, at least 1 
one of whom is on a court -appointed attorney roster administered by the Maine 2 
Commission on Indigent Legal Services;  3 
D.  The Attorney General or the Attorney General's d esignee;  4 
E.  The Commissioner of Administrative and Financial Services or the 5 
commissioner's designee;  6 
F.  The Director of the Governor's Office of Policy and Management or the director's 7 
designee;  8 
G.  The President of the Maine Prosecutors Association or the president's designee; 9 
and 10 
H.  The Chair of the Maine Commission on Indigent Legal Services or the chair's 11 
designee.  12 
2.  Chairs.   The first -named Senate member is the Senate chair and the first -named 13 
House of Representatives member is the House chair of  the working group.  14 
3.  Appointments; convening.   All appointments must be made no later than 30 days 15 
following the effective date of this section.  The appointing authorities shall notify the 16 
Executive Director of the Legislative Council once all appointm ents have been 17 
completed. When the appointment of all members has been completed, the chairs shall 18 
call and convene the first meeting of the working group.  If 30 days or more after the 19 
effective date of this section a majority of but not all appointments have been made, the 20 
chairs may request authority and the Legislative Council may grant authority for the 21 
working group to meet and conduct its business.  22 
4.  Duties.   The working group shall develop recommendations to improve the 23 
delivery of indigent legal services to those eligible to receive such services in the State.  24 
The recommendations must focus on ensuring adequate representation, increasing the 25 
efficiency in delivering legal services, verifying eligibility throughout representation and 26 
reducing cost s while still fully honoring the constitutional and statutory obligations to 27 
provide  representation.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the working group 28 
may access data maintained by the Maine Commission on Indigent Legal Services and 29 
shall mai ntain the confidentiality of any confidential information provided to the working 30 
group.  The working group may invite the participation and input of additional interested 31 
parties and request information as necessary to carry out its duties.  32 
5.  Staff assi stance.  The Legislative Council shall provide necessary staffing services 33 
to the working group.  34 
6.  Report.   No later than December 6, 2017, the working group shall submit a report 35 
that includes its findings and recommendations, including suggested legisla tion, for 36 
presentation to the 2nd Regular Session of the 128th Legislature.  The Joint Standing 37 
Committee on Judiciary may report out to the Second Regular Session of the 128th 38 
Legislature legislation to implement recommendations on matters related to the report.  39 
Sec. UUUU -18.  Transfer from General Fund; indigent legal services.  On 40 
or immediately after July 1, 2018, the State Controller shall transfer $16,400,290 from the 41 
unappropriated surplus of the General Fund to the Maine Commission on Indigent Legal  42 
Services, Reserve for Indigent Legal Services program, Other Special Revenue Funds.  43 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 749 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  Funds transferred pursuant to this section may not be transferred out of the Reserve for 1 
Indigent Legal Services program without legislative approval.  2

2019  2020 -2021  biennial budget and for each biennial budget thereafter, the biennial 9

appropriation of 18% in excess of the department's requested biennial budget.  11

§6-B.  Per diem compensation for Active Retired Justices of the Supreme Judicial 25 
Court  26

Judicial Court in any calendar year does not exceed 75% of the annual salary of an 34

Retired Justice of the Suprem e Judicial Court who receives compensation under this 36

D.  Appeal. Upon appeal of such determination or redetermination, the commission 14 
shall after affording the employing unit a reasonable opportunity for a fair hearing, 15 
make findings of fact and render  its decision which may affirm, modify, or reverse 16 
the determination of the Director of Unemployment Compensation or its 17 
representative. Such hearings shall be conducted in accordance with Title 5, section 18 
9051 et seq.  The employer or the commissioner may appeal a decision of the Division 19 
of Administrative Hearings to the commission, which may affirm, modify or reverse 20 
the decision upon review of the record.  The commission may hold further hearings 21 
or may remand the case to the Division of Administrative H earings for the taking of 22 
additional evidence.   The commission shall notify the parties to the proceeding of its 23 
findings of fact and decision, and such decision shall be  is subject to appeal pursuant 24 
to Title 5, section 11001 et seq. In the absence of app eal therefrom, the determination 25 
of the commission, together with the record of the proceeding under this subsection, 26 
shall be  is admissible in any subsequent material proceeding under this chapter, and if 27 
supported by evidence, and in the absence of fraud , shall be  is conclusive, except as 28 
to errors of law, upon any employing unit which  that was a party to the proceeding 29 
under this subsection.  30

§1226.  Appeal of determination or assessment  33

commissioner's designated representatives made under sections 1082, subsection 14,  36 
1221, 1222 and, 1225 and 122 8, or an assessment made under section 1225, to the 37 
commission  Division of Administrative Hearings  by filing an appeal, in accordance 38

notification is mailed to the employer's last known address as it appears in the records 40 
of the bureau or, in the absence of such mailing, within 30 days after the notification 41 
is delivered.  If the employer fails to perfect this appeal, the assessment or 42 
determination is final as to law and fact.  43 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 754 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  B.  Upon appeal from such assessment or determination the commission  Division of 1 
Administrative Hearings  shall, after affording the appellant and the commissioner's 2 
designated representative a reasonable opportunity for a fair hearing, make finding of 3 
facts a nd render its decision, which may affirm, modify or reverse the action of the 4 
designated representative. The conduct of the hearings shall be  is governed by 5 
regulations  rules  of the commission consistent with Title 5, section 9051 et seq. The 6 
commission  Division of Administrative Hearings  shall promptly notify the parties to 7 
the proceeding of its finding of facts and its decision. The decision shall be  is subject 8 
to appeal to the commission, which may affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the 9 
Division o f Administrative Hearings based on the evidence presented or may remand 10 
the case to the Division of Administrative Hearings for further hearing pursuant to the 11 
commission's rules.  The decision of the commission is subject to  appeal pursuant to 12 
Title 5, se ction 11001 et seq. The commissioner shall have  has the right to appeal a 13 
final decision of the Maine Unemployment Insurance Commission  commission  to the 14 
Superior Court.  15

proce edings under section 1082, subsection 14 , or this subchapter , which  that has become 17 
final, shall be  is binding in any proceedings relating to applications or requests for 18 
refunds or credit, insofar as such determination or decision necessarily involves the  issue 19 
of whether an employing unit constitutes an employer or whether services performed for, 20 
or in connection with, the business of such employing unit constitute employment.  21

Sec. CCCCC -1.  26 MRSA §1191, sub -§3, as amended by PL 2009, c. 466, §1, 26 
is further amended to read:  27 
3.  Weekly benefit for partial unemployment.   Each eligible individual who is 28 
partially unemployed in any week must be paid a partial benefit for that week.  The 29 
partial benefit is equal to the weekly benefit amount less the individual's weekly earnings 30 
in excess of $25 , except that, beginning the first full benefit week beginning on or after 31 
January 1, 2018, the partial b enefit is equal to the weekly benefit amount less the 32 
individual's weekly earnings in excess of $100 .  The following amounts are not 33 
considered wages for purposes of this subsection:  34 
A.  Amounts received from the Federal Government by a member of the Natio nal 35 
Guard and organized reserve, including base pay and allowances;  36 
B.  Amounts received as a volunteer firefighter or as a volunteer emergency medical 37 
services person;  38 
C.  Amounts received as an elected member of the Legislature; and  39

individual’s most recent weekl y benefit amount.  4 
Sec. CCCCC -2.  26 MRSA §1221, sub -§3, ¶A, as amended by PL 2013, c. 175, 5 
§1, is further amended to read:  6 
A.  At the time the status of an employing unit is ascertained to be that of an 7 
employer, the commissioner shall establish and mainta in, until the employer status is 8 
terminated, for the employer an experience rating record, to which are credited all the 9 
contributions that the employer pays on the employer's own behalf. This chapter may 10 
not be construed to grant any employer or individua ls in the employer's service prior 11 
claims or rights to the amounts paid by the employer into the fund. Benefits paid to 12 
an eligible individual under the Maine  Employment Security Law must be charged 13 
against the experience rating record of the claimant's mo st recent subject employer , 14 
except that, beginning January 1, 2018, benefits paid to an eligible individual under 15 
the Employment Security Law must be charged against the experience rating record 16 
of the claimant's employers in a ratio inversely proportional  to the claimant's 17 
employment beginning with the most recent employer,  or to the General Fund if the 18 
otherwise chargeable experience rating record is that of an employer whose status as 19 
such has been terminated; except that no charge may be made to an indi vidual 20 
employer but must be made to the General Fund if the commission finds that:  21 
(1)  The claimant's separation from the claimant's last employer was for 22 
misconduct in connection with the claimant's employment or was voluntary 23 
without good cause attribu table to the employer;  24

offered by a previous employer, without good cause attributable to the employer;  26

Sec. CCCCC -5.  26 MRSA §1221, sub -§4-A, ¶B, as amended by PL 2007, c. 28 
352, Pt. A, §2, is further amended to read:  29 
B.  Subject to paragraph A, an employer's contribution rate for the 12 -month period 30 
commencing Janua ry 1st of each year is based upon the employer's experience rating 31 
record and determined from the employer's reserve ratio.  The employer's reserve 32 
ratio is the percent obtained by dividing the amount, if any, by which the employer's 33 
contributions, credite d from the time the employer first or most recently became an 34 
employer, whichever date is later, up to and including June 30th of the preceding 35 
year, including any part of the employer's contributions due for that year paid on or 36 
before July 31st of that y ear, exceed the employer's benefits charged during the same 37 
period, by the employer's average annual payroll for the period of 36 consecutive 38 
months ending June 30th of the preceding year.  The employer's contribution rate is 39 
determined under subparagraphs  (1) to (8).  40

reserve ratios, beginning with the highest ratio.  For each employer, the schedu le 43

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  (a)  The amount of the employer's reserve ratio;  1 
(b)  The amount of the employer's annual taxable payroll; and  2 
(c)  A cumulative total consisting of the amount of the employer's annual 3 
taxable payroll plus the amount of the annual taxable pay rolls of all other 4 
employers preceding the employer on the list.  5 
(2)  The commissioner shall segregate employers into contribution categories in 6 
accordance with the cumulative totals under subparagraph (1), division (c).  The 7 
contribution category is deter mined by the cumulative payroll percentage limits 8 
in column B.  Each contribution category is identified by the contribution 9 
category number in column A that is opposite the figures in column B, which 10 
represent the percentage limits of each contribution ca tegory.  If an employer's 11 
taxable payroll falls in more than one contribution category, the employer must 12 
be assigned to the lower -numbered contribution category, except that an 13 
employer may not be assigned to a higher contribution category than is assigne d 14 
any other employer with the same reserve ratio.  15

(4)  The commissioner shall compute the predetermined yield by mul tiplying the 18 
ratio of total wages to taxable wages for the preceding calendar year by the 19 
planned yield.  20 
(5)  The commissioner shall determine the contribution rates effective for a rate 21 
year by multiplying the predetermined yield by the experience factors  for each 22 
contribution category.  Contribution category 20 in the table in subparagraph (2) 23 
must be assigned a contribution rate of at least 5.4%.  The employer's experience 24 
factor is the percentage shown in column C in the table in subparagraph (2) that 25 
corresponds with the employer's contribution category in column A, except that 26 
the experience factors in column E must be used to determine the contribution 27 
rates for rate years 2000 and 2001 and those in column D must be used for rate 28 
years 2002 and 2003.  Beginning January 1, 2018, for rate years when schedule A 29 
is in effect as determined in subparagraph (3 -A), the experience factor in 30 
subparagraph (2) for contribution category 1 is assigned an experience factor of 31 
0.00 in column C.  32 
(6)  If, subsequent to the assignment of contribution rates for a rate year, the 33 
reserve ratio of an employer is recomputed and changed, the employer must be 34 
placed in the position on the schedule prepared pursuant to subparagraph (1) that 35 
the employer would have occupied had th e corrected reserve ratio been shown on 36 
the schedule.  The altered position on the schedule does not affect the position of 37 
any other employer.  38 
(7)  In computing the contribution rates, only the wages reported by employers 39 
liable for payment of contributio ns into the fund and net benefits paid that are 40 
charged to an employer's experience rating record or to the fund are considered in 41 
the computation of the average benefit cost rate and the ratio of total wages to 42 
taxable wages.  43  A B C

PART DD DDD  5 
Sec. DDDDD -1.  Department of Labor; position review after 6 
reorganization.  The Commissioner of Labor is authorized to identify positions to be 7 
eliminated on or before June 30, 2019 pursuant to reorganizations within the Employment 8 
Security Services prog ram and the Employment Services Activity program and shall 9 
submit a report regarding any positions eliminated to the joint standing committee of the 10 
Legislature having jurisdiction over appropriations and financial affairs by January 6, 11 
2020.  12 
Sec. DDDDD -2.  Calculation.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the 13 
State Budget Officer shall calculate the amount of savings from the position eliminations 14 
under this Part and shall make adjustments by financial order upon approval of the 15 
Governor no later th an June 30, 2019. These eliminations are considered adjustments to 16 
authorized position count, appropriations and allocations.  17

marine resources.  Unexpended balances in the fund at the end of a fisc al year do not 17 
lapse but must be carried forward to the next fiscal year to be used for the purposes of the 18 
fund. Any interest earned on the money in the fund must be credited to the fund.  19

Sec. IIIII -1.  8 MRSA §1003, sub -§5 is enacted to read:  30

Gambling Control Unit, established as a bureau within the Department of Public Safety 32

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  PART JJJJJ  1 
Sec. JJJJJ -1.  17 MRSA §311, as amended by PL 2001, c. 342, §1, is further 2 
amended to read:  3 
§311.  Definitions  4 
As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following words 5 
shall have the following meanings.  6 
1.  Beano.   "Beano" means a specific kind of group game of chance, regardless of 7 
whether such a game is characterized by another name. Wherever the term "beano" is 8 
used, the word "bingo" or any other word used to characteriz e such a game may be 9 
interchanged. In "beano," each participant is given or sold one or more tally cards, so - 10 
called, each of which contains preprinted numbers or letters and may or may not be 11 
arranged in vertical or horizontal rows. The participant covers or marks the numbers or 12 
letters as objects similarly numbered or lettered are drawn from a receptacle and the 13 
winner or winners are determined by the sequence in which those objects are drawn.  The 14 
manner in which the winner is determined must be clearly a nnounced or displayed before 15 
any game is begun.  Until July 1, 1994, a game described in this subsection is "beano" 16 
and a licensee may conduct such a game regardless of whether the manner of determining 17 
the winner is specifically described as a permissible  manner of determining the winner in 18 
rules adopted by the Chief of State Police.   For the purposes of this chapter, to hold, 19 
conduct or operate beano includes charging a fee or offering something of value to play 20 
in exchange for the opportunity to receive something of value for winning a game.  21 
1-A.  Commercial beano hall permit.   "Commercial beano hall permit" means 22 
written authority from the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  issued to a 23 
permittee who rents or leases premises for profit to a l icensee to hold, conduct or operate 24 
"beano."  25 
1-B.  Chief of State Police.   "Chief of the State Police" or "chief" means the Chief of 26 
the State Police or the chief's designee.  27 
2.  Equipment.  "Equipment" shall mean  means  the receptacle and numbered objects 28 
to be drawn from it; the master board upon which such objects are placed as drawn; the 29 
tally cards or sheets bearing such numbers to be covered and the objects used to cover 30 
them; the boards or signs, however operated, used to display the numbers as they ar e 31 
drawn; public address systems; and any other articles essential to the operation, conduct 32 
and playing of "Beano."  33 
2-A.  Director.  "Director" means the Executive Director of the Gambling Control 34 
Board and the Gambling Control Unit.  35 
2-B.  Gambling Control  Unit.  "Gambling Control Unit" or "unit" means the bureau 36 
within the Department of Public Safety under Title 25, section 2902, subsection 12 or an 37 
authorized representative of the Gambling Control Unit.  38 
3.  License.  "License" shall mean that  means  written  authority from the Chief of the 39 
State Police  Gambling Control Unit  to hold, conduct or operate the amusement 40 
commonly known as  "Beano" for the entertainment of the public within the State of 41 
Maine. A location permit must accompany the license to be valid . 42 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 767 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  4.  Licensee.  "Licensee" shall mean  means  any organization which , including a 1 
federally recognized Indian tribe in the State, that  has been granted a license by the Chief 2 
of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  to hold, conduct or operate "Beano" or 3 
"Bingo."  4 
5.  Location permit.  "Location permit" shall mean  means  that card issued by the 5 
Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit , describing the premises or area in which 6 
"Beano" may be conducted. Such location permit must be accompanied by a license.  7 
Only such locations expressly described in the location permit shall be  are used for the 8 
conduct of any game.  9 
6.  Organization.  "Organization" shall mean  means  any firm, association or 10 
corporation authorized to conduct "Beano" in accordance with this chap ter. 11 
7.  Period.  "Period" shall mean  means  the number of calendar weeks authorized by a 12 
single license for the operation of "Beano" or "Bingo."  13 
7-A.  Permittee.   "Permittee" means an individual, corporation, partnership or 14 
unincorporated association that r ents or leases a building or facilities for profit to a 15 
licensee to hold, conduct or operate "beano."  16 
7-B.  Wild number beano.   "Wild number beano" means a beano occasion, game or 17 
series of beano games in which a number is picked or denoted as a wild numbe r that may 18 
be used to fill any number or letter on a beano card.  19 
8.  Winner -take-all round.   "Winner -take-all round" means a beano game or series 20 
of beano games in which all the proceeds from the sale of the cards for that round are 21 
paid to participants as  prizes during that round.  22 
9.  Registrant.  "Registrant" means a person or organization registered with the 23 
Gambling Control Unit to hold, conduct or operate beano games for which a license is not 24 
required.  25

§313 -C.  Organizations  eligible for registration; fees  15 
1.  Registration eligibility.  The Gambling Control Unit may accept registrations 16 
from the following organizations to conduct beano to be conducted by duly authorized 17 
members for the exclusive benefit of the organization:  18

fraternal, patriotic, religious or veterans organization that has been in existence and 22

registration; and  24

association described in this subsection that has been in existence for at least 2 years 26 
prior t o submitting a registration to conduct beano to the Gambling Control Unit.  27

organi zation has a charter from a national organization.  30

C.  For up to a calendar year, the fee is $400.  34 
D.  The fee for a single game is $5. An organization is limited to 6 single -game 35 
registrations in a calendar year.  36 
Registration fees required by this subsection must accompany a registration submitted to 37 
the Gambling Control Unit and must be credited to th e General Fund.  38

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §313 -D.  Registration exceptions  1 
Notwithstanding section 312, subsection 1 and section 313 -E, and subject to the 2 
conditions set out in this section, the following organizations may conduct beano without 3 
a license or without registering with  the Gambling Control Unit.  4 
1.  Senior organizations.  Clubs, groups or organizations composed of individuals at 5 
least 90% of whom are 62 years of age or older when beano is conducted for their own 6 
entertainment and not for profit.  7 
2.  Campgrounds.  A camp ground licensed under Title 22, section 2492 or a 8 
campground operated by the State Government or the Federal Government when:  9 
A.  Beano is offered exclusively to campground patrons and guests of campground 10 
patrons;  11 
B.  A prize awarded to a winner of a bean o game does not exceed a value of $25 for 12 
any one game; and  13 
C.  Proceeds from fees charged to campground patrons and their guests to participate 14 
in a beano game are used only to pay for prizes awarded to players and to cover the 15 
actual costs incurred to op erate the games.  16 
3.  Resort hotels. A bona fide resort hotel, which includes a full -service hotel facility 17 
and offers leisure and recreational activities to its patrons, such as tennis, golf or 18 
horseback riding, when:  19 
A.  Beano is offered exclusively to re sort hotel patrons and their guests;  20 
B.  A prize awarded to a winner of a beano game does not exceed a value of $25 for 21 
any one game; and  22 
C.  Proceeds from fees charged to resort hotel patrons and their guests to participate 23 
in a beano game are used only t o pay for prizes awarded to players and to cover the 24 
actual costs incurred to operate the games.  25 
4.  Schools.  A school for children in kindergarten to grade 8 when:  26 
A.  Games are offered exclusively to students and faculty of the school and their 27 
families ; 28 
B.  A prize awarded to a winner of a beano game does not exceed a value of $25 for 29 
any one game; and  30 
C.  Proceeds from fees charged to participate in a beano game are used only to pay 31 
for prizes awarded to players, to support a parent -teacher organizatio n associated 32 
with the school and to cover the actual costs incurred to operate the games.  33 
Notwithstanding section 319, persons under the age of 16 may take part in a game of 34 
beano conducted under subsection 2, 3 or 4.  35

total amount of prizes awarded on any one occasion may not exceed $1,400 in value 38 
except that once per calendar year on one occasion a registrant may award up to $2,000 in 39

§315 -A.  Limited dual beano registration  25 
The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  may issue a limited dual beano 26 
license  registration  to 2 organizations eligible for a re gular license  registration  to conduct 27 
a game of beano.  A limited dual beano license  registration  permits 2 organizations to 28 
conduct beano jointly on the same date and at the same location.  An organization may 29 
only conduct beano under the authority of a d ual license  registration  on 2 occasions 30 
during a calendar year.  The following provisions apply to licensure  registration  under 31 
this section.  32 
1.  Application.  The 2 organizations wishing to conduct beano jointly shall submit 33 
an application to the Chief of  the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  in a manner 34 
prescribed by the chief  unit. 35 
2.  Lead registrant.  One organization must be identified as the lead applicant  36 
registrant  and acknowledge responsibility for any violation of the laws or rules governing 37 
beano committed during the conduct of the game.  38 
3.  Disposition of revenue.  Revenue received from the conduct of the game must be 39 
divided in equal amounts between both organizations.  Each organization shall file a 40 
disposition of funds report as if that orga nization had conducted beano independently.  41

§317 -A.  Investigations; actions on licenses and registrations  40 
1.  Gambling Control Unit.   The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  41 
may:  42 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 773 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  A.  Investigate all aspects  of this chapter including the direct and indirect ownership 1 
or control of any licenses , registrations  or commercial beano hall permits;  2 
B.  Suspend, revoke or refuse to issue a license or registration , after notice of the 3 
opportunity for a hearing, if the  applicant, applicant's agent or employee, licensee , 4 
registrant  or the licensee's or registrant's  agent or employee violates a provision of 5 
this chapter or Title 17 -A, chapter 39 or fails to meet the statutory requirements for 6 
licensure or registration  pursuant to this chapter;  7 
C.  Immediately suspend or revoke a license or registration  if there is probable cause 8 
to believe that the licensee or the licensee's agent or employee or the registrant or the 9 
registrant's agent or employee  violated a provision of T itle 17 -A, chapter 39;  10 
D.  Suspend or revoke a commercial beano hall permit, after notice of the opportunity 11 
for hearing, if a permittee or permittee's employee commits murder or a Class A, B or 12 
C crime or violates a provision of this chapter or Title 17 -A, chapter 15, 29, 37 or 39;  13 
E.  Immediately suspend or revoke a commercial beano hall permit if there is 14 
probable cause to believe that the permittee or the permittee's employee committed 15 
murder or a Class A, B or C crime or violated a provision of Title 1 7-A, chapter 15, 16 
29, 37 or 39; and  17 
F.  Issue a subpoena in the name of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  in 18 
accordance with Title 5, section 9060, except that this authority applies to any stage 19 
of an investigation under this chapter and is not limite d to an adjudicatory hearing.  20 
This authority may not be used in the absence of reasonable cause to believe a 21 
violation has occurred.  If a witness refuses to obey a subpoena or to give any 22 
evidence relevant to proper inquiry by the chief  unit, the Attorne y General may 23 
petition the Superior Court in the county where the refusal occurred to find the 24 
witness in contempt.  The Attorney General shall cause to be served on that witness 25 
an order requiring the witness to appear before the Superior Court to show ca use why 26 
the witness should not be adjudged in contempt.  The court shall, in a summary 27 
manner, hear the evidence and, if it is such as to warrant the court in doing so, punish 28 
that witness in the same manner and to the same extent as for contempt committed  29 
before the Superior Court or with reference to the process of the Superior Court.  30 
2.  Action after notice and opportunity for hearing.   The Chief of the State Police  31 
Gambling Control Unit  shall notify the applicant, licensee , registrant  or permittee in 32 
writing, before a license , registration  or permit is denied, suspended or revoked pursuant 33 
to subsection 1, paragraph B or D, of the intended denial or commencement date of the 34 
suspension or revocation, which may not be made any sooner than 96 hours after th e 35 
licensee's , registrant's  or permittee's receipt of the notice, of the duration of the 36 
suspension or revocation and of the right to a hearing pursuant to this subsection.  The 37 
applicant, licensee , registrant  or permittee has the right to request a hearing  before the 38 
Commissioner of Public Safety or the commissioner's designee.  Upon the applicant's, 39 
licensee's , registrant's  or permittee's request for a hearing, the Commissioner of Public 40 
Safety shall provide a hearing.  The hearing must comply with the Mai ne Administrative 41 
Procedure Act.  The purpose of the hearing is to determine whether a preponderance of 42 
the evidence establishes that the applicant, applicant's agent or employee, licensee or 43 
licensee's agent or employee or registrant or registrant's agent  or employee  violated a 44 
provision of this chapter or Title 17 -A, chapter 39 or the permittee or the permittee's 45 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 774 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  employee committed murder or a Class A, B or C crime or violated a provision of this 1 
chapter or Title 17 -A, chapter 15, 29, 37 or 39.  A request  for a hearing may not be made 2 
any later than 10 days after the applicant, licensee , registrant  or permittee is notified of 3 
the proposed denial, suspension or revocation.  The suspension or revocation action must 4 
be stayed pending the hearing; the hearing may not be held any later than 30 days after 5 
the date the commissioner  director  receives the request unless otherwise agreed by the 6 
parties or continued upon request of a party for cause shown.  7 
3.  Immediate suspension or revocation.   A licensee whose lice nse or permittee 8 
whose permit is immediately suspended or revoked by the Chief of the State Police  9 
Gambling Control Unit  pursuant to subsection 1, paragraph C or E must be notified in 10 
writing of the duration of the suspension or revocation and the licensee 's or the 11 
permittee's right to request a hearing before the Commissioner of Public Safety or the 12 
commissioner's designee.  Upon the licensee's or permittee's request for a hearing, the 13 
Commissioner of Public Safety shall provide a hearing.  The hearing mus t comply with 14 
the Maine Administrative Procedure Act.  The purpose of the hearing is to determine 15 
whether a preponderance of the evidence establishes that the licensee or the licensee's 16 
agent or employee or registrant or registrant's agent or employee  violated a provision of 17 
Title 17 -A, chapter 39 or the permittee or the permittee's employee committed murder or 18 
a Class A, B or C crime or violated a provision of Title 17 -A, chapter 15, 29, 37 or 39.  A 19 
request for a hearing may not be made any later than 48 hours after the licensee or 20 
permittee is notified of the suspension or revocation.  A hearing may not be held any later 21 
than 10 days after the date the commissioner receives the request.  22 
Sec. JJJJJ -21.  17 MRSA §319, as enacted by PL 1975, c. 307, §2, is repealed 23 
and the following enacted in its place:  24 
§319.  Persons under 16 years of age  25 
Persons under 16 years of age are not permitted to take part in the conduct of, nor 26 
participate in, the game of "beano" or "bingo," nor may persons under 16 years of age b e 27 
admitted to the playing area unless accompanied by a parent, guardian or other 28 
responsible person.  29 
"Beano" or "bingo" games licensed or registered under this chapter may not be 30 
conducted unless some person at least 18 years of age, who has been a member in good 31 
standing of the licensee or registrant for at least 2 years, exercises exclusive control of 32 
each game played.  33 
A license or registration for the conduct of "beano" or "bingo" may not be issued to 34 
any firm, association, corporation or group composed wholly or primarily of persons 35 
under 16 years of age.  36

before the conduct of the games.  41

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §325.  Penalties  1 
1.  Violation of chapter or rules; general pen alty.  Except as otherwise specifically 2 
provided, a person, firm, association or corporation that violates a provision of this 3 
chapter or a rule of the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  prescribed by 4 
authority of this chapter commits a civil violation for which a fine of not more than 5 
$1,000 may be adjudged.  6 
2.  Commercial beano hall violations.   A person, corporation, partnership or 7 
unincorporated association that rents or leases a building or facilities to hold, conduct or 8 
operate "beano" or  "bingo" commits a Class E crime if that person, corporation, 9 
partnership or unincorporated association:  10 
A.  Rents or leases a building or facilities to hold, conduct or operate a "beano" or 11 
"bingo" game without a commercial beano hall permit issued by the  Chief of the 12 
State Police  Gambling Control Unit ; or 13 
B.  Violates a provision of this chapter or a rule adopted by the Chief of the State 14 
Police  Gambling Control Unit  pursuant to this chapter.  15 
Violation of this subsection is a strict liability crime as def ined in Title 17 -A, section 34, 16 
subsection 4 -A. 17 
Sec. JJJJJ -27.  17 MRSA §326, as amended by PL 1997, c. 684, §4, is further 18 
amended to read:  19 
§326.  Proceeds  20 
1-A.  Payment of proceeds.   An organization licensed or registered  to operate beano 21 
or bingo and Lu cky 7 games in conjunction with beano or bingo may use the proceeds or 22 
part of the proceeds to:  23 
A.  Pay salaries, wages or remuneration to any person directly involved in operating 24 
beano, bingo or Lucky 7 games;  25 
B.  Defray the expenses or part of the expen ses that further the purpose for which the 26 
organization is formed except that proceeds may not be:  27 
(1)  Used to purchase alcohol or to defray the cost of activities where alcohol is 28 
served; or  29 
(2)  Paid directly to organization members except as specifical ly allowed in this 30 
subsection; and  31 
C.  Defray the expenses or part of the expenses of a member, auxiliary member, 32 
officer or employee of the organization for a serious illness, injury or casualty loss if 33 
the licensee makes an application and the applicatio n is approved by the licensing 34 
division within the Bureau of State Police  Gambling Control Unit . 35 
(1)  An application must be made in the form and contain the information the 36 
licensing division  unit requires.  37 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 777 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  (a)  In the case of serious illness or injury, t he licensing division  unit may 1 
require certification by a licensed physician setting out the facts in support of 2 
the application.  3 
(b)  In the case of a casualty loss, the licensing division  unit may require 4 
statements or reports from a law enforcement agen cy, rescue or other 5 
emergency services personnel or an insurance agency to support the 6 
application.  7 
(c)  The licensing division may deny an application if it appears that the 8 
person who would receive the proceeds has adequate means of financial 9 
support, in cluding, but not limited to, insurance or workers' compensation 10 
benefits.  11 
1-B.  Filing.  An organization that chooses to use the proceeds or part of the proceeds 12 
as allowed by subsection 1 -A must file with the Chief of the State Police  Gambling 13 
Control Unit , at least quarterly, a form for the disposition of funds prescribed by the 14 
Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  detailing all payments made.  Every 15 
statement on the form must be made under oath by an officer of the organization.  16 
2.  Rules.  The rules adopted pursuant to section 317 must contain standards 17 
governing payments made under this section.  Payments under subsection 1 -A, paragraph 18 
A may not exceed 20% of the revenue generated by the games and the rules must limit 19 
payments to reasonable co mpensation, taking into account the nature of the services 20 
rendered, comparable wage rates, the size of the organization and other revenues, the size 21 
of the games and the revenue generated by the games.  The Chief of the State Police  22 
Gambling Control Unit  may disallow any excessive payment of proceeds, may suspend 23 
an organization's license or registration  for excessive payment of proceeds and may 24 
condition the restoration of an organization's license or registration  on the repayment of 25 
an excessive payment of proceeds by the organization.  26 
4.  Posting.   An organization licensed or registered  to operate beano or bingo and 27 
Lucky 7 games in conjunction with beano or bingo shall post in a conspicuous place in 28 
the room or hall where the licensed game is conducted a sign that states: the net revenue 29 
earned from the operation of those games in dollars and cents; the amount of charitable 30 
donations from that net revenue in dollars and cents; what percentage in dollars and cents 31 
of the net revenue that amount represents  in donations to nonprofit activities; and what 32 
percentage of the net revenue was distributed from licensed games for the previous 33 
calendar year and the current calendar year.  34

Sec. KKKKK -8.  17 MRSA §1831, sub -§5, as amended by PL 2011, c. 420, Pt. 33 
A, §11, is further amended to read:  34 
5.  Game of chance.  "Game of chance" means a game, contest, scheme or device in 35 
which: 36 
A.  A person stakes or risks something of value for the opportunity to win something 37 
of value;  38 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 780 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  B.  The rules of operation or play require an event the result of which is determined 1 
by chance, outside the control of the contestant or participant; and  2 
C.  Chance enters as an element that influences the outcome in a manner that cannot 3 
be eliminated through the application of skill.  4 
For the purposes of this subsection, "an event the result of which is determined by 5 
chance" includes but is not limited to a shuffle of a deck of cards, a roll of a die or dice or 6 
a random drawing or generation of an object that may include, but is not limited to, a 7 
card, a die, a number or simulations of any of these. A shuffle of a deck of cards, a roll of 8 
a die, a random draw ing or generation of an object or some other event the result of 9 
which is determined by chance that is employed to determine impartially the initial order 10 
of play in a game, contest, scheme or device does not alone make a game, contest, 11 
scheme or device a game of chance.  For purposes of this chapter, beano, bingo , a savings 12 
promotion raffle  and table games as defined in Title 8, section 1001, subsection 43 -A are 13 
not games of chance.  14

amended to read:  4 
§1832.  Licenses  5 
1.  License or registration required.  Except as provided in section 1833, a  A 6 
person, firm, corporation, association or organization may not hold, conduct or operate a 7 
game of chance without a license issued  by or, as applicable, without registering with  the 8 
Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  in accordance with this section.  A 9 
license is not required when a game of chance constitutes social gambling.  10 
2.  Eligible organizations; licenses.  Notwit hstanding other provisions of law, the 11 
Chief of the State Police  The Gambling Control Unit  may issue a license to operate a 12 
game of chance  card game and certain tournament games  to an organization that submits 13 
a completed application as described in subsec tion 5 and has been founded, chartered or 14 
organized in this State for a period of not less than 2 consecutive years prior to applying 15 
for a license and is:  16 
A.  An agricultural society;  17 
B.  A bona fide nonprofit charitable, educational, political, civic, re creational, 18 
fraternal, patriotic or religious organization;  19 
C.  A volunteer fire department; or  20 
D.  An auxiliary of any of the organizations in paragraphs A to C.  21 
2-A.  Registration.  The Gambling Control Unit may accept a registration from an 22 
eligible org anization described in subsection 2 and other persons as specifically provided 23 
under section 1835 -A, section 1836, subsection 4 -B and section 1837 -A to conduct games 24 
of chance, raffles and charitable cribbage tournaments.  An eligible organization or 25 
perso n seeking to register to conduct a game of chance, raffle or charitable cribbage 26 
tournament shall register in the manner prescribed by the Gambling Control Unit and 27 
shall maintain records and reports in the same manner as described under section 1839, 28 
except that disposition of funds reports are not required to be submitted to the Gambling 29 
Control Unit but must be maintained in the same manner as other records.  30 
3.  Must be 18 years of age.   The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  31 
may not accept  a registration to conduct a game of chance, a raffle or certain tournament 32 
games or accept  an application from or issue a license for card games and certain 33 
tournament games  under this section to a person or  representative of an eligible 34 
organization who is not 18 years of age or older.  35 
4.  Municipal approval required.   An eligible organization described in subsection 36 
2 applying for a license to conduct a card game of chance  and tournament games 37 
requiring a license  shall obtain written approval from the lo cal governing authority where 38 
the game of chance  is to be operated or conducted.  This written approval must be 39 
submitted with the application to the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  as 40 
described in subsection 5.  41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 782 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  5.  Application.   An eligibl e organization described in subsection 2 wishing  seeking 1 
to obtain a license  to operate or  conduct a card game of chance  or certain tournament 2 
games requiring a license  shall submit an application to the Chief of the State Police  3 
Gambling Control Unit .  Th e application must be in a form provided by the Chief of the 4 
State Police  Gambling Control Unit  and must be signed by a duly authorized officer of 5 
the eligible organization. The application must include the full name and address of the 6 
organization, a full  description of the card game of chance  or tournament game , the 7 
location where the card game or tournament game  is to be conducted and any other 8 
information determined necessary by the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  9 
for the issuance of a l icense to operate a card game of chance  or certain tournament 10 
games , including but not limited to membership lists, bylaws and documentation showing 11 
the organization's nonprofit status or charitable designation.  12 
6.  Multiple licenses.   The Chief of the Sta te Police  Gambling Control Unit  may 13 
issue more than one license or registration  to conduct or operate a game of chance  14 
governed by this chapter  simultaneously to an eligible organization described in 15 
subsection 2.  Each game of chance  governed by this chap ter must have a separate 16 
license, the nature of which must be specified on the license.  17 
7.  Agricultural fairs.   Notwithstanding any provision in this chapter to the contrary, 18 
in addition to games of chance, the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control U nit may 19 
issue a license  accept a registration  to conduct or operate games of chance known as 20 
"penny falls" or "quarter falls" at any agricultural fair, as long as the net revenue from 21 
those games is retained by the licensed  registered  agricultural society.  22 
8.  Electronic video machines.   The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  23 
may issue a game of chance  license to operate an electronic video machine to any eligible 24 
organization described in subsection 2.  25 
A.  An electronic video machine licensed under this section may only be operated for 26 
the exclusive benefit of the licensee, except that up to 50% of the gross proceeds 27 
from the operation of the machine may be paid to the distributor as a rental fee and 28 
for service and repair of the machine. Notwi thstanding other provisions of this 29 
chapter, a licensee may rent an electronic video machine from a distributor.  30 
B.  No more than 5 electronic video machines may be operated on the licensee's 31 
premises.  A separate games of chance license is required for th e operation of each 32 
electronic video machine.  33 
C.  A licensee may operate an electronic video machine only on the licensee's 34 
premises.  35 
D.  Two or more licensees may not share the use of any premises for the operation of 36 
electronic video machines.  37 
E.  A dist ributor or employee of the distributor may not be a member of the licensed 38 
organization.  39 
F.  An electronic video machine licensed under this subsection may not be operated 40 
in a manner that meets the definition of illegal gambling machine as described in 41 
Title 17 -A, section 952, subsection 5 -A. 42

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  Sec. KKKKK -16.  17 MRSA §1834, as amended by PL 2013, c. 218, §1, is 1 
further amended to read:  2 
§1834.  Fees  3 
1.  Original application fee.   The original application for a license to operate a game 4 
of chance must be acco mpanied by a fee of $7.50. This is not a fee for a license and is not 5 
refundable.  6 
2.  Operation of games of chance.   Except for electronic video games and games of 7 
cards  as provided in this section, the registration  fee for a license  to operate a game of 8 
chance is $15 for each week computed on a Monday to Sunday basis or for a portion of a 9 
week.  The fee for a license issued for a calendar month is $60 and the fee for licenses 10 
issued for a calendar year is $700.  11 
The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Contro l Unit  may issue any combination of 12 
weekly or monthly licenses for the operation of games of chance.  Except for games of 13 
cards as provided in subsection 4, licenses  Registration  to conduct any authorized game 14 
of chance may be issued for a period of up to 12 months on one application.  15 
3.  Operation of electronic video machines.   The fee for a game of chance license to 16 
operate an electronic video machine in accordance with section 1832, subsection 8 is $15 17 
for each week computed on a Monday to Sunday basis o r for a portion of a week.  The 18 
fee for a license issued for a calendar month is $60.  19 
The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  may issue any combination of 20 
weekly or monthly licenses for the operation of electronic video machines.  A license or 21 
combination of licenses to operate an authorized electronic video machine may be issued 22 
for a period of up to 12 months.  23 
4.  Games of cards.   The fee for a license issued to an organization to operate a game 24 
of cards, when the organization charges no more than a $10 daily entry fee for 25 
participation in the games of cards and when no money or valuable thing other than the 26 
$10 daily entry fee is gambled by any person in connection with the game of cards, is $30 27 
for each calendar year or portion of a calendar year.  For card games that are played by 28 
placing the maximum bet of $1 per hand or deal, the license fee is the same as provided 29 
in subsection 2  for a calendar month is $60 and the fee for licenses issued for a calendar 30 
year is $700 . 31 
5.  Distributors.   The fee for a license issued to a distributor is $625 for each 32 
calendar year or portion of a calendar year.  33 
6.  Printers.  The fee for a license issued to a printer is $15 for each calendar year or 34 
portion of a calendar year.  35 
7.  Application.   A license to ope rate any authorized card game of chance  may be 36 
issued for a period of up to 12 months on one application.  Authority to conduct a game 37 
of chance, a raffle or charitable cribbage tournament games pursuant to section 1836, 38 
subsection 4 -B may be granted for a  period of up to 12 months on one registration.  39 
All fees required by this section must accompany the a registration or an  application 40 
for any license issued by authority of this chapter.  41

 Page 784 - 128LR2175(03) -1

Sec. KKKKK -17.  17 MRSA §1835, as amended by PL 2013, c. 149, §1 and c. 6 
218, §2, is further amended to read:  7 
§1835.  Conduct card games  8 
1.  Wagers or entry fees for card games; exceptions.   The following limits apply to 9 
games of chance  a card game . 10 
A.  The maximum bet for a licensed game of chance including  card games  game  in 11 
which bets are placed per hand or per deal is $1.  12 
B.  Licensed card games that award part or all of the entry fees paid to participa te in 13 
the game as prize money and in which no money or thing of value is wagered except 14 
for the entry fee are limited to a $10 daily entry fee and no more than 60 players at 15 
any one time at any one location.  16 
C.  If the licensee operates card games of chanc e for less than 3 total days in a 17 
calendar year and contributes 100% of the gross revenue from those games of chance  18 
to charity, the amount wagered must be limited to:  19 
(1)  A $1 daily entry fee;  20 
(2)  Fifty cents per game; or  21 
(3)  Twenty -five cents per card  received.  22 
Prior to play of the game, the licensee shall determine which of the limits in 23 
subparagraphs (1), (2) and (3) is to be used and shall post the limit where the game is 24 
conducted . 25 
2.  Games conducted by members and bartenders of licensee only.   A card game 26 
of chance  licensed pursuant to this chapter must be operated and conducted for the 27 
exclusive benefit of the licensee and must be operated and conducted only by duly 28 
authorized members of the licensee or by persons employed by the licensee as bart enders, 29 
except that nonmembers employed by the licensee as bartenders may not operate or 30 
conduct any card game of chance  permitted under subsection 5, paragraph B.  The 31 
requirements of this subsection do not apply to any agricultural society licensed to 32 
operate a card game of chance . 33 
3.  Games conducted at agricultural fair by members of the agricultural society 34 
or a bona fide nonprofit.  Games of chance  Card games  operated and conducted solely 35 
by members of an agricultural society or card games of chance  operated and conducted 36 
by members of bona fide nonprofit organizations on the grounds of the agricultural 37 
society and during the annual fair of the agricultural society may use cash, tickets, tokens 38 
or other devices approved by the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  by rule.  39 
Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, the tickets, tokens or other devices 40 
approved by the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  must be unique to the 41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 785 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  agricultural society and may be in denominations  of 25¢, 50¢ or $1.  The tickets, tokens 1 
or devices approved by the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  may be sold 2 
and redeemed only by a person who has been a member or active volunteer of the 3 
agricultural society for at least 2 fair seasons.   The agricultural society has the burden of 4 
proof for demonstrating the qualification of members or active volunteers.  5 
An agricultural society that uses tokens shall provide records and reports as required by 6 
section 1839.  7 
4.  Persons under 18 years of ag e.  Except as provided in this subsection, a  A 8 
licensee, game owner or operator may not permit a person under 18 years of age to take 9 
part in a card game of chance, and a person under 18 years of age may not sell chances, 10 
except in relation to charitable, religious or recognized youth associations .  11 
Notwithstanding any rule to the contrary, upon receiving an application on a form 12 
provided by the Chief of the State Police and a determination by the chief that a game of 13 
chance licensed to be conducted at a fe stival -style event is designed to attract players 14 
under 18 years of age and awards a nonmonetary prize valued at less than $10 for every 15 
chance played, the chief may permit:  16 
A.  Persons under 18 years of age to conduct or operate the game of chance; and  17 
B.  Persons under 18 years of age to play the game of chance without being 18 
accompanied by an adult.  19 
Nothing in this subsection permits games of chance to be operated without a license.  20 
5.  Location.   A license issued pursuant to this section must specify the  location 21 
where the organization may operate the licensed card game of chance .  A licensee may 22 
not operate card games of chance  in more than one location at the same time.  23 
A.  An agricultural society or a bona fide nonprofit organization may operate a card 24 
game of chance  on the grounds of an agricultural society and during the annual fair of 25 
the agricultural society.  26 
B.  No more than one licensee may operate a card game of chance  at a time on the 27 
same premises.  In any room where a licensed card game of cha nce is being 28 
conducted, there must be at least one member of the licensee present in that room for 29 
every 2 nonmembers who are present.  That member must have been a member of the 30 
licensee for at least one year.  A member of the licensee, either directly or  through 31 
another member or guest, may not stake or risk something of value in the licensee's 32 
card game of chance  unless the member has been a member of the licensee for at 33 
least 14 days not including the day of admission into membership.  34 
A bona fide nonpro fit organization may operate a licensed card game of chance  to which 35 
the general public has access once every 3 months for a period not to exceed 3 36 
consecutive days.  The licensed card game of chance  may be operated at any location 37 
described in the license  and may be conducted only by members of the licensee.  This 38 
subsection does not apply to raffles conducted in accordance with section 1837.  39 
6.  Door prizes.   Distribution of tickets to an event upon which appear details 40 
concerning any prize to be given aw ay as a result of a drawing is a game of chance within 41 
the meaning of this chapter; a distribution of tickets containing only the words "Door 42 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 786 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  Prize," without further description, is excluded from the provisions of this chapter, as 1 
long as no promotional ma terials or presentations, written or oral, describe the door prize.  2 
7.  "Donation" not to provide an exclusion.  The word "donation" printed on a 3 
ticket does not exclude the sponsoring organization from complying with this chapter.  4 
8.  Wager limit exceptio n.  Notwithstanding subsection 1, an organization that is 5 
licensed to conduct games of chance in accordance with this chapter is permitted to 6 
accept wagers up to $50 per hand for a poker run.  The organization must inform the 7 
Chief of the State Police  Gamb ling Control Unit  30 days in advance of the date when the 8 
organization intends to conduct a poker run with an increased wager limit.  An 9 
organization is limited to 2 poker run events per calendar year in which wagers up to $50 10 
per hand are permitted.  For the purposes of this subsection, "poker run" means a game of 11 
chance using playing cards that requires a player to travel from one geographic location 12 
to another in order to play the game.  13

4-A.  Exception for super cribbage tournament.  Notwithstanding any provision of 30 
this section to  the contrary, the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  may 31

cards from their dealt hand to create a crib of 4 cards unseen by other players that will be 35 
ultimately part of the dealer's hand.  The license fee for a super cribbage tournam ent is 36

for a tournament game by this section except as follows.  38

Sec. KKKKK -22.  17 MRSA §1836, sub -§4-B is enacted to read:  11 
4-B.  Charitable cribbage tournament.  The Gambling Control Unit shall accept a 12 
registration for a cribbage tou rnament to be conducted as prescribed by this subsection.  13 
For the purposes of this section, "cribbage" means a card game that uses a board and pegs 14 
to keep score and of which the characteristic feature is a crib into which players discard 15 
cards from their  dealt hand to create a crib of 4 cards unseen by other players that will be 16 
ultimately part of the dealer's hand. In a cribbage tournament, winners are determined by 17 
a process of elimination.  A cribbage tournament may extend beyond a calendar day.  A 18 
person may operate a cribbage tournament as registered by the Gambling Control Unit if 19 
the operator:  20 
A.  Is a restaurant licensed in accordance with Title 22, chapter 562 or a manufacturer 21 
licensed under Title 28 -A, section 1355 -A who offers complimentary sam ples or 22 
samples for a charge to the public at the licensee's manufacturing facility.  For the 23 
purposes of this subsection, "restaurant" means a reputable place operated by 24 
responsible persons of good reputation that is regularly used for the purpose of 25 
providing food for the public and that has adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining 26 
room equipment and capacity for preparing and serving suitable food for the public;  27 
B.  Limits play to the location of the licensed establishment and to patrons of the 28 
license d establishment who are 21 years of age or older; and  29 
C.  Charges an entry fee not to exceed $25 per person for participation in the cribbage 30 
tournament.  Notwithstanding section 1838, all entry fees must be awarded as prizes 31 
to winners of the tournament f or which the entry fees were paid, except that the 32 
operator may donate all or a portion of the entry fees to a charitable organization.  An 33 
operator may not charge a fee except for the entry fee and may not receive any 34 
portion of the proceeds from the oper ation of the cribbage tournament.  35

Sec. KKKKK -25.  17 MRSA §1837 -A is enac ted to read:  5 
§1837 -A.  Raffles  6 
1.  Registration required.  Unless otherwise specified by this section, a person or 7 
organization may not conduct a raffle without registering with the Gambling Control 8 
Unit.  9 
2.  Raffle with a prize of $1,000 or less.  A perso n or organization is not required to 10 
register with the Gambling Control Unit to conduct a raffle in which the total value of the 11 
prize offered to the holder of the winning chance does not exceed $1,000.  If the raffle is 12 
conducted in a manner in which ther e are multiple winning chances, the total value of all 13 
prizes offered may not exceed a value of $1,000.  14 
3.  Raffle with a noncash prize of $1,001 to $10,000.  A person or organization may 15 
conduct a raffle in which the total value of the prize offered to th e winning chance is 16 
greater than $1,001 and does not exceed $10,000 upon the acceptance of a registration by 17 
the Gambling Control Unit.  The Gambling Control Unit may not accept a registration for 18 
a raffle under this subsection unless the registration stat es a verifiable charitable purpose 19 
for which the proceeds of the raffle are dedicated to benefit.  If the raffle is conducted in a 20 
manner in which there are multiple winning chances, the total value of all prizes offered 21 
may not exceed a value of $10,000.  A prize offered for a raffle conducted under this 22 
subsection may not be in the form of cash and may not be exchanged for cash.  23 
4.  Raffle with a noncash prize up to $75,000 conducted by eligible organization.  24 
An eligible organization as described in sect ion 1832, subsection 2 may conduct a raffle 25 
in which the total value of the prize offered to the winning chance does not exceed 26 
$75,000 upon the acceptance of a registration by the Gambling Control Unit.  The 27 
registration must state a verifiable charitable  purpose for which the proceeds of the raffle 28 
are dedicated to benefit.  If the raffle is conducted in a manner in which there are multiple 29 
winning chances, the total value of all prizes offered may not exceed a value of $75,000.  30 
A prize for a raffle cond ucted under this subsection may not be in the form of cash and 31 
may not be exchanged for cash.  An eligible organization may not conduct more than one 32 
raffle under this subsection in a 12 -month period.  33 
5.  Raffle conducted by persons 18 years of age or olde r; exception.  Raffle 34 
chances or tickets may not be sold by a person under 18 years of age, except for raffles 35 
conducted under subsections 2 and 3 designed to benefit activities of children at an event 36 
generally attended by persons under 18 years of age.  37

games.  3

established in Title 26, section 664, subsection 1, unless the game is one for which 6 
the limit in paragraph A applies.  7
