the licensing division  Gambling Control Unit  requires.  21 
(1)  In the case of serious illness or injury, the licensing division  unit may require 22 
certification by a lic ensed physician in support of the application.  23 
(2)  In the case of a casualty loss, the licensing division  unit may require 24 
statements or reports from a law enforcement agency, rescue or other emergency 25 
services personnel or an insurance agency to support the application.  26 
(3)  The licensing division  unit may deny an application if it appears that the 27 
person who would receive the proceeds has adequate means of financial support, 28 
including, but not limited to, insurance or workers' compensation benefits.  29 
3.  Rules.   The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  shall adopt routine 30 
technical rules in accordance with Title 5, chapter 375 to carry out this section.  31 
Sec. KKKKK -27.  17 MRSA §1839, as enacted by PL 2009, c. 487, Pt. A, §2, is 32 
amended to read:  33 
§1839.  Records and reports  34 
1.  Records required.   Each licensee or registrant  shall keep a record of all financial 35 
transactions involving games of chance  operated under each license granted to the 36 
licensee  this chapter .  The treasurer of the licensee or a nother officer designated by the 37 
treasurer is responsible for maintaining those records.   The records must include an exact 38 
account of all gross revenue from the games, an itemization of all allowable expenses, 39 
including, but not limited to, the cost of pr izes, printing, licenses and administration, and 40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 792 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  the disposition of all proceeds, including, but not limited to, all gifts, grants and payments 1 
to any person, firm, corporation, association or organization for any purpose whatsoever.  2 
All financial records  involving games of chance  operated under this chapter  must be 3 
separate and distinguishable from other records of the organization.  Revenue from more 4 
than one game of chance  operated under this chapter  may be entered into one account.  5 
2.  Records required  for licensee or registrant employing tokens.   If a licensee or 6 
registrant  employs tokens to account for revenue from games of chance  operated under 7 
this chapter  and if the licensee or registrant  maintains direct control over the sale and 8 
redemption of the  tokens and keeps accurate records of all tokens used, then the chief  9 
Gambling Control Unit  may by rule alter or reduce the record -keeping requirements of 10 
subsection 1 to the extent that a licensee's  the use of tokens renders those records 11 
unnecessary for adequate control of the licensee's or registrant's  games.  12 
3.  Disposition of funds reports.   Within 10 business days after the last day of any 13 
period during which a licensed game of chance  under this chapter  is conducted with other 14 
than an annual license o r within 10 business days after the end of each calendar month 15 
during which a licensed game of chance is conducted with an annual license , the licensee 16 
shall file with the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  a disposition of funds 17 
form prescrib ed and furnished by the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit , 18 
detailing for the period the total receipts and expenditures of the game and the disposition 19 
of funds.  Every statement must be made under oath by an officer of the licensee or by the  20 
member in charge of the conduct of the game.  A registrant who conducts games under 21 
this chapter shall maintain records of disposition of funds, which must be made available 22 
to the Gambling Control Unit upon request.  23 
4.  Disposition of funds reports from registrant using tokens.   If tokens are 24 
employed to account for revenue from games of chance  operated under this chapter , then 25 
the licensee  registrant  shall maintain a  report of the number of tokens sold, the number 26 
redeemed and the disposition of funds fr om the proceeds of sale in addition to such other 27 
information as the chief  Gambling Control Unit  may require under subsection 3.  28 
5.  Records maintained for 3 years.   Every licensee or registrant  that has conducted 29 
a game of chance  under this chapter  shall maintain and keep for a period of 3 years 30 
reports as may be necessary to substantiate the records and reports required by this 31 
section or by the rules adopted under this chapter.  32 
6.  Location.  All records maintained by a licensee or registrant  pursuant to this 33 
section and pursuant to the rules adopted under this chapter must be kept and maintained 34 
on the premises where the game of chance  has been conducted or at the primary business 35 
office of the licensee or registrant , which must be designated by the licen see in the license 36 
application or the registrant in the registration .  These records must be open to inspection 37 
by the Chief of the State Police or the chief's representative  Gambling Control Unit , and a 38 
licensee or registrant  may not refuse the Chief of t he State Police or the chief's 39 
representative  Gambling Control Unit  permission to inspect or audit the records.  Refusal 40 
to permit inspection or audit of the records does not constitute a crime under this chapter 41 
but constitutes grounds for revocation of l icense or registration . 42

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 793 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §1840.  Distributors; records and reports  1 
1.  Printers licensed.   A printer in the State may not print materials to be used in the 2 
conduct of a licensed game of chance unless licensed by the Chief of the State Police.  A 3 
printer licensed under this section may act as a distributor without having to be licensed 4 
as a distributor as long as neither the printer nor anyone on the printer's behalf acts as a 5 
seller for services connected with a game of chance outside of the confines of the printer's 6 
premises described in that printer's license.  If that printer or someone else acts as a seller 7 
for the printer's services in connection with a game of c hance outside of the premises 8 
described on that printer's license, either that printer or any person or persons acting on 9 
that printer's behalf must be licensed as a distributor under subsection 2.  10 
The applicant for a printer's license, or, if the applican t is a firm, corporation, association 11 
or other organization, its resident manager, superintendent or official representative shall 12 
file an application with the Chief of the State Police on a form provided by the Chief of 13 
the State Police.  The Chief of the  State Police shall furnish to each applicant a current 14 
copy of this chapter and the rules adopted under section 1843 and to each licensee a copy 15 
of any changes or additions to this chapter and the rules adopted under section 1843.  16 
2.  Distributors license d.  A distributor may not sell, lease, market or otherwise 17 
distribute gambling apparatus or implements unless licensed by the Chief of the State 18 
Police  Gambling Control Unit , except that a license is not required for the sale, marketing 19 
or distribution of raffle tickets when the holder of the winning chance receives something 20 
of value worth less than $10,000.  21 
A nonresident manufacturer or distributor of gambling apparatus or implements doing 22 
business in the State must have an agent in this State who is lice nsed as a distributor.  A 23 
distributor may not sell, market or otherwise distribute gambling apparatus or implements 24 
to a person or organization, except to persons or eligible  organizations described under 25 
section 1832, subsection 2  licensed or registered  to operate or conduct games of chance  26 
under section 1832, licensed  this chapter or registered  to conduct a special raffle under 27 
section 1837, subsection 2 or eligible to conduct a raffle pursuant to section 1837, 28 
subsection 1  1837 -A.  A distributor may not lease or loan or otherwise distribute free of 29 
charge any gambling apparatus or implements to an organization eligible to operate a 30 
game of chance  under this chapter , except that a distributor may lease gambling apparatus 31 
or implements to an agricultural so ciety licensed  registered  to operate games of chance on 32 
the grounds of the agricultural society and during the annual fair of the agricultural 33 
society as long as the distributor does not charge the agricultural society an amount in 34 
excess of 50% of the gro ss revenue from any licensed  game of chance  conducted under 35 
this chapter . 36 
A licensee or registrant  shall acquire gambling apparatus and implements from a 37 
distributor licensed under this section, unless the gambling apparatus or implements are 38 
printed, manu factured or constructed by the licensed organization.  At no time may any 39 
licensee print, manufacture or construct any gambling apparatus or implements for 40 
distribution to any other licensee.  The applicant for a distributor's license , or, if the 41 
applicant  is a firm, corporation, association or other organization, its resident manager, 42 
superintendent or official representative shall file an application with the Chief of the 43 
State Police  Gambling Control Unit  on a form provided by the Chief of the State Poli ce 44 
Gambling Control Unit .  The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  shall 45 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 794 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  furnish to each applicant a current copy of this chapter and the rules adopted under 1 
section 1843 and to each licensee a copy of any changes or additions to this chapter a nd 2 
the rules adopted under section 1843.  3 
3.  Sales agreements.  A distributor shall forward to the Chief of the State Police  4 
Gambling Control Unit , prior to delivery of any gambling machine to the purchaser, a 5 
copy of all sales agreements, sales contracts or any other agreements involving the sale of 6 
any gambling machine.  The terms of the sales contract must include, but are not limited 7 
to, the name of seller, name of purchaser, address of seller, address of purchaser, 8 
description of the gambling machine i ncluding serial number and model name and 9 
number, total sale price, any arrangement or terms for payments and the date of final 10 
payment.  11 
Any change, modification or alteration of these agreements must be reported to the Chief 12 
of the State Police  Gambling C ontrol Unit  by the purchaser within 6 days of the change, 13 
modification or alteration.  14 
4.  Service agreements.  With the sale of any gambling machine involving a service 15 
agreement, the distributor shall forward to the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Contr ol 16 
Unit a copy of the agreement prior to delivery of the machine.  The terms of the service 17 
agreements must include, but are not limited to, the name of seller, name of purchaser, 18 
address of seller, address of purchaser, description of machine to be servic ed including 19 
serial number and model name and number and all prices and payments for that service.  20 
Any change, modification or alteration of the agreement must be reported to the Chief of 21 
the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  by the purchaser within 6 day s of the change, 22 
modification or alteration.  23 
5.  Agricultural societies; lease agreements.   When a gambling apparatus or 24 
implement is leased as provided in subsection 2 to an agricultural society, the distributor 25 
shall forward to the Chief of the State Pol ice Gambling Control Unit  a copy of the lease 26 
agreement prior to delivery of the gambling apparatus or implement.  The terms of the 27 
lease must include, but are not limited to, the name of the lessor; address of the lessor; 28 
name of the lessee; address of th e lessee; description of the gambling apparatus or 29 
implement; serial number, model name or number of the gambling apparatus or 30 
implement; and all prices and payments for the lease.  Each lease must be for a specific 31 
period of time no longer than the durati on of the annual fair of that lessee, and each 32 
gambling apparatus must have its own separate lease.  Gambling apparatus or implements 33 
leased under this section:  34 
A.  May be operated only for the exclusive benefit of the agricultural society, except 35 
that the  agricultural society may pay a distributor up to 50% of gross gaming revenue 36 
in accordance with subsection 2; and  37 
B.  Must bear the name and address of the distributor.  38 
6.  Reports.   At the end of each calendar month, a distributor or printer  shall file w ith 39 
the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  a report indicating:  40 
A.  The names and addresses of all persons or organizations to which the distributor 41 
or printer  has distributed equipment and the dates of the distribution;  42 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 795 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  B.  A description of t he equipment distributed, including serial number and model 1 
name and number; and  2 
C.  The quantities of any equipment distributed.  3 
7.  Retention and inspection of records.  A distributor or printer  shall maintain and 4 
keep for a period of 3 years, on the prem ises of the distributor or printer , any records that 5 
may be necessary to substantiate the reports required by this section or by the rules 6 
adopted under this chapter.  The records must be open to inspection, and a licensee or 7 
registrant  may not refuse the Chief of the State Police or the chief's representative  8 
Gambling Control Unit  permission to inspect or audit the records.  Refusal to permit 9 
inspection or audit of the records does not constitute a crime under this chapter but 10 
constitutes grounds for revoc ation of license or registration . 11 
8.  Reports generally.   The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  shall 12 
require from any licensed printer or  distributor, or from any organization authorized to 13 
operate a game of chance  under this chapter , whatev er reports determined necessary by 14 
the chief  unit for the purpose of the administration and enforcement of this chapter.  15 
Sec. KKKKK -29.  17 MRSA §1842, as enacted by PL 2009, c. 487, Pt. A, §2, is 16 
amended to read:  17 
§1842.  Investigations and actions on lice nses and registrations; evidence  18 
1.  Investigation.   The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  shall 19 
investigate or cause to be investigated all complaints made to the chief  unit and all 20 
violations of this chapter or the rules adopted pursuant t o section 1843.  21 
2.  Refusal to issue, modify or renew; modification; suspension; revocation.  Each 22 
of the following is grounds for an action to refuse to issue, modify or renew or to modify, 23 
suspend or revoke the license of a distributor or printer  licensed  under this chapter:  24 
A.  The distributor or printer  or its resident manager, superintendent or official 25 
representative made or caused to be made a false statement of material fact in 26 
obtaining a license under this chapter or in connection with service rend ered within 27 
the scope of the license issued;  28 
B.  The distributor or printer  or its resident manager, superintendent or official 29 
representative violated any provision of this chapter or any rule adopted by the Chief 30 
of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  under section 1843.  31 
(1)  Except as provided in subparagraph (2), the Chief of the State Police  32 
Gambling Control Unit  shall give written notice of any violation to the distributor 33 
or printer  who then has 14 days to comply. Failure to comply within the 14 -day 34 
period is grounds for an action under this section.  35 
(2)  If a distributor or printer  violates section 1840, subsection 1 or 2, the Chief of 36 
the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  is not required to give the notice or allow 37 
the compliance period provided  in subparagraph (1); or  38 
C.  The distributor or printer  or its resident manager, superintendent or official 39 
representative has been:  40 
(1)  Convicted of a crime under this chapter or Title 17 -A, chapter 39; or  41

 Page 796 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  (2)  Convicted within the prior 10 years of any crime for which imprisonment for 1 
more than one year may be imposed.  2 
3.  Gambling Control Unit.   The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  3 
may:  4 
A.  Investigate all aspects of this chapter including the direct and indirect ownership 5 
or control of a ny licenses or registrations ; 6 
B.  Suspend, revoke or refuse to issue a license or accept a registration , after notice 7 
and the opportunity for a hearing, if the applicant, applicant's agent or employee, 8 
licensee or, licensee's agent or employee, or registra nt, registrant's agent  or employee 9 
or person registering  violates a provision of this chapter or Title 17 -A, chapter 39 or 10 
fails to meet the statutory requirements for licensure or registration  pursuant to this 11 
chapter;  12 
C.  Immediately suspend or revoke a license or registration  if there is probable cause 13 
to believe that the licensee or the licensee's agent or employee or the registrant or the 14 
registrant's agent  or employee violated section 1832, subsection 8, paragraph C; 15 
section 1841, subsection 2; or a p rovision of Title 17 -A, chapter 39;  16 
D.  Issue a subpoena in the name of the State Police in accordance with Title 5, 17 
section 9060, except that this authority applies to any stage of an investigation under 18 
this chapter and is not limited to an adjudicatory hearing.  This authority may not be 19 
used in the absence of reasonable cause to believe a violation has occurred.  If a 20 
witness refuses to obey a subpoena or to give any evidence relevant to proper inquiry 21 
by the chief  unit, the Attorney General may petitio n the Superior Court in the county 22 
where the refusal occurred to find the witness in contempt.  The Attorney General 23 
shall cause to be served on that witness an order requiring the witness to appear 24 
before the Superior Court to show cause why the witness s hould not be adjudged in 25 
contempt.  The court shall, in a summary manner, hear the evidence and, if it is such 26 
as to warrant the court in doing so, punish that witness in the same manner and to the 27 
same extent as for contempt committed before the Superior Court or with reference to 28 
the process of the Superior Court; and  29 
E.  Require such evidence as the chief  unit determines necessary to satisfy the chief  30 
unit that an applicant or organization licensed or registered  to conduct games of 31 
chance  under this chap ter conforms to the restrictions and other provisions of this 32 
chapter.  Charters, organizational papers, bylaws or other such written orders of 33 
founding that outline or otherwise explain the purpose for which an organization was 34 
founded , must, upon request , be forwarded to the Chief of the State Police  Gambling 35 
Control Unit .  The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  may require of 36 
any licensee , registrant or person registering  or of any person operating, conducting 37 
or assisting in the operation o f a game  licensed game of chance  or registered under 38 
this chapter,  evidence as the chief  unit may determine necessary to satisfy the chief  39 
unit that the person is a duly authorized member of the licensee , registrant or person 40 
registering  or a person employ ed by the licensee , registrant or person registering  as a 41 
bartender as required by section 1835, subsection 2 and section 1835 -A, subsection 2 .  42 
Upon request, this evidence must be forwarded to the Chief of the State Police  43 
Gambling Control Unit .  The Chie f of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  may 44 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 797 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  require such evidence as the chief  unit may determine necessary regarding the 1 
conduct of games of chance by a licensee  authorized under this chapter  to determine 2 
compliance with this chapter.  3 
4.  Actions afte r notice and opportunity for hearing.   The Chief of the State Police  4 
Gambling Control Unit  shall notify the applicant , registrant  or licensee in writing, before 5 
a license or registration  is denied, suspended or revoked pursuant to subsection 3, 6 
paragraph B , of the intended denial or commencement date of the suspension or 7 
revocation, which may not be made any sooner than 96 hours after the licensee's or 8 
registrant's  receipt of the notice, of the duration of the suspension or revocation and of the 9 
right to a hearing pursuant to this subsection.  The applicant or, licensee , person 10 
registering or registrant  has the right to request a hearing before the Commissioner of 11 
Public Safety or the commissioner's designee.  Upon the applicant's or licensee's  request 12 
for a  hearing, the Commissioner of Public Safety shall provide a hearing.  The hearing 13 
must comply with the Maine Administrative Procedure Act.  The purpose of the hearing 14 
is to determine whether a preponderance of the evidence establishes that the applicant, 15 
person registering,  applicant's or registering person's  agent or employee or the licensee , 16 
registrant  or licensee's or registrant's  agent or employee violated a provision of this 17 
chapter or Title 17 -A, chapter 39.  A request for a hearing may not be made an y later than 18 
10 days after the applicant or, licensee , person registering or registrant  is notified of the 19 
proposed denial, suspension or revocation.  The suspension or revocation must be stayed 20 
pending the hearing; the hearing may not be held any later th an 30 days after the date the 21 
commissioner receives the request unless otherwise agreed by the parties or continued 22 
upon request of a party for cause shown.  23 
5.  Immediate suspension or revocation.   A licensee or registrant  whose license or 24 
registration  is immediately suspended or revoked by the Chief of the State Police  25 
Gambling Control Unit  pursuant to subsection 3, paragraph C must be notified in writing 26 
of the duration of the suspension or revocation and the licensee's or registrant's  right to 27 
request a hearing before the Commissioner of Public Safety or the commissioner's 28 
designee.  Upon the licensee's or registrant's  request for a hearing, the Commissioner of 29 
Public Safety shall provide a hearing.  The hearing must comply with the Maine 30 
Administrative P rocedure Act.  The purpose of the hearing is to determine whether a 31 
preponderance of the evidence establishes that the licensee or, the registrant,  the 32 
licensee's agent or employee or the registrant's agent or employee  violated section 1832, 33 
subsection 8, paragraph C; section 1841, subsection 2; or a provision of Title 17 -A, 34 
chapter 39.  A request for a hearing may not be made any later than 48 hours after the 35 
licensee or registrant  is notified of the suspension or revocation.  A hearing may not be 36 
held any  later than 10 days after the date the commissioner receives the request.  37 
6.  Access to premises.   A person, firm, corporation, association or organization 38 
making application or registration  to the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  39 
to conduct  or operate a game of chance  under this chapter  or any such person, firm, 40 
corporation, association or organization authorized under this chapter to conduct or 41 
operate a game of chance  shall permit inspection of any equipment, prizes, records or 42 
items and m aterials used or to be used in the conduct or operation of a game of chance  43 
under this chapter  by the Chief of the State Police or the chief's authorized representative  44 
Gambling Control Unit . 45

Sec. KKKKK -30.  17 MRSA §1843, as enacted by PL 2009, c. 487, Pt. A, §2, is 6 
amended to read:  7 
§1843.  Rules  8 
The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  may adopt routine technical 9 
rules pu rsuant to Title 5, chapter 375, subchapter 2 -A necessary for the administration 10 
and enforcement of this chapter and for the licensing , registration , conduct and operation 11 
of games of chance  governed by this chapter .  The Chief of the State Police  Gambling 12 
Control Unit  may regulate, supervise and exercise general control over the operation of 13 
such games. In establishing such rules, the Chief of the State Police must  Gambling 14 
Control Unit shall , in addition to the standards set forth in other provisions of th is 15 
chapter, set forth conduct, conditions and activity considered undesirable, including:  16 
1.  Fraud.  The practice of any fraud or deception upon a participant in a game of 17 
chance  governed by this chapter ; 18 
2.  Unsafe premises.  The conduct of a game of chanc e governed by this chapter  in or 19 
at premises that may be unsafe due to fire hazard or other such conditions;  20 
3.  Advertising and solicitation.  Advertising that is obscene or solicitation on a 21 
public way of persons to participate in a game of chance  governe d by this chapter ; 22 
4.  Organized crime.  Infiltration of organized crime into the operation of games of 23 
chance  governed by this chapter  or into the printing or distributing of gambling materials;  24 
5.  Disorderly persons.  Presence of disorderly persons in a l ocation where a game of 25 
chance  governed by this chapter  is being conducted;  26 
6.  Leasing of equipment.   Leasing of equipment by a licensee or registrant  used in 27 
the operation of games of chance  governed by this chapter  not in accordance with this 28 
chapter; a nd 29 
7.  Bona fide nonprofit organization.  The establishment of organizations that exist 30 
primarily to operate games of chance  governed by this chapter  and do not have a bona 31 
fide nonprofit charitable, educational, political, civic, recreational, fraternal, p atriotic, 32 
religious or public safety purpose.  33 
The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  shall provide a mechanism for 34 
individuals and businesses to request a determination from the State Police  Gambling 35 
Control Unit  as to whether a particular gam e, contest, scheme or device qualifies as a 36 
game of chance or a game of skill.  37

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §2306.  Exemptions; lotteries  1 
Any person, firm, corporation, association or organization licensed or registered  by 2 
the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  as provided in chapter 62 or 3 
authorized to conduct a raffle without a license  registering  as provided in section 1837  4 
1837 -A, is exempt from the application of this chapter insofar as the possession of raffle 5 
tickets, gambling apparatus and implements of gambling that are permitted within the 6 
scope of the license or licenses issued  registration , and all persons are exempt from this 7 
chapter insofar as gambling or posse ssion of raffle tickets is concerned, if the gambling 8 
and possession is in connection with a game of chance licensed as provided  operated  in 9 
accordance with  chapter 62 or a raffle conducted without a license  registration  as 10 
authorized by section 1837  1837 -A. 11 
Sec. KKKKK -32.  17-A MRSA §951, as amended by PL 2009, c. 487, Pt. B, 12 
§10, is further amended to read:  13 
§951.  Inapplicability of chapter  14 
Any person licensed or registered  by the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control 15 
Unit as provided in Title 17, ch apter 13 -A or chapter 62, or authorized to operate or 16 
conduct a raffle pursuant to Title 17, section 1837  1837 -A, is exempt from the application 17 
of the provisions of this chapter insofar as that person's conduct is within the scope of the 18 
license or regist ration . 19 
Sec. KKKKK -33.  Authority to administer and enforce, and make 20 
necessary technical changes to, existing games of chance rules and 21 
regulations.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law, games of chance rules that 22 
have been adopted by the Departmen t of Public Safety, Bureau of State Police pursuant to 23 
the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 17, chapter 62 may be administered and enforced by the 24 
Gambling Control Unit upon the effective date of this Act. To the extent necessary to 25 
make such rules consistent  with the intent of this Act, the Gambling Control Unit may 26 
make technical amendments to the rules and regulations without having to engage in 27 
rulemaking pursuant to the Maine Administrative Procedure Act.  28

7.  Other duties.  The performance of such other duties as are set forth in this and 32 
other sections of the statutes and as may be conferred or imposed from time to time by 33 
law.  The State Fire Mar shal, the State Fire Marshal's deputy and investigators appointed 34

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  PART MMMMM  1 
Sec. MMMMM -1.  25 MRSA §2450, first ¶, as amended by PL 2009, c. 364, 2 
§3, is further amended to read:  3 
The Commiss ioner of Public Safety shall adopt, in accordance with requirements of 4 
the Maine Administrative Procedure Act, a schedule of fees for the examination of all 5 
plans for construction, reconstruction or repairs submitted to the Department of Public 6 
Safety. The fee schedule for new construction or new use is 5¢ per square foot for 7 
occupied spaces and 2¢ per square foot for bulk storage occupancies, except that a fee for 8 
review of a plan for new construction by a public school may not exceed $450.  The fee 9 
schedu le for reconstruction, repairs or renovations is based on the cost of the project and 10 
may not exceed $450, except as provided in section 2450 -A.  The fee schedule for new 11 
construction, reconstruction, repairs or renovations is 1.5/10 of 1% of the cost to 12 
construct or reconstruct the portion of the project that is subject to State Fire Marshal 13 
review.   Except for projects reviewed by a municipality pursuant to section 2448 -A, the 14 
fees must be credited to a special revenue account to defray expenses in carryi ng out this 15 
section.  Any balance of the fees may not lapse, but must be carried forward as a 16 
continuing account to be expended for the same purpose in the following fiscal years.  17 
For projects reviewed by a municipality that include occupied spaces, a 1¢ fee per square 18 
foot must be remitted to the Department of Public Safety and a 4¢ fee per square foot 19 
must be paid to the municipality.  20

surplus by the end of fiscal year 2018 -19. 28

The commissioner may, with the approv al of the Governor, appoint a deputy 24 
commissioner, who is the chief of one of the department bureaus and shall perform the 25 
duties of the commissioner during the commissioner's absence, in addition to the deputy 26 
commissioner's regular duties.  The compensat ion and expense of the deputy 27

which the deputy commissioner is chief.   The commissioner may appoint and employ the 29

legislative affairs  to be under the commissioner's immediate supervision, direction and 31 
control, and to serve at the commissioner's pleasure and perform such duties as the 32 
commissioner may prescribe, except as otherwise pro vided by law.  In the absence of the 33 
commissioner, the commissioner, or the Governor if the commissioner is unable, may 34 
appoint one of the deputy commissioners to act on behalf of the commissioner.   In 35 
addition, the commissioner may appoint an associate co mmissioner for administrative 36 
services who is not subject to the Civil Service Law and who serves at the pleasure of the 37

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  Sec. QQQQQ -3.  Department of Administrative and Financial Services; 1 
Bureau of General Services; reorganization.  The Comm issioner of Administrative 2 
and Financial Services shall review those provisions of the Maine Revised Statutes 3 
governing the Bureau of General Services and, based upon that review, develop and 4 
submit a bill for introduction to the Second Regular Session of the 128th Legislature that 5 
reorganizes in statute the functions and activities of the Bureau of General Services and 6 
proposes any necessary budgetary changes.  Prior to submitting a bill, the commissioner 7 
may organize the activities and functions of the Bu reau of General Services in a manner 8 
the commissioner determines is most effective and efficient.  9

PART SSSSS  16 
Sec. SSSSS -1.  34-A MRSA §1406 is enacted to read:  17 
§1406.  Authority to review financial records of counties as those records relate to 18 
corrections  19 
1.  County jail records.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the contrary, 20 
the commissioner may inspect, review and take custody of records of the counties as 21 
those records relate to the funding and operation of the county jails.  Upon the request of 22 
the commissioner, a county jail within 15 days of the request shall supply complete and 23 
accurate information.  The commissioner shall work with the jails to assist them in 24 
achieving compliance with the requirements  of this subsection.  The commissioner shall 25 
enforce the standards of this subsection by imposition of monetary penalties pursuant to 26 
policies and procedures under section 1208 -B, subsection 1, paragraph B.  This 27 
subsection must be liberally construed to e ffect the purpose of this section.  28 
2.  Violation.  A state government agency or local government entity whose officer 29 
or employee violates subsection 1 commits a civil violation for which a fine of not more 30 
than $5,000 may be adjudged.  31 
3.  Appeal.  If the commissioner is aggrieved by a refusal or denial to inspect or copy 32 
a record or a failure to allow the inspection or copying of a record under this section, the 33 
commissioner may appeal the refusal, denial or failure within 30 calendar days of the 34 
receipt o f the written notice of refusal, denial or failure to the Superior Court for the 35 
county where the person refusing, failing or denying the inspection or copying resides or 36 
the agency employing that person has its principal office.  The agency or official sh all file 37 
a statement of position explaining the basis for denial within 14 calendar days of service 38 
of the appeal.  If a court, after a review, and taking of testimony and other evidence as 39 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 803 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  determined necessary, determines the refusal, denial or failure wa s not for just and proper 1 
cause, the court shall enter an order for disclosure.  Appeals may be advanced on the 2 
docket and receive priority over other cases when the court determines that the interests 3 
of justice so require.  4 
4.  Proceedings not exclusive.  The proceedings authorized by this section are not 5 
exclusive of any other civil remedy provided by law.  6 
5.  Attorney's fees.   In an appeal under subsection 3 or another civil proceeding, the 7 
court may award reasonable attorney's fees and litigation expen ses to the substantially 8 
prevailing plaintiff who appealed pursuant to subsection 3 or in another civil proceeding 9 
if the court determines that the illegal action was committed in bad faith.  Attorney's fees 10 
and litigation costs may not be awarded to or ag ainst a federally recognized Indian tribe.  11 
6.  Subpoena power.  The commissioner may, in connection with the performance of 12 
the commissioner's duties, apply to the Superior Court for a subpoena to compel the 13 
attendance of witnesses and the production of bo oks, papers, records and documents of 14 
individuals, firms, associations and corporations and all officers, boards, commissions 15 
and departments of county government.  The court, before issuing the subpoena, shall 16 
provide adequate opportunity for the commissi oner and the party against whom the 17 
subpoena is requested to be heard.  The court may issue the subpoena only on a showing 18 
by the commissioner and specific findings of fact by the court that the attendance of the 19 
witness or the production of the books, pap ers, records or documents is reasonably 20 
necessary to carry out specific duties of the commissioner that are related to the 21 
operations and finances of the county jails and that the commissioner has made 22 
reasonable efforts to secure the attendance or the boo ks, papers, records or documents 23 
without recourse to compulsory process.  24 
Sec. SSSSS -2.  Report.  By February 15, 2018, the Department of Corrections 25 
shall submit a report to the Joint Standing Committee on Appropriations and Financial 26 
Affairs on plans to r estructure the funding and operation of county jails and correctional 27 
facilities and prisoner population and capacity.  28

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  5.  Eligible costs.  "Eligible costs" means the actual and direct expenses incurred in 1

A.  Eligible costs for a planning gran t include the expense of:  5 
(1)  Studies to examine alternative methods of achieving collaboration, including 6 
those adopted by other municipalities;  7 
(2)  Cost -benefit studies; and  8 
(3)  Facilitation of community meetings and public outreach and education.  9 
B.  Eligible costs for a cooperative services grant includes  include  the expense of:  10 
(1)  Execution and implementation of an interlocal agreement under chapter 115, 11 
a tax base sharing arrangement or another regional government mechanism for 12 
achieving collabor ation;  13 
(2)  Joint strategic planning or comprehensive or capital investment planning;  14 
(3)  Public outreach and education;  15 
(4)  Collaboration or consolidation of offices or services;  16

(6)  Administrative services and costs, such as photocopying, printing, telephone 19 
service and travel costs.  20 
C.  Eligible costs for a capital grant include the expense of:  21 
(1)  Site, facility, infrastructure or utility s ystem acquisition;  22 
(2)  Repair, rehabilitation or renovation of existing facilities;  23 
(3)  New construction or expansion of existing facilities; and  24 
(4)  Purchase of major equipment or systems.  25

by a municipality, county or regional government subdivision are not eligible costs.  27

§6205.  Eligibility; intergovernmental cooperation  30 
In accorda nce with the request for proposals issued by the department under section 31 
6209, an eligible applicant may apply for a planning grant , a capital grant  or a 32 
cooperative services grant from the fund.  In order to be eligible for a planning grant , a 33 
capital gr ant or a cooperative services grant, an eligible applicant must demonstrate in its 34 
application that the project for which it seeks a grant will be undertaken in cooperation 35 
with one or more municipalities, counties or regional government subdivisions.  36

CHAPTER 123  39 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 808 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  SCHOOL MANAGEMENT AN D LEADERSHIP CENTERS  1 
§3801.  General provisions  2 
1.  Definitions.  As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise indicates, the 3 
following terms have the following meanings.  4 
A.  "Municipality" means a city, town or organized plantation.  5 
B.  "School management and leadership center" means a multiservice agency 6 
establ ished and operated exclusively for the purposes of developing, managing and 7 
providing services or programs to 2 or more members pursuant to section 3802, 8 
subsection 2 and may include associate members pursuant to section 3802, subsection 9 
3.  A "school mana gement and leadership center" is a political subdivision pursuant 10 
to section 3802, subsection 7.  11 
2.  Establishment.  A school administrative unit as described in section 3802, 12 
subsection 2 may become a member of a school management and leadership center 13 
through an interlocal agreement pursuant to Title 30 -A, chapter 115 and the agreement 14 
may include associate members as described in section 3802, subsection 3.  15 
3.  Interlocal agreement.  An interlocal agreement establishing a school 16 
management and leadership  center must include the structure and governance of the 17 
school management and leadership center and its functions, programs and services.  18 
A.  An interlocal agreement must include the specifications required pursuant to Title 19 
30-A, section 2203, subsection  2 and a description of:  20 
(1)  The school management and leadership center board composition, election or 21 
appointment of officers, board member terms and method of voting;  22 
(2)  An approval process for a new school administrative unit to join the school 23 
mana gement and leadership center;  24 
(3)  An approval process for an existing member to transfer to another school 25 
management and leadership center;  26 
(4)  The process for determining the sharing of costs for and the assessments of 27 
or payments to the school managem ent and leadership center;  28 
(5)  The budget process that requires a school management and leadership center 29 
budget be adopted by a date established in order to meet local school 30 
administrative unit budget deadlines.  The budget process must include a 31 
contin gency plan for a budget failure and must be in the cost center summary 32 
budget format pursuant to section 1485;  33 
(6)  The process for a balanced budget as required by section 3802, subsection 10 34 
and the method of determining the return of any excess funds to  the members of 35 
the school management and leadership center; and  36 
(7)  The process for the disposition of indebtedness and property including by 37 
sale or lease, transferred to or from or administered by the school management 38 
and leadership center.  39 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 809 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  B.  An int erlocal agreement may include but is not limited to a description of the 1 
following:  2 
(1)  The approval process for the formation of a school management and 3 
leadership center;  4 
(2)  Any associate members, the process for including associate members and 5 
their roles in the school management and leadership center;  6 
(3)  The process to authorize the school management and leadership center to 7 
borrow funds for school construction purposes including bonds and notes;  8 
(4)  The process to approve the purchase or lease of  buildings or land by the 9 
school management and leadership center;  10 
(5)  The process by which a school management and leadership center may 11 
establish, maintain and expend funds from a reserve fund or contingency fund;  12 
(6)  The process of hiring an executive  director for the school management and 13 
leadership center; and  14 
(7)  A transition plan to move authorized programs and services from a member 15 
to the school management and leadership center.  16 
An interlocal agreement cannot transfer a school administrative uni t's responsibility for 17 
providing the opportunity of a free public education to each of its students or a free, 18 
appropriate education to each of its students with a disability as required by this Title or 19 
by federal law.  20 
4.  Duties of school management and leadership center.  A school management 21 
and leadership center's functions, programs and services may include but are not limited 22 
to the following:  23 
A.  Accounting, payroll and financial management services and procurement;  24 
B.  Transportation, transportation  routing and vehicle maintenance;  25 
C.  Reporting functions;  26 
D.  Special education programs and administration;  27 
E.  Gifted and talented programs and administration;  28 
F.  Alternative education programs and administration;  29 
G.  Substitute teachers and staff augm entation;  30 
H.  Technology and technology support;  31 
I.  Food service planning and purchasing;  32 
J.  Energy management and facilities maintenance;  33 
K.  Regional school leadership academies;  34 
L.  Staff training and professional development;  35 
M.  Shared educational p rograms or staff;  36 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 810 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  N.  Shared support service programs;  1 
O.  Educational programs such as summer school, extended school year, tutoring, 2 
advanced placement and other programs that serve students and improve student 3 
achievement;  4 
P.  Shared extracurricular or cocurricular programs; and  5 
Q.  Superintendent services.  6 
§3802.  School management and leadership center authorized  7 
A school management and leadership center shall provide administrative and 8 
education functions in accordance with this chapter and shall func tion as an extension of 9 
the member school administrative units and associate members of the school management 10 
and leadership center.  A member school administrative unit of the school management 11 
and leadership center cannot transfer the responsibility for providing the opportunity of a 12 
free public education to each of its students or a free, appropriate education to each of its 13 
students with a disability as required by this Title or by federal law.  14 
1.  Geographic boundaries.  The commissioner shall determin e 9 to 12 geographic 15 
areas for the establishment of each school management and leadership center.  16 
Membership in a particular school management and leadership center does not require the 17 
member to be physically located in the school management and leadersh ip center's 18 
geographic boundary.  19 
2.  Members.  Members in a school management and leadership center must be 20 
determined by interlocal agreement pursuant to Title 30 -A, chapter 115 and may include 21 
the following types of school administrative units:  22 
A.  Commu nity school districts pursuant to chapter 105;  23 
B.  Municipal school units pursuant to chapter 111;  24 
C.  Regional school units pursuant to chapter 103 -A; 25 
D.  School administrative districts pursuant to chapter 103; and  26 
E.  Schools established on tribal lands  pursuant to Title 30, chapter 601.  27 
3.  Associate members.  Associate members for a school management and leadership 28 
center may include the following through a contractual agreement or memorandum of 29 
understanding with the members of the school management a nd leadership center:  30 
A.  Career and technical education regions pursuant to chapter 313, subchapter 4;  31 
B.  Public charter schools as defined in chapter 112;  32 
C.  Providers of child development services pursuant to chapter 303;  33 
D.  Magnet schools pursuant t o chapters 312 and 312 -A; 34 
E.  The Maine Educational Center for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing and the 35 
Governor Baxter School for the Deaf pursuant to chapter 304;  36 
F.  Providers of education in the unorganized territory pursuant to chapter 119; or  37 
G.  Municip alities and counties pursuant to Title 30 -A. 38 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 811 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  4.  Provision of services to or from other public entities or nonprofit entities.   A 1 
school management and leadership center may provide services to or purchase services 2 
from other types of political subdivision s, public entities or nonprofit organizations or 3 
associations.  4 
5.  Purchase of services from another school management and leadership center.  5 
A member of a school management and leadership center may purchase services from 6 
another school management and le adership center if not provided by the member’s school 7 
management and leadership center.  8 
6.  Validation.  A school management and leadership center authorized and 9 
organized under this chapter is validated, confirmed, approved and declared legal in all 10 
respects, notwithstanding any defect or irregularity that may have occurred in the 11 
organization of the school management and leadership center or in the selection of the 12 
board of that school management and leadership center.  13 
7.  Political subdivision.  A schoo l management and leadership center is a political 14 
subdivision within the meaning of Title 5, section 19002, subsection 6 and a quasi - 15 
municipal corporation within the meaning of Title 30 -A, section 5701, and all the 16 
provisions of those sections apply to it.  Notwithstanding Title 30 -A, section 2203, 17 
subsection 8, paragraph B, the members of a school management and leadership center 18 
may delegate eminent domain power to the school management and leadership center by 19 
agreement. A school management and leadership  center is considered a tax -exempt 20 
governmental entity for the purposes of Title 36, section 1760, subsection 2.  21 
8.  Executive director.  A school management and leadership center shall employ an 22 
executive director, and the interlocal agreement under secti on 3801, subsection 3 must 23 
specify that the executive director shall administer, in compliance with this chapter, the 24 
provisions of the interlocal agreement in the school management and leadership center.  25 
9.  Personnel.  The executive director of a school management and leadership center 26 
may employ a chief financial officer and may employ additional staff necessary to 27 
administer the functions assigned to the school management and leadership center 28 
through the provisions of the interlocal agreement under sec tion 3801, subsection 3.  29 
10.  Balanced budget.  A school management and leadership center must have a 30 
balanced budget and return excess funds to the members as prescribed by the interlocal 31 
agreement under section 3801, subsection 3.  32 
11.  Authority to borro w, expend and accept funds.  A school management and 33 
leadership center may:  34 
A.  Borrow funds in anticipation of a member’s payment of its share of the school 35 
management and leadership center budget. Such borrowing:  36 
(1)  Must be repaid within one year; and  37 
(2)  May not at any time exceed 3/4 of the school management and leadership 38 
center's annual approved budget;  39 
B.  Expend available funds to pay debt service, security and maintenance costs; and  40 
C.  Accept and expend funds from state, federal and other sourc es and expend those 41 
funds on behalf of the members.  42 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 812 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  12.  Bonding authority.  A school management and leadership center may issue 1 
bonds and notes for school construction purposes. For purposes of this section, "school 2 
construction purposes" includes minor c apital costs relating to maintenance of a school's 3 
physical plant. The school management and leadership center board shall decide whether 4 
the issuance of bonds or notes by the school management and leadership center for school 5 
construction purposes is nece ssary. The board shall determine whether the issuance of 6 
bonds or notes is authorized, and, if so, the board shall issue the bonds or notes and 7 
administer the proceeds of, and the payment of principal of and interest on, those bonds 8 
or notes after issuance . A school management and leadership center may issue bonds and 9 
notes for school construction purposes only under the provisions of the interlocal 10 
agreement under section 3801, subsection 3.  11 
13.  Withdrawal from school management and leadership center.  If a single 12 
school administrative unit applies to withdraw, it must demonstrate to the commissioner 13 
that as a result of the school administrative unit's withdrawing that there will be no 14 
increase in costs or decrease in student programs and services for the withdrawing school 15 
administrative unit and for any of the remaining member school administrative units of 16 
the school management and leadership center.  17 
14.  Dissolution of school management and leadership center.  A school 18 
management and leadership center m ay not be dissolved unless it applies to the 19 
commissioner for approval and:  20 
A.  All member school administrative units apply to transfer to another school 21 
management and leadership center; or  22 
B.  If all the member school administrative units of a school ma nagement and 23 
leadership center apply to dissolve the school management and leadership center, 24 
they demonstrate to the commissioner that there will be no increase in costs or 25 
decrease in student programs and services for any of the member school 26 
administrat ive units of the school management and leadership center.  27 
15.  Reporting requirements.  A school management and leadership center must 28 
meet state and federal reporting requirements on behalf of each member school 29 
administrative unit.  30 
§3803.  Oversight  31 
The commissioner shall provide oversight of the school management and leadership 32 
centers, and this oversight must include the following.  33 
1.  Data collection; monitoring.  The commissioner or the commissioner's designee 34 
is responsible for collecting, analyzing and reporting data from school management and 35 
leadership centers. The commissioner or the commissioner's designee shall monitor the 36 
performance and legal compliance of the school management and leadership centers, 37 
including collecting and analyzing data to  support ongoing evaluation of the school 38 
management and leadership centers.  39 
2.  Notification of unsatisfactory performance or compliance.  If a school 40 
management and leadership center’s performance or legal compliance appears 41 
unsatisfactory, the commissio ner shall promptly provide written notice to the school 42 
management and leadership center and its members of perceived problems and provide 43 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 813 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  reasonable opportunity for the school management and leadership center to remedy the 1 
problems.  The school management  and leadership center shall provide the commissioner 2 
a corrective action plan to remedy the problems.  3 
§3804.  Audit  4 
A school management and leadership center shall adhere to generally accepted 5 
accounting principles and shall annually engage an external au ditor to do an independent 6 
audit of the school management and leadership center's finances. The school management 7 
and leadership center shall submit the audit to its members and to the department. The 8 
audit must be conducted in the same manner as a school administrative unit audit in 9 
accordance with chapter 221, subchapter 2.  10 
§3805.  Application for and approval of a school management and leadership center  11 
1.  Application.  The commissioner shall establish an application process under this 12 
chapter for the f ormation of a school management and leadership center.  The application 13 
must be in a form and contain such information as required by the commissioner, 14 
including, but not limited to:  15 
A.  The identification of the school administrative units that are applyi ng to form the 16 
school management and leadership center;  17 
B.  The specified structure and governance of the school management and leadership 18 
center and its purposes, functions, programs and services;  19 
C.  How any savings resulting from the formation of the sc hool management and 20 
leadership center will be used; and  21 
D.  A copy of the proposed interlocal agreement pursuant to section 3801, subsection 22 
3. 23 
2.  Commissioner’s approval.  If an application under this section contains the 24 
information required pursuant to  subsection 1, the commissioner shall notify each school 25 
administrative unit participating in the school management and leadership center that, 26 
pending voter approval as set forth in subsection 3, the school management and 27 
leadership center is approved pur suant to this chapter. The commissioner shall keep a 28 
register of school management and leadership centers that have been approved pursuant 29 
to this chapter.  30 
3.  Voter approval.  If the commissioner approves an application for a school 31 
management and leaders hip center pursuant to subsection 2, the school management and 32 
leadership center must receive voter approval using the process specified in the interlocal 33 
agreement pursuant to section 3801, subsection 3, paragraph B, subparagraph (1).  34 
§3806.  Direct state  funding of a school management and leadership center  35 
A school management and leadership center receives direct state funds for start -up 36 
costs in accordance with section 15689, subsection 9.  A school management and 37 
leadership center that provides to membe rs at least 2 different services covering a total of 38 
at least 2 different categories as specified in section 15683 -C, subsection 2 must receive 39 
annual support for 55% of the executive director’s salary and benefits, an accounting and 40 
payroll system and a s tudent information system.  41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 814 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  The school administrative units that are members of a school management and 1 
leadership center must receive state funds in accordance with section 15683 -C. 2 
§3807.  Regional school leadership academies  3 
A regional school leadership academy is a professional development consortium that 4 
combines state and local programs and resources, including the preparation, licensure, 5 
certification, professional development and training for educational leadership, into a 6 
coherent system that can si gnificantly improve the recruitment and preparation of 7 
prospective candidates for school principals and other school leadership positions, as well 8 
as the induction, mentoring and retention of principals and school leaders during the first 9 
2 years of employ ment in their school leadership positions.  The mission of an academy 10 
may be to enhance the quality of the preservice and in -service staff training programs for 11 
school principals and other school leadership positions, to improve the distribution, 12 
supply an d quality of school leadership personnel in underserved school administrative 13 
units in the State and to develop appropriate professional development pathways at 14 
participating schools in the academy.  To fulfill its mission, the academy may work in 15 
coordina tion with educational leadership mentors and coaches, with high -performing 16 
educational leaders and with educator preparation programs and statewide education 17 
associations.  18 
Sec. VVVVV -7.  20-A MRSA §5205, sub -§6-B is enacted to read:  19 
6-B.  School management  and leadership center enrollment policies.  Members in 20 
a school management and leadership center, as defined in section 3801, subsection 1, 21 
paragraph B, may adopt a mutual policy allowing the transfer of students, with parental 22 
approval, among the member school administrative units. The mutual policy must set 23 
forth procedures and standards governing the transfers, including but not limited to the 24 
school year or years in which the policy applies, application procedures and standards of 25 
responsibility for tr ansportation and special education. Each member school board that 26 
adopts the mutual policy under this subsection shall post a copy of the mutual policy on 27 
the school administrative unit’s publicly accessible website and shall provide timely 28 
notice of the p olicy to residents of the school administrative unit governed by that school 29 
board. For the purposes of chapter 606 -B, a student transferred under this subsection is 30 
considered a resident of the school administrative unit to which the student transferred.  31

(2)  Temporary and interim instructional space.  Temporary space is instructional 8 
space consisting of one or mor e mobile or modular buildings that are portable, 9 
that are constructed on - or off -site and that can be disassembled and moved 10 
economically to a new location.  Interim instructional space is fixed instructional 11 
space that a school administrative unit rents f or a defined period of time and then 12 
vacates at the end of the lease.  13

space may lease temporary or interim space, with state support, for a 15 
maximum of 5 years.  A school administr ative unit may appeal to the 16 
commissioner if this limitation presents an undue burden.  When making a 17 
determination on a school administrative unit's request for relief based on 18 
undue burden, the commissioner may consider, but is not limited to 19 
considering , the following:  20 
(i)  Fiscal capacity;  21 
(ii)  Enrollment demographics; and  22 
(iii)  Unforeseen circumstances not within the control of the appealing 23 
school administrative unit.  24 
An extension granted by the commissioner beyond the 5 -year maximum for 25 
state suppo rt is limited to a period of one year.  Any additional request for 26 
extensions must be submitted and reviewed on an annual basis.  The 27 
commissioner's decision is final.  28 
(b)  A school administrative unit with state -approved need for instructional 29 
space may e ngage in a lease -purchase agreement for temporary or interim 30 
instructional space with state support for a maximum of 5 years; and 31 
(3)  Permanent small instructional space that replaces existing approved leased 32 
temporary or interim instructional space.  Per manent small instructional space 33 
consists of new buildings or additions to existing buildings that are secured to a 34 
permanent foundation.  Once an existing leased temporary or interim 35 
instructional space has been replaced by a permanent small instructional  space 36 
through an approved financing agreement, that space is eligible for state support 37 
for a maximum of 10 years .; and  38 
(4)  Regional programs and services space. A school administrative unit engaged 39 
in a state -approved lease -purchase agreement for region al programs and services 40

Sec. VVVVV -10.  20-A MRSA §15683 -C is enacted to read:  6 
§15683 -C.  School management and leadership center members; calculation of 7 
school managemen t and leadership center administration allocation and 8 
state contribution  9 
Beginning with fiscal year 2018 -19, this section applies to school administrative units 10 
that are members of school management and leadership centers pursuant to chapter 123.  11 
1.  Calcu lation of school management and leadership center per -pupil rate.  The 12 
commissioner shall calculate a per -pupil amount for school management and leadership 13 
center administration.  The per -pupil amount for school management and leadership 14 
center administrat ion is based on the actual General Fund expenditures for school 15 
administrative units with 2,500 students or more for the functions of school boards, 16 
elections and central offices, as defined in the State's accounting handbook for local 17 
school systems for t he most recent year available, excluding expenditures for 18 
administrative technology -related software and less miscellaneous revenues from other 19 
local governments, divided by the average of October and April enrollment counts for 20 
that fiscal year and adjust ed by appropriate trends in the Consumer Price Index or other 21 
comparable index.  22 
2.  Categories of services of school management and leadership center.  The 23 
following are the categories of services that a school administrative unit that is a member 24 
of a sch ool management and leadership center pursuant to chapter 123 may purchase for 25 
funding purposes under section 3806.  26 
A.  Category 1, instructional services, includes the following services:  27 
(1)  Special education programs and administration;  28 
(2)  Gifted and talented programs and administration;  29 
(3)  Alternative education programs and administration;  30 
(4)  Shared educational programs or staff; and  31 
(5)  Educational programs such as summer school, extended school year, 32 
tutoring, advanced placement and other progr ams that serve students and improve 33 
student achievement.  34 
B.  Category 2, education support services, includes the following services:  35 
(1)  Substitute teachers and staff augmentation;  36 
(2)  Technology and technology support;  37 
(3)  Staff training and professio nal development;  38 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 817 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  (4)  Regional school leadership academies;  1 
(5)  Shared support services programs; and  2 
(6)  Shared extracurricular or cocurricular programs.  3 
C.  Category 3, central office services, includes the following services:  4 
(1)  Accounting, payroll,  financial management services and procurement;  5 
(2)  Reporting functions;  6 
(3)  Food service planning and purchasing; and  7 
(4)  Superintendent services.  8 
D.  Category 4, facilities and transportation system services, includes the following 9 
services:  10 
(1)  Tran sportation, transportation routing and vehicle maintenance; and  11 
(2)  Energy management and facilities maintenance.  12 
3.  Eligibility for school management and leadership center allocation.  The 13 
commissioner shall determine that a school administrative unit i s eligible for a school 14 
management and leadership center allocation if according to its school management and 15 
leadership center interlocal agreement pursuant to section 3801, subsection 3, the school 16 
administrative unit purchases at least 2 different servi ces covering a total of at least 2 17 
different categories from the school management and leadership center as specified in 18 
subsection 2.  19 
4.  Total allocation and state contribution.  The commissioner shall determine an 20 
eligible school administrative unit's t otal school management and leadership center 21 
allocation under subsection 3 as the school management and leadership center per -pupil 22 
rate in subsection 1 multiplied by the school administrative unit's subsidizable pupil count 23 
for October 1st of the most rec ent calendar year prior to the year of funding.  The state 24 
contribution for each school administrative unit's school management and leadership 25 
center allocation is the allocation multiplied by the school administrative unit's state share 26 
percentage pursuan t to section 15672, subsection 31, not to exceed 70% and not less than 27 
30%.  28

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  12.  Secondary student open enrollment period.  Each April 1st to May 1st is an 1 
annual open enrollment period for a secondary student to request a transfer pursuant to 2 
subsection 6 to a public high school in another schoo l administrative unit in the next 3 
school year.  During the open enrollment period, the student’s resident school 4 
administrative unit may not deny the transfer.  A school administrative unit shall inform 5 
parents of secondary students of the open enrollment period no later than March 1st of 6 
each year.  For the purposes of chapter 606 -B, a student transferred under this subsection 7 
is considered a resident of the school administrative unit to which the student transferred.  8 
PART ZZZZZ  9 
Sec. ZZZZZ -1.  20-A MRSA §7 303 is enacted to read:  10 
§7303.  Education savings accounts  11 
The department shall, in accordance with this section, establish education savings 12 
accounts, referred to in this section as "savings accounts," for children with disabilities.  13 
Savings accounts may  be used by the parents or legal guardians of such children for 14 
educational purposes in accordance with this section.  15 
1.  Establish savings accounts.   The department by rule shall establish an application 16 
process for a parent or legal guardian of a child w ith disabilities to request the 17 
establishment of a savings account.  An application requesting establishment of a savings 18 
account must be submitted to the department no later than January 1st preceding the 19 
school year in which the account will be used.  Th e department may establish a savings 20 
account only upon a demonstration by the parent or legal guardian that the child has been 21 
enrolled in a public school for at least one school year and that an individualized 22 
education program has been determined for the  child and only if the parent or legal 23 
guardian signs an agreement with the department pursuant to subsection 2.  The 24 
establishment of savings accounts must be limited to no more than 100 students.  25 
2.  Written agreement.  The department and the parent or l egal guardian of a child 26 
for whom a savings account will be established must sign an agreement that the parent or 27 
legal guardian will not enroll the child in a public school or charter school for the school 28 
year in which the education savings account is es tablished and that the parent or legal 29 
guardian will use a portion of the education savings account funds allocated annually to 30 
provide an education for the child in a manner consistent with the system of learning 31 
results established in section 6209.  32 
3.  Renewal, rollover and closure.   The department may annually renew a savings 33 
account and deposit funds into the account in accordance with subsection 5 if, in 34 
accordance with rules adopted by the department, the parent or legal guardian 35 
demonstrates that the  child continues to have and follow an individualized education 36 
program and has completed a national norm -referenced achievement test and has had a 37 
review and acceptance of the child's progress by an identified individual who holds a 38 
current teacher's cert ificate from the State.  Unspent funds in a savings account that is 39 
renewed remain in the savings account and may be used in accordance with subsection 5, 40 
except that no more than 75% of the funds deposited in any year may be carried forward.  41 
Any unspent amount that is in excess of 75% of the funds deposited in that year must be 42 
transferred at the end of the fiscal year to the State Controller for handling in accordance 43 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 820 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  with subsection 6.  If the requirements of this subsection are not met, the department shall 1 
close the savings account and transfer all funds in the savings account to the State 2 
Controller, who shall handle the funds as provided in subsection 6.  3 
4.  Maintenance of fund for postsecondary education.  After a child for whom a 4 
savings account ha s been created graduates from high school, no further funds may be 5 
deposited in the account, but to the extent there are funds remaining in the account, the 6 
fund, at the request of the child or the parent or legal guardian of the child, must, in 7 
accordance  with rules adopted by the department, remain open and available to help fund 8 
a postsecondary course of education for the child.  If the child does not enroll in such a 9 
course within 4 years after graduating from high school, the department shall close the  10 
savings account and transfer all funds in the savings account to the State Controller, who 11 
shall handle the funds as provided in subsection 6.  12 
5.  Funding and oversight.   The department shall administer and oversee savings 13 
accounts as follows.  14 
A.  Each ye ar the department shall deposit into each active savings account 90% of 15 
the state subsidy that is attributable to the child for whom the savings account is 16 
established and that would otherwise have been provided to the child's school 17 
administrative unit un der chapter 606 -B.  The department shall also direct that school 18 
administrative unit to deposit into the savings account 90% of the school 19 
administrative unit's required contribution to the unit's total cost of education 20 
attributable to that child.  The de partment shall calculate these amounts and shall 21 
allocate the state funds to the extent possible in a manner consistent with the 22 
schedules applicable to state subsidy payments pursuant to section 15689 -B. 23 
B.  The department and the State Controller may eac h separately receive up to 1/5 of 24 
that 10% of the state subsidy attributable to a child for whom a savings account is 25 
established that is not deposited in the savings account.  Funds received under this 26 
paragraph may be used to pay the costs of administeri ng this section.  27 
C.  The parent or legal guardian of a child may expend funds in a savings account 28 
only through the use of a debit card and may use funds in the account to pay for only 29 
the following educational expenses:  30 
(1)  Tuition and fees at a private primary or secondary school;  31 
(2)  Textbooks;  32 
(3)  Educational therapies;  33 
(4)  Tutoring by a certified teacher or education technician II or III;  34 
(5)  Online classes;  35 
(6)  Test fees;  36 
(7)  Services provided by a public school, including access to or enrollme nt in 37 
extracurricular activities or individual classes;  38 
(8)  Reimbursement of fees for transportation related to the child's education, for 39 
which receipts must be provided to the department, up to $500 in any one year;  40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 821 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  (9)  Consumable materials relating to  educational activities, up to $100 in any 1 
one year; and  2 
(10)  Tuition and fees at a university or vocational school recognized by the 3 
department in accordance with rules adopted by the department or accredited by a 4 
regional accrediting agency approved or recognized by the United States 5 
Department of Education.  6 
A parent or legal guardian of a child may not use funds in a savings account to pay in 7 
cash for any educational expense under this paragraph.  8 
D.  On a quarterly basis the department shall review all expenditures from savings 9 
accounts to ensure that they are in accordance with the requirements of this 10 
subsection and rules adopted under this section.  If at any time the department finds 11 
that expenditures from a savings account are not in accordance with  the requirements 12 
of this subsection or rules adopted under this section, the department shall notify the 13 
parent or legal guardian of the child of the apparent misuse of funds and shall freeze 14 
the account so that no further expenditures may be made.  If, a fter an opportunity for 15 
hearing, the department determines that there was no misuse of funds, it shall 16 
unfreeze the account.  If the department determined there was in fact a misuse of 17 
funds, the department shall direct the parent or legal guardian to repa y within 30 days 18 
to the State the amount of misused funds.  All repaid funds must be transferred to the 19 
State Controller for handling in accordance with subsection 6.  If the parent or legal 20 
guardian does not repay the full amount of misused funds or file an appeal of the 21 
department’s decision within the 30 days, the department shall close the savings 22 
account and transfer all funds in the savings account to the State Controller for 23 
handling in accordance with subsection 6.  A decision by the department unde r this 24 
paragraph is a final agency action that may be appealed to the Superior Court by a 25 
parent or legal guardian within 30 days of the decision in accordance with the Maine 26 
Rules of Civil Procedure, Rule 80C.  27 
6.  Funds returned.  Any funds transferred ou t of or removed from a savings account 28 
or paid to the State by the parent or legal guardian of a child under this section and 29 
received by the State Controller must be handled by the State Controller in accordance 30 
with this subsection.  The State Controller  shall divide the funds in the same proportion as 31 
the funds are deposited in the savings account from the State and the school 32 
administrative unit pursuant to subsection 5 and return the portion attributable to the 33 
school administrative unit to that unit a nd transfer the remainder to the unappropriated 34 
surplus of the General Fund.  35 
7.  Rules.   The department shall adopt rules necessary to implement this section.  36 
Rules adopted pursuant to this subsection are routine technical rules as defined in Title 5, 37 
chapter 375, subchapter 2 -A. 38

applic able. 35

Sec. BBBBBB -7.  20-A MRSA §8305 -A, sub -§2, as corrected by RR 2003, c. 2, 31

2.  Admission standards.   A region, center or satellite program shall determine, in 33 
accordance with its published admission standards, whether to admit a person to such a 34 
region, center or satellite program.  Unless otherwise specifically provided for in this 35 
chapter, priority to enroll in any career and technical education course of study offered by 36
