Sec. DDDDDD -5.  26 MRSA §965, sub -§1-A is enacted to read:  11 
1-A.  Public education employees negotiation.  This subsection governs the 12 
negotiation of standard salary and standard benefits for publi c education employees.  13 
A.  Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, solely for the negotiation of 14 
standard salary and standard benefits for public education employees, the State is 15 
considered the public employer and subject to all limitations a nd responsibilities 16 
provided in this chapter. It is the obligation of the State and the bargaining agent 17 
representing public education employees across the State to bargain collectively for 18 
standard salary and standard benefits for public education employe es in accordance 19 
with this subsection.  For the purposes of this subsection, "collective bargaining" 20 
means the mutual obligation of the State and the bargaining agent representing public 21 
education employees:  22 
(1)  To meet at reasonable times;  23 
(2)  To meet within 10 days after receipt of written notice from the other party 24 
requesting a meeting for collective bargaining purposes, as long as the parties 25 
have not otherwise agreed in a prior written contract;  26 
(3)  To execute in writing any agreements arrived at.   The term of any such 27 
agreement is subject to negotiation but may not exceed 2 years;  28 
(4)  To participate in good faith in the mediation, fact -finding and arbitration 29 
procedures required by this section; and  30 
(5)  To confer and negotiate in good faith with  respect to salary and benefits.  31 
B.  Any cost item related to this subsection is the financial responsibility of the State.  32 
The cost item must be based upon student -staff ratios as established under Title 20 -A, 33 
chapter 606 -B. 34 
A cost item related to this s ubsection must be submitted for inclusion in the 35 
Governor's next operating budget within 10 days after the date on which the 36 
agreement is ratified by the parties.  If the Legislature rejects any of the cost items 37 
related to this subsection submitted to the  Legislature, all cost items related to this 38 
subsection must be returned to the parties for further bargaining.  39 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 828 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  For purposes of this paragraph, "cost item" means any benefit acquired through 1 
collective bargaining the implementation of which requires an app ropriation by the 2 
Legislature.  3 
C.  The organization representing the majority of public education employees is the 4 
bargaining agent to represent public education employees for the collective 5 
bargaining purposes of this subsection between the State and the organization.  The 6 
organization must provide to the State a demonstration of majority support of public 7 
education employees.  8 
D.  Aside from the negotiation of standard salary and standard benefits under this 9 
subsection, a public education employee remains the employee of the public 10 
employer.  11 
E.  All matters not specified in this subsection appropriate to collective bargaining 12 
must be negotiated pursuant to subsection 1 by the public employer and the 13 
bargaining agent determined under section 966.  14 
F.  This su bsection applies only to public education employees who are employed by 15 
a school administrative unit that:  16 
(1)  After approval of the school board, notifies the Commissioner of Education 17 
that the school administrative unit will participate in collective ba rgaining under 18 
this subsection and meets the following criteria:  19 
(a) The school administrative unit's percentage of economically 20 
disadvantaged students as determined pursuant to Title 20 -A, section 15675, 21 
subsection 2 is greater than the state average perc entage of economically 22 
disadvantaged students;  23 
(b)  The school administrative unit's regional adjustment as determined 24 
pursuant to Title 20 -A, section 15682 is less than 1;  25 
(c)  The school administrative unit's state share percentage as determined 26 
under Ti tle 20 -A, section 15672, subsection 31 is greater than 60%; and  27 
(d)  The school administrative unit operates a school; or  28 
(2)  After approval of the school board, petitions the Commissioner of Education 29 
to participate in collective bargaining under this su bsection.  The commissioner 30 
must respond to such a petition with an approval, a denial or a request for 31 
additional information within 30 days of receiving the request.  32 
G.  All collective bargaining agreements between bargaining agents and a 33 
participating s chool administrative unit entered into prior to completion of a contract 34 
pursuant to this subsection continue to be in effect and remain the financial 35 
responsibility of the participating school administrative unit for the remainder of their 36 
terms unless th e bargaining agent and participating school administrative unit 37 
mutually agree otherwise.  38 
This subsection does not prohibit the negotiation of salary and benefits in addition to 39 
what is negotiated between the State and the bargaining agent under this subse ction.  40

shall undertake a comprehensive attendance initiative, looking at a holistic approach to 11 
supp ortive services to children to ensure they are attending school and receiving the 12 
necessary supports for positive educational outcomes.  The department shall report to the 13 
Joint Standing Committee on Education and Cultural Affairs on the status of this wor k by 14 
January 31, 2018.  15

Amend the bill by striking out all of the Parts left blank intentionally.  17

SUMMARY  20 
PART A  21 
 22 
This Part makes appropriations and allocations of funds for the 2018 -2019 biennium.  23 
PART B  24 
 25 
This Part makes appropriations and allocations of funds for approved reclassifications 26 
and range changes.  27 
PART C  28 
 29 
This Part does the following.  30 
1.  It establishes the total cost of education from kindergarten to grade 12 for fiscal 31 
year 2017 -18, the state contr ibution and the annual target for the state share percentage.  32 
2.  It provides statutory changes to the Essential Programs and Services Funding Act 33 
for implementation in the 2017 -2018 school year.  34 
3.  It provides statutory changes to the Essential Programs and Services Funding Act 35 
for implementation in the 2018 -2019 school year.  36 
4.  It provides statutory changes for the funding and oversight of the Maine School 37 
for Marine Science, Technology, Transportation and Engineering.  38 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 835 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  5.  It directs the Commissioner of  Education to develop a plan for funding public 1 
education from kindergarten to grade 12.  The plan must be based on providing direct 2 
instruction and support for student learning and include the establishment of a system to 3 
measure and ensure accountability  for the use of the state funds.  The new school funding 4 
formula must be presented to the Legislature for consideration by the 2019 -2020 school 5 
year.  6 
6.  It sets the effective dates for certain sections of this Part.  7 
PART D  8 
 9 
This Part makes changes to the individual and corporate income taxes, including:  10 
1.  Eliminating, for tax years beginning in 2017 or after, the 3% income tax surcharge 11 
imposed on taxable income in excess of $200,000 and eliminating the Fund to Advance 12 
Public Kindergarten to Grade 12 Edu cation since the source of that fund is the 3% 13 
income tax surcharge;  14 
2. Amending individual income tax rates and the income amounts to which those 15 
rates apply for tax years beginning in 2018 or after;  16 
3.  Increasing the maximum Maine pension income deducti on for nonmilitary 17 
retirement plan benefits from $10,000 to $35,000 over a 5 -year period beginning with the 18 
2017 tax year. The $35,000 deduction amount that applies to tax years beginning after 19 
2021 is subject to an annual inflation adjustment;  20 
4.  Elimina ting the top corporate income tax rate of 8.93% for tax years beginning on 21 
or after January 1, 2018;  22 
5.  Eliminating for taxable corporations the alternative minimum tax for tax years 23 
beginning after December 31, 2016;  24 
6.  Increasing the income tax credit for child care expenses so that the credit for all 25 
child care expenses, whether or not quality child care expenses, is 50% of the federal 26 
child care credit for the taxable year. Under current law, the Maine credit is 25% of the 27 
federal child care credit un less the related child care expenses are considered quality child 28 
care expenses, in which case the Maine credit is 50% of the federal child care credit. As 29 
in current law, the credit is refundable up to $500.  The change applies to tax years 30 
beginning afte r December 31, 2017; and  31 
7.  Correcting cross -references to reflect the new income tax brackets.  32 
PART E  33 
 34 
This Part increases the sales tax on lodging from 9% to 10% beginning October 1, 35 
2017 and amends the provision of law regarding transfers to the Touris m Marketing 36 
Promotion Fund to reflect the increase in the lodging tax and expands the provision for 37 
sellers required to register to collect and report sales taxes to include online real property 38 
rental platforms and room remarketers.  39 
PART G  40 
 41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 836 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  Under current law, the homestead property tax exemption for property tax years 1 
beginning on or after April 1, 2017 increased by $5,000 to $20,000 and the percentage of 2 
state reimbursement to municipalities for property taxes lost as a result of the exemption 3 
increased f rom 50% to 62.5%.  This Part eliminates the increase in the exemption and 4 
state reimbursement amounts for property tax years beginning on or after April 1, 2017.  5 
PART I  6 
 7 
This Part phases out the business equipment tax reimbursement, or BETR, program 8 
and tr ansitions property eligible for the BETR program as of April 1, 2018 into the 9 
business equipment tax exemption, or BETE, program. Property located at a retail sales 10 
facility and used in a retail sales activity first put into service on or after April 1, 20 18 11 
will no longer be eligible for either the BETR or BETE program. Such retail property 12 
placed into service on or before April 1, 2018 that qualifies for the BETE program will no 13 
longer be eligible for exemption after 2027.  14 
PART K  15 
 16 
This Part permanently se ts the transfer to the Local Government Fund for state - 17 
municipal revenue sharing at 2%.  18 
PART L  19 
 20

agencies.  This Part also authorizes any remaining balance in the Department of 23 
Administrative and Financial Services, Information Services program, General Fund 24 
account at the close of fiscal year 2016 -17 to be carried forward into the new Depa rtment 25

General Fund account to be used for the same purposes.  27

PART N  8

This Part makes the following changes to the laws governing the Consensus 10 
Economic Forecasting Commission.  11 
1.  It allows the terms of commission members to be staggered.  12 
2.  It changes reporting requirements to conform to current practice  and adds a 13 
requirement that at least 2 economic forecasts assuming potential economic recession 14 
scenarios be provided no later than February 1st in even -numbered years.  15 
3.  It changes the required number of meetings of the commission and the Revenue 16 
Forec asting Committee from 4 a year to 3.  17 
4.  It adds a requirement that the commission and the committee jointly issue a report 18 
to the Governor, the Legislative Council and the joint standing committee of the 19 
Legislature having jurisdiction over appropriations  and financial affairs that uses the 20 
potential economic recession scenarios.  21

PART EEEE  37 
 38 
This Part repeals provisions of the Temporary Assistance fo r Needy Families, or 39 
TANF, and food supplement statutes that prohibit the Department of Health and Human 40 
Services from denying benefits based on a felony drug conviction. It also establishes a 41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 847 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  requirement that to be eligible for TANF or food supplement ben efits an individual must 1 
not have been convicted of a drug -related felony within 5 years of the date of application 2 
or while receiving benefits. This Part also repeals the provision that allows the 3 
department to administer drug tests to convicted drug felo ns in the TANF program 4 
because it is no longer necessary due to the eligibility requirement.  5 
PART FFFF  6 
 7 
This Part makes the following changes to the laws governing the Temporary 8 
Assistance for Needy Families, or TANF, program.  9 
1.  It establishes asset and time limits for transitional child care services of $100,000 10 
and 18 months, respectively.  11 
2.  It shortens the lifetime limit on TANF benefits from 60 months to 48 months.  12 
3.  It establishes the requirement for a TANF applicant to participate in a job 13 
readi ness evaluation program prior to being granted TANF cash benefits.  14 
4.  It provides that for a first failure to meet the conditions of a family contract under 15 
TANF, termination of benefits is for 60 days and applies to the adult recipient and the full 16 
famil y unit and for a 2nd and subsequent violation, termination of benefits is for 90 days 17 
and applies to the adult recipient and the full family unit.  18 
5.  It amends the alternative aid laws to make such aid available no more than once 19 
every 24 months, instead of once every 12 months.  20 
6.  It removes all the good cause exceptions that prevent a person from being 21 
sanctioned under the ASPIRE -TANF program for failure to participate in that program, 22 
with the exception of domestic violence.  23 
7.  It removes the 24 -month  limit on education training and treatment for participants 24 
in the ASPIRE -TANF program in order to eliminate the difference between Maine and 25 
federal law regarding the number of months of education and training that may qualify as 26 
countable work activities  and specifies that accommodations for an individual with a 27 
disability are limited to those required by federal law. It amends laws governing the 28 
Parents as Scholars Program to specify that an enrollee in the program must meet federal 29 
work participation re quirements.  30 
8.  It creates a penalty for quitting or losing a job for a recipient of TANF cash 31 
assistance if the job was quit or lost without good cause.  32 
9.  It establishes the Fund for the Payment of Federal Fines Imposed for 33 
Noncompliance with Federal Wo rk Participation Requirements in the Department of 34 
Health and Human Services. The purpose of the fund is to pay fines imposed on the State 35 
by the Federal Government due to the State's failure to comply with federal requirements 36 
related to the ASPIRE -TANF p rogram.  The Part requires the Commissioner of Health 37 
and Human Services to report annually regarding the fines owed by the State for 38 
noncompliance to the joint standing committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction over 39 
health and human services matter s, which is required to report out a bill, within 30 days 40 
of the commissioner's report, appropriating the amount necessary to pay the fines.  41 
PART GGGG  42 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 848 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT   1 
This Part changes the disability determination cutoff from 45 days to 90 days for 2 
applications for aid b ased on a disability, and it eliminates the requirement to provide 3 
state-funded temporary medical coverage.  The Part also directs the Department of Health 4 
and Human Services to seek relief from any requirement in the Polk v. Longley  consent 5 
decree requiri ng the department to act on Medicaid applications within 45 days and 6 
provides that the change from 45 days to 90 days for applications for aid based on a 7 
disability does not take effect until the department receives that relief.  8 
PART HHHH  9 
 10 
This Part amends  the definition of "eligible person" in the municipal general 11 
assistance laws to remove language that includes under the definition a person who is 12 
lawfully present in the United States or who is pursuing a lawful process to apply for 13 
immigration relief an d to add language that excludes under the definition a noncitizen 14 
who is not eligible for federal benefits pursuant to 8 United States Code, Sections 1621 15 
and 1641.  16 
PART IIII  17 
 18 
This Part specifies that the base year for the hospital tax is 2014.  19 
PART JJJJ  20 
 21 
This Part prohibits the Department of Health and Human Services from obtaining 22 
waivers from the United States Department of Agriculture that would expand access to 23 
benefits under the statewide food supplement program.  24 
PART KKKK  25 
 26 
This Part does the followin g. 27 
1.  It repeals the provision that requires the Department of Health and Human 28 
Services to provide a food supplement program for noncitizens who would be eligible for 29 
federal Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program benefits but for their status as alie ns 30 
under the federal Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 31 
1996.  32 
2.  It repeals the provision that requires the department to provide supplemental 33 
security income for noncitizens who would be eligible for federal supplemental s ecurity 34 
income but for their status as aliens under the federal Personal Responsibility and Work 35 
Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996.  36 
3.  It repeals the provision that requires the department to provide financial assistance 37 
to noncitizens who would be e ligible for Temporary Assistance for Needy Families but 38 
for their status as aliens under the federal Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity 39 
Reconciliation Act of 1996.  40 
PART LLLL  41 
 42

 5

available balances of appropriations between the MaineCare General Fund accounts for 7 
both fiscal years of the 2018 -2019 biennium.  8 
PART NNNN  9 
 10 
This Part does the following.  11 
1.  It authorizes the Department of Health and Human Services to transfer by 12 
financia l order certain available appropriations, including those in Personal Services, 13 
among MaineCare, MaineCare -related and non -MaineCare -related accounts.  14 
2.  It authorizes the Department of Health and Human Services to transfer by 15 
financial order available Pe rsonal Services balances in the Disproportionate Share - 16 
Dorothea Dix Psychiatric Center program, the Disproportionate Share - Riverview 17 
Psychiatric Center program and the Riverview Psychiatric Center program to the All 18 
Other line category of those program s in order to provide flexibility in the payment of 19 
operational expenses.  20 
PART OOOO  21 
 22 
This Part eliminates, beginning July 1, 2019, the authority of the Department of 23 
Health and Human Services to transfer dedicated family support services funds between 24 
the Developmental Services - Community program and the Office of Aging and 25 
Disability Services Central Office program and Long Term Care - Office of Aging and 26 
Disability Services program.  27

 29

from the Department of Health and Human Services, Developmental Services - 31 
Community program to the Crisis Outreach Program for the 2018 -2019 biennium.  32

 34 
This Part authorizes the Department of Health and Human Services to  transfer 35 
appropriations within the Office of Child and Family Services related to the cost of 36 
administering the child welfare program.  37

 39

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 850 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  PART SSSS  1 
 2 
This Part renames the Division of Licensing and Regulatory Services program within 3 
the Department of Health and Human Services the Division of Licensing and 4 
Certification pro gram.  5 
PART TTTT  6 
 7 
This Part gives the Department of Health and Human Services the authority to adopt 8 
emergency rules to implement any provisions of this bill over which it has specific 9 
authority that has not been addressed by some other Part of the bill wit hout the necessity 10 
of demonstrating that immediate adoption is necessary to avoid a threat to public health, 11 
safety or welfare.  12 
PART UUUU  13 
 14 
This Part amends the laws governing the Maine Commission on Indigent Legal 15 
Services.  It requires the eligibility sta ndards developed by the commission to take into 16 
account the ability of a person to make periodic installment payments toward counsel 17 
fees.  It requires the commission, at least every 5 years, to review the standards for 18 
evaluating counsel.  It modifies and  adds to the duties of the commission.  It specifies that 19 
the executive director of the commission may contract for personnel.  It provides that 20 
non-General Fund funds received by the commission do not lapse at the end of the fiscal 21 
year.  It requires the executive director of the commission to establish procedures to 22 
verify and review the eligibility of persons for indigent legal services and requires the 23 
executive director to provide the court information used to determine indigency for 24 
guidance to the co urt in determining a person's financial ability to obtain private counsel.  25 
It provides for reimbursement and installment payments for persons determined by the 26 
court to be able to contribute to payment of assigned or contract counsel.  It exempts from 27 
the prohibition on disclosing tax information the disclosure to the commission of tax 28 
information for the purpose of determining the eligibility for indigent legal services and 29 
the ability to reimburse expenses incurred by counsel.  30 
This Part requires the Stat e Controller to transfer $16,400,290 from the 31 
unappropriated surplus of the General Fund to the Maine Commission on Indigent Legal 32 
Services, Reserve for Indigent Legal Services program, Other Special Revenue Funds and 33 
stipulates that funds may not be trans ferred out of the Reserve for Indigent Legal Services 34 
program without legislative approval.  35 
This Part also establishes the Working Group to Improve the Provision of Indigent 36 
Legal Services.  The working group consist of 11 members including 2 Senators and 2 37 
members of the House of Representatives.  The other members represent the other 38 
stakeholders, including 2 appointed by the Chief Justice of the Supreme Judicial Court. 39 
Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the working group may access data 40 
maintain ed by the Maine Commission on Indigent Legal Services and shall maintain the 41 
confidentiality of any confidential information provided to the working group.  The 42 
working group may invite the participation and input of additional interested parties and 43 
reque st information as necessary to carry out its duties.  44 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “  B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 851 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  The working group must submit a report, including recommendations, by December 1 
6, 2017.  The Joint Standing Committee on Judiciary may report out legislation to the 2 
Second Regular Session of the 128th Le gislature.  3 
PART VVVV  4 
 5 
This Part delays the funding of the Fiscal Stability Program until the 2020 -2021 6 
biennial budget.  7 
PART WWWW  8 
 9 
This Part directs the State Controller to transfer funds from the Inland Fisheries and 10 
Wildlife Carrying Balances - General F und account to the Enforcement Operations - 11 
Inland Fisheries and Wildlife program, General Fund account to purchase one 12 
replacement aircraft engine in fiscal year 2017 -18 and one replacement aircraft engine in 13 
fiscal year 2018 -19. 14 
PART XXXX  15 
 16 
This Part incr eases compensation of active retired judges and justices of the state 17 
courts from $300 per day to $375 per day and from $175 per 1/2 day to $215 per 1/2 day.  18 
PART YYYY  19 
 20 
This Part clarifies that the record search fee schedule established by the State Court 21 
Administrator is for those record searches performed by Judicial Department employees 22 
and specifies that the record search fees deposited into the fund for use by the State Court 23 
Administrator to fund publications, forms and information technology are thos e fees for 24 
record searches performed by Judicial Department employees.  25 
This Part also allows the Supreme Judicial Court to raise or establish fees on online 26 
electronic case searches performed by Judicial Department employees, document delivery 27 
and case fil ings and surcharges on fines for the purpose of paying the cost of maintaining 28 
an electronic filing and court information management system.  29 
PART ZZZZ  30 
 31 
This Part removes the requirement that the salaries of the Director of Labor 32 
Standards, the Chair of the  Maine Unemployment Insurance Commission and the 33 
members of the Maine Unemployment Insurance Commission be subject to adjustment 34 
by the Governor.  It provides that the Commissioner of Labor sets the salaries of the 35 
Director of the Bureau of Unemployment Co mpensation, the chair of the Maine 36 
Unemployment Insurance Commission and the members of the Maine Unemployment 37 
Insurance Commission.  38 
It provides that the members of the Maine Unemployment Insurance Commission 39 
must be sworn and may be removed by the Governo r for inefficiency, willful neglect of 40 
duty or malfeasance in office, but only with the review and concurrence of the joint 41 
standing committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction over labor matters upon hearing 42 
in executive session or by impeachment. Be fore removing a commission member, the 43 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ B” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 852 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  Governor shall notify the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of 1 
Representatives of the removal and the reasons for the removal.  2 
PART AAAAA  3 
 4 
This Part moves the original jurisdiction of employer unemp loyment appeals cases 5 
from the Maine Unemployment Insurance Commission, the members of which are 6 
appointed by the Governor, to the Department of Labor, Bureau of Unemployment 7 
Compensation, Division of Administrative Hearings to conform with federal law.  8 
This Part also revises the law to comply with Section 303(a)(3) of the federal Social 9 
Security Act, which requires that the first level of appeals hearings must be conducted by 10 
a merit -staffed governmental employee in order to meet the impartial hearing requ irement 11 
of Section 303(a)(3). For the purposes of this provision, "merit -staffed" means that the 12 
individuals are subject to personnel standards based on a merit system and are not 13 
political appointees.  14 
PART BBBBB  15 
 16 
This Part repeals the provision of law tha t prohibits any unencumbered balance in the 17 
Competitive Skills Scholarship Fund from being used for a different purpose without 18 
legislative approval.  19 
PART CCCCC  20 
 21 
Section 1 of the Part changes the weekly benefit subtraction factor for partial 22 
unemployment f rom $25 to $100 to incentivize reemployment and connection to the 23 
workforce.  24 
The remainder of this Part changes the experience rating and the lowest tax schedule 25 
to make Maine unemployment tax rates more equitable. The chargeability of benefit 26 
charges is r evenue neutral.  27 
PART DDDDD  28 
 29 
This Part authorizes the Department of Labor to identify positions to eliminate as the 30 
result of ongoing reorganizations.  31 
PART EEEEE  32 
 33 
This Part establishes new surcharges on licenses issued by the Department of Marine 34 
Resources and directs the new surcharges to the Coastal Fisheries Research, Management 35 
and Enforcement Fund, Other Special Revenue Funds account established in the 36 
department. The fund must be used to fund scientific research, management and 37 
enforcement activities r elated to marine resources.  38 
PART FFFFF  39 
 40

 Page 853 - 128LR2175(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  This Part renames the Board of Registration for Professional Engineers program 1 
within the Department of Professional and Financial Regulation the State Board of 2 
Licensure for Professional Engineers program.  3 
PART IIII I 4 
 5 
This Part provides that the Executive Director of the Gambling Control Unit has the 6 
authority to administer and enforce the provisions of the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 7 
17, chapter 13 -A governing the conduct of beano and Title 17, chapter 62 governin g 8 
games of chance.  9 
PART JJJJJ  10 
 11 
This Part transfers the oversight, administration and enforcement of the Maine 12 
Revised Statutes, Title 17, chapter 13 -A governing beano from the Chief of the State 13 
Police to the Gambling Control Unit within the Department of Public Safety.  It reduces 14 
some requirements for organizations that conduct beano, such as requiring them to 15 
register with the Gambling Control Unit rather than apply for a license and to maintain 16 
records of the use of proceeds from beano rather than regul arly file disposition of funds 17 
reports with the Gambling Control Unit.  High -stakes beano under Title 17, chapter 13 -A 18 
is still subject to licensure.  This Part also adds some provisions to Title 17, chapter 13 -A 19 
to permit schools, campgrounds and resorts to conduct beano for the entertainment of 20 
their guests, including children under 16 years of age, as long as certain requirements are 21 
met. 22 
PART KKKKK  23 
 24 
This Part transfers in the Department of Public Safety the oversight, administration 25 
and enforcement of t he Maine Revised Statutes, Title 17, chapter 62 governing games of 26 
chance from a licensing unit to the Gambling Control Unit.  It reduces some requirements 27 
for organizations that conduct certain games of chance, such as requiring them to register 28 
with the Gambling Control Unit rather than apply for a license and maintaining records of 29 
the use of proceeds from games rather than regularly filing disposition of funds reports 30 
with the Gambling Control Unit.  Card games and most tournament games are still 31 
subjec t to licensure under this Part.  It adds a provision that permits the operation of 32 
cribbage tournaments for charitable purposes without a license.  These tournaments are 33 
not required to be conducted by a nonprofit organization and may be conducted in place s 34 
like a restaurant or brewery tap room.  Entry fees are limited to $25, and all fees must be 35 
paid as prizes or donated to a verifiable charitable purpose.  It also makes changes 36 
regarding the conduct of raffles for charitable purposes, including a provisi on that permits 37 
the conduct of a raffle with a prize value up to $1,000 to be conducted by a person or 38 
organization without having to be licensed by or registered with the Gambling Control 39 
Unit.  40 
PART LLLLL  41 
 42 
This Part provides that public safety inspectors in the Department of Public Safety, 43 
Office of the State Fire Marshal for the purpose of enforcing the Maine Revised Statutes, 44

criminal and civil violation process against offenders who violate the National Fire 3 
Protection Association No. 101, Life Safety Code.  4 
PART MMMMM  5 
 6 
This Part amends the law regarding examinations of plans for constru ction, 7 
reconstruction or repairs submitted to the Department of Public Safety by establishing a 8 
single fee schedule for new construction, reconstruction, repairs and renovations of 1.5/10 9 
of 1% of the cost to construct or reconstruct the portion of the pro ject subject to State Fire 10 
Marshal review.  11

 13

from the Gambling Control Board program, Other Special Revenue Funds account in the 15 
Department of Public Safety by the  end of fiscal year 2018 -19 to the General Fund 16 
unappropriated surplus.  17

 19

in an amount not to exceed $100,000,000 to be used for capital repairs and improvements  21 
to buildings within the University of Maine System.  22 
PART QQQQQ  23 
 24 
This Part clarifies that there are 2 deputy commissioner positions within the 25 
Department of Administrative and Financial Services.  This Part also authorizes the 26 
Commissioner of Administrativ e and Financial Services to reorganize the Bureau of 27 
General Services and submit a bill in the Second Regular Session of the 128th Legislature 28 
to enact the reorganization.  29 
PART RRRRR  30 
 31

undedicated revenue annually to the Agriculture Promotion Fund in the Department of 33 
Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry.  34 
PART SSSSS  35 
 36 
This Part provides the Commissioner of Corrections authority to inspect, review and 37 
take custody of records of county jails related to the funding and operation of county jails.  38 
This Part requires the Department of Corrections by February 15, 2018 to submit a 39 
report to the Joint Standing Committee on Appropriations and Financial Affairs on plans 40

prisoner population and capacity.  42

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  PART TTTTT  1 
 2

PART UUUUU  4 
 5 
This Part transfers responsibility for the administr ation of the Fund for the Efficient 6 
Delivery of Local and Regional Services from the Department of Administrative and 7 
Financial Services to the Department of Economic and Community Development.  This 8 
Part also adds capital grants as a 3rd type of grant ava ilable from the fund; current law 9 
provides for planning grants and cooperative services grants.  10 
PART VVVVV  11 
 12 
This Part provides for the creation of 9 to 12 school management and leadership 13 
centers. School administrative units may voluntarily establish a sch ool management and 14 
leadership center through an interlocal agreement and may include associate members 15 
through contractual agreements or memoranda of understanding.  A school management 16 
and leadership center provides administrative and education functions in accordance with 17 
the interlocal agreement and functions as an extension of the schools that are members of 18 
the school management and leadership center.  Participating school administrative units 19 
voluntarily choose which educational functions or support s ervices they purchase from a 20 
school management and leadership center.  21 
PART XXXXX  22 
 23 
This Part allows the Commissioner of Education to authorize one additional public 24 
charter school in each school year through the 2021 -2022 school year once the statutory 25 
cap of 10 public charter schools is reached.  26 
PART YYYYY  27 
 28 
This Part establishes an annual open enrollment period for secondary students during 29 
which they may request to transfer to a public high school outside of their resident school 30 
administrative unit for th e subsequent school year without the approval of their resident 31 
school administrative unit. This Part also requires that parents of secondary students be 32 
notified of this option by March 1st of each year.  For the purposes of the Essential 33 
Programs and Ser vices Funding Act, the residency of a student is considered to be the 34 
school administrative unit to which the student transferred.  35 
PART ZZZZZ  36 
 37 
This Part directs the Department of Education to establish education savings accounts 38 
for no more than 100 childr en with disabilities that may be used by the parents or legal 39 
guardians of such children for certain educational purposes. The parent or legal guardian 40 
and the Department of Education must enter into a written agreement governing the terms 41 
of the account a nd how the funds will be used. The funding for these accounts would 42 
come from shifting 90% of the essential programs and services funding that would 43

the savings accoun t. The Part provides mechanisms for approval of educational 2

PART AAAAAA  4 
 5 
This Part adds engaging in training and staff development for identification of and 6 
provision of intervention services for children with autism to the program functions of the 7 
Child Development Services System.  8 
PART BBBBBB  9 
 10 
This Part amends the career and technical education laws to enable career and 11 
technical education programs to serve students in g rades 6 to 8.  12 
PART CCCCCC  13 
 14 
This Part requires the University of Maine System, the Maine Community College 15 
System and the Maine Maritime Academy to report the cost to students of remedial 16 
courses in the subjects of English language arts and mathematics, by school 17 
administrative unit for students graduating within the prior 3 years from a school in that 18 
school administrative unit.  The Part requires the Commissioner of Education to reduce 19 
state subsidy to the school administrative units and to pay those funds  to the higher 20 
education institution where the students took those remedial courses. Those higher 21 
education institutions are required to use the funds to reduce or eliminate the cost of 22 
remedial courses to their students and to report to the Commissioner o f Education and the 23 
Legislature how those funds were used to achieve the reduction or elimination of those 24 
costs.  25 
PART DDDDDD  26 
 27 
This Part authorizes the State to bargain for a contract for standard salary and benefits 28 
for public education employees in parti cipating school districts.  This Part also establishes 29 
annual targets for the percentage share of expenditures by regional school units on direct 30 
instruction, which includes regular instruction, special education, career and technical 31 
education and other i nstruction including summer school and extracurricular instruction.  32 
PART EEEEEE  33 
 34 
This Part directs the Department of Education to review the work of the 35 
public -private partnership Count ME In and to undertake a comprehensive attendance 36 
initiative to addres s truancy.  This Part also directs the department to report to the Joint 37 
Standing Committee on Education and Cultural Affairs by January 31, 2018.  38

 40

 9

 23
